Service, Honey-Be Breeding, Genetics & Physiology Lab., 1157 Ben Hur Rd., Baton Rouge, LA 70820, USA
Abstract: Two lines of Apis mellifera carnica were selectively propagated from an assembled parental stock through four generations. The resulting lines of bees diverged to be comparatively resistant and susceptible, respectively, to Varroa jacobsoni. Much of this phenotypic variation in honey bee response to Varroa has a genetic component. Since important portions of this genetic variation are additive, selective breeding shows good promise for providing the desired long-term solutions to Varroa mite difficulties. -Authors

Title: Criteria for nest site selection in honey bees (Hymenoptera: Apidae) : preferences between pheromone attractants and cavity shapes
Affiliations: Carl Hayden Bee Research Center, USDA-ARS, 2000 E. Allen Road, Tucson, AZ 85719, USA.
Authors with affiliations: Schmidt, J.O., Carl Hayden Bee Research Center, USDA-ARS, 2000 E. Allen Road, Tucson, AZ 85719, USA.; Thoenes, S.C., Carl Hayden Bee Research Center, USDA-ARS, 2000 E. Allen Road, Tucson, AZ 85719, USA.
Abstract: Nerolic acid, the second most abundant compound in the Nasonov pheromone of Apis mellifera, was investigated to determine its importance as a component in synthetic attractants. Both Africanized and European populations preferred synthetic pheromone blends containing nerolic acid in combination with citral and geraniol to those containing only citral and geraniol. Nest cavity shape, tapered cylinder versus rectangular prism, apparently is not an important factor in cavity acceptance by honey bee swarms. -from Authors

Authors: Matis J.H., Rubink W.L., Makela M.
Title: Use of the gamma distribution for predicting arrival times of invading insect populations
Affiliations: Lab. for Biostratistics & Biosystems Modeling, Dept. of Statistics, Texas A&M Univ., College Station, TX 77843-3143, USA
Authors with affiliations: Matis, J.H., Lab. for Biostratistics & Biosystems Modeling, Dept. of Statistics, Texas A&M Univ., College Station, TX 77843-3143, USA; Rubink, W.L., Lab. for Biostratistics & Biosystems Modeling, Dept. of Statistics, Texas A&M Univ., College Station, TX 77843-3143, USA; Makela, M., Lab. for Biostratistics & Biosystems Modeling, Dept. of Statistics, Texas A&M Univ., College Station, TX 77843-3143, USA
Abstract: Models that describe the distance traveled in a fixed time of a dispersing insect population are well-known. The gamma distribution is presented as a model for the inverse variable, namely the time required to travel a fixed distance. Use of the model is illustrated by fitting it to data on the consecutive northernmost captures of honeybee Apis mellifera swarms through Guatemala and Mexico. -from Authors

Title: The cytochrome b and ATPase genes of honeybee mitochondrial DNA
Affiliations: Dept. of Genetics/Human Variation, La Trobe University, Bundoora, Vic. 3083, Australia
Authors with affiliations: Crozier, R.H., Dept. of Genetics/Human Variation, La Trobe University, Bundoora, Vic. 3083, Australia; Crozier, Y.C., Dept. of Genetics/Human Variation, La Trobe University, Bundoora, Vic. 3083, Australia
Abstract: The gene sequences for honeybee cytochrome b, ATPase 6, and ATPase 8 are presented, along with the inferred amino acid sequences of the proteins. These mitochondrial genes are in the same relative positions as are their counterparts in Drosophila mitochondrial mtDNA and have evolved at a significantly greater overall rate than have those of Drosophila. Comparisons using both amino acid identity and the proportion of conservative replacements between the inferred Apis and vertebrate cytochrome b sequences shows the two highly conserved sections reported by Howell, but his recognition of five conserved regions is not well supported. A very high AT bias is reflected in very high codon biases. The best predictors of the number of occurrences of an amino acid in honeybee cytochrome b are the T and G contents of its codon family-unlike the case for vertebrate cytochrome b, in which the codon family size and AT bias are the strongest predictors; protein function, at least as judged by hydrophilicity characteristics, appears to be unaffected by these differing influences on amino acid composition.
Author Keywords: ATPase genes; cytochrome b; honeybee

Title: The essence of royalty: honey bee queen pheromone
Authors with affiliations: Winston, M.L.; Slessor, K.N.
Abstract: Describes new findings on the mechanisms of coordination of individuals in an Apis mellifera colony. Discusses the composition and role of pheromones on behaviour and development of the colony rearing new queens and the development of ovaries in worker bees; how the fractions of the queen's pheromones that control the retinue response were identified; the functions of the queen's pheromones, including the presence/absence effects on the number of new queens raised and the control of swarming. The quantities of pheromones produced by the queen and how these were transmitted through the colony by retinue workers were studied, showing that most of the pheromones are internalised. -L.J.Chellis

Title: Reproductive biology of Crataegus monogyna in northwestern Spain
Affiliations: Laboratorio de Botanica, Facultad de Farmacia, Universidad de Santiago, 15071 Santiago de Compostela, Spain
Authors with affiliations: Guitian, J., Laboratorio de Botanica, Facultad de Farmacia, Universidad de Santiago, 15071 Santiago de Compostela, Spain; Fuentes, M., Laboratorio de Botanica, Facultad de Farmacia, Universidad de Santiago, 15071 Santiago de Compostela, Spain
Abstract: Flowering in hawthorn was in April and May, fruiting from September to January/February. Cross-pollinated and freely-exposed flowers had similar fruit set; these were about those of bagged flowers and manually self-pollinated flowers. The main pollinators were Apis mellifera (52% of pollinator visits) and several other Apidae and Diptera. The main seed dispersers were fruit-eating birds of the genus Turdus (96% of visits). Fruits were damaged by fruit pulp-eating insect larvae (Phagocarpus permundus and an unidentified lepidopteran) and birds (Pyrrhula pyrrhula, Fringilla coelebs and Phylloscopus collybita), and seed-eating birds (Coccothraustes coccothraustes). -from Authors

Title: An initial assessment of blueberry pollinators in new zealand
Source title: New Zealand Journal of Crop and Horticultural Science
Affiliations: DSIR Plant Protection, Private Bag, Christchurch, New Zealand
Authors with affiliations: Macfarlane, R.P., DSIR Plant Protection, Private Bag, Christchurch, New Zealand
Abstract: The short tongued bumble bee, Bombus terrestris (L.), followed by the honey bee, Apis mellifera L., were the commonest blueberry pollinators at Lincoln, New Zealand. At most, 7% of honey bee visits and 24% of B. terrestris visits to blueberry flowers could have resulted in pollination. Honey bees visited flowering shelter adjacent to the blueberries more often than the bumble bees did. The long tongued bumble bees, B. hortorum (L.) and B. ruderatus (Fabr.), consistently pollinated blueberry flowers, but low populations restricted their value in pollination. There were no other effective insect pollinators of blueberries. © 1992 The Royal Society of New Zealand.
Author Keywords: Apis mellifera; Blueberry pollination; Bombus terrestris; Bumble bees; Competing flowers; Honey bees; New Zealand

Authors: Spivak M., Zeltzer A., Degrandi-Hoffman G., Martin J.H.
Title: Influence of temperature on rate of development and color patterns of queen honey bees (Hymenoptera: Apidae)
Affiliations: Carl Hayden Bee Research Center, USAD-ARS, 2000 E Allen Road, Tucson, Arizona 857619, USA.
Authors with affiliations: Spivak, M., Carl Hayden Bee Research Center, USAD-ARS, 2000 E Allen Road, Tucson, Arizona 857619, USA.; Zeltzer, A., Carl Hayden Bee Research Center, USAD-ARS, 2000 E Allen Road, Tucson, Arizona 857619, USA.; Degrandi-Hoffman, G., Carl Hayden Bee Research Center, USAD-ARS, 2000 E Allen Road, Tucson, Arizona 857619, USA.; Martin, J.H., Carl Hayden Bee Research Center, USAD-ARS, 2000 E Allen Road, Tucson, Arizona 857619, USA.
Abstract: Apis mellifera queens completed the postcapping period (last instar and pupal stages) in incubators maintained at temperatures corresponding with the natural range found in the brood nest: 30.5, 33.5, and 35.5°V. The black queen line required significantly fewer accumulated degree-days for development than the yellow line at all temperatures. The queens from both lines had significantly more yellow coloration on the integument when they completed the postcapping period at 35.5°C than at 30.5°C. -from Authors

Title: Regulation of division of labor in insect societies
Affiliations: Dept. of Entomology, Univ. of Illinois, Urbana, Illinois 61801, USA.
Authors with affiliations: Robinson, G.E., Dept. of Entomology, Univ. of Illinois, Urbana, Illinois 61801, USA.
Abstract: Deals with plasticity in division of labor and the processes that regulate it, focusing on highly eusocial species that are among those exhibiting the most complex forms of division of labor, especially honey bees Apis mellifera and ants. After describing the patterns of division of labor within insect colonies, the author outlines the social and ecological factors that affect division of labor and review the types of worker behavioral responses that occur when these factors change. He then discusses mechanisms that are involved in the regulation of division of labor, devoting special attention to recent hormonal and genetic studies of honey bees. The paper concludes with a discussion of several new theoretical approaches to the study of division of labor. -from Author

Title: Honeybees mark with scent and reject recently visited flowers
Affiliations: Departamento de Ciencias Biológicas, Facultad de Ciencias Exactas y Naturales, Universidad de Buenos Aires, Pb. II-Ciudad Universitaria, Buenos Aires, CP 1428, Argentina
Authors with affiliations: Giurfa, M., Departamento de Ciencias Biológicas, Facultad de Ciencias Exactas y Naturales, Universidad de Buenos Aires, Pb. II-Ciudad Universitaria, Buenos Aires, CP 1428, Argentina; Núñez, J.A., Departamento de Ciencias Biológicas, Facultad de Ciencias Exactas y Naturales, Universidad de Buenos Aires, Pb. II-Ciudad Universitaria, Buenos Aires, CP 1428, Argentina
Abstract: Experimental evidence is reported for flower-marking by honeybees (Apis mellifera ligustica) while they were foraging on an artificial patch of flowers yielding a continuous and equal flow of sucrose solution. Honeybees marked with scent and rejected all recently visited and nectar-depleted flowers. The short fade-out time of this scent allowed discrimination of flowers that temporarily provided no food. The repellent nature of this scent mark was demonstrated by the use of an air extractor connected to the patch; when the apparatus was turned on, the rejection behaviour disappeared. The movement pattern of foraging bees also contributed to foraging efficiency, as the probability of an immediate return to the flower just abandoned was very low. However, when a quick repeat visit took place, the presence of the repellent scent-mark promoted rapid rejection. © 1992 Springer-Verlag.
Author Keywords: Foraging behaviour; Foraging efficiency; Honeybee; Movement pattern; Scent-mark

Title: The biology and management of Africanized honey bees
Affiliations: Dept. of Biological Sciences, Simon Fraser Univ., Burnaby, British Columbia, V5A 1S6, Canada.
Authors with affiliations: Winston, M.L., Dept. of Biological Sciences, Simon Fraser Univ., Burnaby, British Columbia, V5A 1S6, Canada.
Abstract: Apis mellifera scutellata was introduced to South America in 1956 and has now spread through most of Latin America, and parts of the southern USA. This bee was preadapted to its new habitat, and seems to have had no geographical or ecological barrier to reduce or stop its spread. Differences are noted between temperate and tropical honeybees, including nests (Africanized bees have much smaller ones with lower volumes of honey storage), individual worker characteristics, colony reproduction and population growth rates (the swarming rate of Africanized bees being much higher than that of temperate bees), defensive behaviour (high levels of attack following minimal disturbance by Africanized bees), and foraging (greater emphasis on pollen by Africanized bees). Gene flow in the feral population has predominantly been towards maintaining original African traits. Comments are made on the impact and management of Africanized bees in tropical America, and the predicted range and impact in North America are discussed. -P.J.Jarvis

Title: Insects on cabbages and oilseed rape
Source title: Insects on cabbages and oilseed rape
Authors with affiliations: Kirk, W.D.J.
Abstract: This is a guide to the natural history and identification of these insects. Firstly, there is an account of the genus Brassica and its cultivation, and the importance of glucosinolates in deterring insects excepting brassica specialists. The life cycle of the insect herbivores are described, particularly the large white butterfly Pieris brassicae, cabbage root fly Delia radicum and cabbage seed weevil Ceutorhynchus assimilis, as well as elucidating interactions within the community of insects. In another section, the flower and its visitors, such as the honeybee Apis mellifera and pollen beetle Meligethes aeneus, are described. The main part of the publication is then devoted to the illustrated dichotomous identification keys to the whole range of insects: the major groups; larvae and non-flying adults; adult beetles; adult flies; and adult butterflies and moths. Lastly, techniques for preservation, trapping, etc., are given. -J.W.Cooper

Title: Diversity, abundance and behaviour of diurnal insects on flowering capitula of commercial sunflower in the transvaal
Source title: South African Journal of Plant and Soil
Affiliations: Apicultural Unit, Plant Protection Research Institute, Private Bag X134, Pretoria, 0001, South Africa; Department of Entomology, University of Pretoria, Pretoria, 0002, South Africa
Authors with affiliations: Du Toit, A.P., Apicultural Unit, Plant Protection Research Institute, Private Bag X134, Pretoria, 0001, South Africa; Holm, E., Department of Entomology, University of Pretoria, Pretoria, 0002, South Africa
Abstract: Sunflower, Helianthus annuus L., is an insect-pollinated crop and the different insect taxa visiting the flowering head play a role of greater or lesser importance in cross-pollination. Species diversity, abundance and behaviour of insects visiting commercial sunflower during flowering are reported for three sites in the Transvaal during 1985–87. The conventional strip-counting method was used to determine diversity and abundance, while notes on behaviour were taken at the same time. The mean number of insects per 100 capitula was 45, 147 and 64 at Settlers, Pretoria and Hartbeesfontein, respectively. Indigenous honeybees, Apis mellifera saltellata Lepeletier, were the most common in all study areas (71%, 86% and 46%, respectively). Other well-represented taxa included Heliothis armigera Hübner (American bollworm larvae), Asiylus atro- maculatus Blanchard (spotted maize beetles), Diptera (flies) and Hemiptera (bugs). Solitary bees were rare. © 1992 Taylor & Francis Group, LLC.
Author Keywords: Apis mellifera; Insect diversity; Pollination; Sunflower

Authors: Degrandi-Hoffman G., Thorp R., Loper G., Eisikowitch D.
Title: Identification and distribution of cross-pollinating honey-bees on almonds
Affiliations: Carl Hayden Bee Research and Biological Control Center, USDA-ARS, 2000 East Allen Road, Tucson, AZ 85719, USA
Authors with affiliations: Degrandi-Hoffman, G., Carl Hayden Bee Research and Biological Control Center, USDA-ARS, 2000 East Allen Road, Tucson, AZ 85719, USA; Thorp, R., Carl Hayden Bee Research and Biological Control Center, USDA-ARS, 2000 East Allen Road, Tucson, AZ 85719, USA; Loper, G., Carl Hayden Bee Research and Biological Control Center, USDA-ARS, 2000 East Allen Road, Tucson, AZ 85719, USA; Eisikowitch, D., Carl Hayden Bee Research and Biological Control Center, USDA-ARS, 2000 East Allen Road, Tucson, AZ 85719, USA
Abstract: Every individual Apis mellifera collected foraging on Prunus armeniaca blossoms had self-pollen on its body and 90% or more had cross-pollen. In 1988, 60-92% of the foragers had non-almond pollen on their bodies, while in 1989 the percentages were 92-100%. In 1988, 42.1-81.2% of stigmas examined had self-pollen, 36.8-68.7% had cross-pollen, and 43.7-94.0% had non-almond pollen. In 1989, 60-100% of the stigmas had self-pollen, 10-100% had cross-pollen, and 80-100% had non-almond pollen. Nut set on limbs adjacent to compatible pollen sources did not differ significantly from those within the same row adjacent to trees of the same cultivar (ie incompatible pollen sources). -from Authors

Title: Pollinator effectiveness and seed set in populations of Agalinis strictifolia (Scrophulariaceae)
Affiliations: Dept. of Botany, Univ. of Texas at Austin, Austin, TX 78713, USA.
Authors with affiliations: Dieringer, G., Dept. of Botany, Univ. of Texas at Austin, Austin, TX 78713, USA.
Abstract: Pollinator effectivness and seed production were studied for two Texas populations over a 4-yr period and were measured using single bee visit manipulations of flowers. No significant difference in pollinator effectiveness (pollen deposited on stigmas) was observed between the populations, but a significant difference between populations was observed in number of seeds produced per flower. The Wellhouse population produced three times as many seeds/flowers from a single pollinator visit as did the firefly Meadow population. Within each population, pollinators (Bombus pennsylvanicus and Apis mellifera) did not differ in the number of pollen grains deposited on stigmas or seeds produced per flower from single visit experiments. Differences in plant density, pollen viability, and ovules per flower also could not account for a significant amount of the variation. -from Author

Authors: Nyffeler M., Dean D.A., Sterling W.L.
Title: Diets, feeding specialization, and predatory role of two lynx spiders, Oxyopes salticus and Peucetia viridans (Araneae: Oxyopidae) , in a Texas cotton agroecosystem
Affiliations: Dept. of Entomology, Texas A&M Univ., College Station, TX 77843, USA.
Authors with affiliations: Nyffeler, M., Dept. of Entomology, Texas A&M Univ., College Station, TX 77843, USA.; Dean, D.A., Dept. of Entomology, Texas A&M Univ., College Station, TX 77843, USA.; Sterling, W.L., Dept. of Entomology, Texas A&M Univ., College Station, TX 77843, USA.
Abstract: The predation ecology of the striped lynx spider and green lynx spider was studied in an insecticide-free cotton field. Lynx spiders were the dominant arthropod predators. P. viridans is a powerful species (10.08 ± 0.52 mm body length) compared with O. salticus (4.24 ± 0.16 mm). O. salticus individuals fed on small-sized prey (2.41 ± 0.17 mm average prey length). P. viridans fed over a broader range of prey size classes and captured a higher proportion of the larger prey organisms (7.04 ± 0.73 mm average prey length). The lynx spiders are polyphagous insectivores that feed on a variety of prey species, predominantly Heteroptera, Hymenoptera, and Diptera. They also frequently eat other spiders. The most frequently captured prey of O. salticus were small Heteroptera (predominantly cotton fleahopper Pseudatomoscelis seriatus). P. viridans most frequently seized large stinging Hymenoptera (eg honey bee Apis mellifera). P. viridans is a significantly more polyphagous predator than the smaller-sized O. salticus. O. salticus, therefore, shows a better fit to the "model predator' of classical biological control because of its relative specialization. -from Authors

Title: Honeybee colony integration: Worker-worker interactions mediate hormonally regulated plasticity in division of labor
Source title: Proceedings of the National Academy of Sciences of the United States of America
Affiliations: Department of Entomology, University of Illinois, 320 Morrill Hall, 505 South Goodwin Avenue, Urbana, IL 61801, United States
Authors with affiliations: Huang, Z.-Y., Department of Entomology, University of Illinois, 320 Morrill Hall, 505 South Goodwin Avenue, Urbana, IL 61801, United States; Robinson, G.E., Department of Entomology, University of Illinois, 320 Morrill Hall, 505 South Goodwin Avenue, Urbana, IL 61801, United States
Abstract: Adult workers in honeybee (Apis mellifera) colonies exhibit plasticity in hormonally regulated, age-based division of labor by altering their pattern of behavioral development in response to changes in colony conditions. One form of this plasticity is precocious development: levels of juvenile hormone increase prematurely and bees begin foraging as much as 2 weeks earlier than average. We used two experimental paradigms inspired by developmental biology to study how bees obtain information on changing colony needs that results in precocious foraging. An analog of "cell culture," with bees reared outside of colonies in different sized groups, revealed that worker-worker interactions exert quantitative effects on endocrine and behavioral development. "Transplants" of older bees to colonies otherwise lacking foragers demonstrated that worker-worker interactions also affect behavioral development in whole colonies. These results provide insights to a long-standing problem in the biology of social insects and further highlight similarities in the integration of activity that exist between individuals in insect colonies and cells in metazoans.
Author Keywords: Apis mellifera; Information acquisition; Juvenile hormone; Ontogeny; Social organization

Title: The relative success of Africanized and European honey-bees over a range of life-zones in Costa Rica
Affiliations: Dept. of Entomology, Univ. of Kansas, Lawrence, Kansas 66045, USA
Authors with affiliations: Spivak, M., Dept. of Entomology, Univ. of Kansas, Lawrence, Kansas 66045, USA
Abstract: The reproductive success and biology of Africanized and European Apis mellifera were compared for a year over three life-zones from 900-2800m. Determinations of colony success and comparative biology included survivorship during the rainy season, causes of colony mortality, frequency of swarming, absconding, seasonal patterns of weight gain, brood-rearing (worker and drone), and nectar and pollen storage. More European than Africanized colonies died from gradual weakening, and only Africanized colonies absconded. Colony deaths and absconding occurred with approximately equal frequency over all elevations during the year. Almost three times as many Africanized as European colonies swarmed over the year. Most swarms occurred in the dry season at the lowest apiary, but both bee types issued swarms at the highest elevation. Africanized colonies weighed significantly more and maintained significantly larger worker brood areas than European colonies across all elevations for most months of the year, except at 2800 m from March-June. Africanized colonies reared more drones than European colonies, except during the dry season at the highest elevation. The most pronounced differences between the bee types were observed in the lowlands, which accounts for the rapid population growth and range expansion of Africanized bees, and their displacement of European bees in these areas. -from Authors

Authors: Peng Y.-S.C., Mussen E., Fong A., Montague M.A., Tyler T.
Title: Effects of chlortetracycline of honey bee worker larvae reared in vitro
Affiliations: Department of Entomology, University of California, Davis, CA 95616, United States
Authors with affiliations: Peng, Y.-S.C., Department of Entomology, University of California, Davis, CA 95616, United States; Mussen, E., Department of Entomology, University of California, Davis, CA 95616, United States; Fong, A., Department of Entomology, University of California, Davis, CA 95616, United States; Montague, M.A., Department of Entomology, University of California, Davis, CA 95616, United States; Tyler, T., Department of Entomology, University of California, Davis, CA 95616, United States
Abstract: An in vitro method was developed for rearing worker honey bee (Apis mellifera L.) larvae to the adult stage. Average larval and postdefecation mortalities were 9.5% and 18.1% respectively. Larval and postdefecation development times were similar to worker brood reared in field colonies. Only 1 of 30 sampled adult bees exhibited queen or intercaste characteristics. The in vitro rearing method subsequently was used in studying the effect of the antibiotic chlortetracycline on larval growth and development. A general dose response was observed in mortalities of larvae fed diets containing 0.0025% to 0.05% chlortetracycline. At 0.0025%, larval and postdefecation mortalities were similar to the controls. At this concentration, chlortetracycline effectively reduced larval and postdefecation mortalities of larvae inoculated with 1 × 104 to 1.5 × 108 spores/ml of Bacillus larvae, the causative pathogen of American foulbrood disease. Chlortetracycline doses higher than 0.0025% retarded larval growth and development and caused precocious pigmentation in early larval instars. © 1992.
Author Keywords: American foulbrood; antibiotics; Apis mellifera; Bacillus larvae; chlortetracycline; disease; honey bee; in vitro rearing; treatment

Authors: Korpela S., Aarhus A., Fries I., Hansen H.
Title: Varroa jacobsoni Oud. In cold climates: Population growth, winter mortality and influence on the survival of honey bee colonies
Affiliations: Agricultural Research Centre of Finland, Institute of Plant Protection, Jokioinen, FIN-31600, Finland; Agricultural University of Norway, Department of Animal Science, Box 5025, Ås, N-1432, Norway; Swedish University of Agricultural Sciences, Bee Division, Uppsala, S-75007, Sweden; Danish Institute of Plant and Soil Science, Department of Apiculture, Ledreborg allé 98, Roskilde, DK-4000, Denmark
Authors with affiliations: Korpela, S., Agricultural Research Centre of Finland, Institute of Plant Protection, Jokioinen, FIN-31600, Finland; Aarhus, A., Agricultural University of Norway, Department of Animal Science, Box 5025, Ås, N-1432, Norway; Fries, I., Swedish University of Agricultural Sciences, Bee Division, Uppsala, S-75007, Sweden; Hansen, H., Danish Institute of Plant and Soil Science, Department of Apiculture, Ledreborg allé 98, Roskilde, DK-4000, Denmark
Abstract: The development of Varroa jacobsoni infestations was monitored in two groups of honey bee (Apis mellifera) colonies kept in SE Finland under conditions where no infestation pressure from outside apiaries was possible and in a climate with a brood rearing period of less than five months. One group of 36 colonies was infested with 5–8 mites/colony and another group of 20 colonies with c. 100 mites/colony. Mite population levels in the colonies were followed by using debris samples. Yearly mite population growth factors were calculated based on values of maximum numbers of mites in the debris per day during the brood season. The averages varied from 8.2 to 24.6 despite the short brood rearing period and an average calculated 39.8% loss of the mite population in winter. The results of chemical treatment of five colonies/group, 38 months (group 1) and 26 months (group 2) after the infestation, supported the population growth results. Equal numbers of mites were killed by the second treatment in the following autumn, both in previously treated colonies and in untreated colonies, a result stressing the need to treat all colonies in an apiary simultaneously. Close correlations were found between mite downfall levels in autumn and the number of mites on wintering bees. It is concluded that under the conditions described, untreated colonies can survive for 4–5 years from an initial infestation by a few mites. © 1992 International Bee Research Association.
Author Keywords: Apis mellifera; Climate; Finland; Honey bees; Population dynamics; Varroa jacobsoni; Winter mortality

Title: Effectiveness of nectarivorous birds and honeybees as pollinators of Banksia spinulosa (Proteaceae)
Affiliations: Department of Zoology, The University of New England, Armidale, New South Wales, 2351, Australia
Authors with affiliations: VAUGHTON, G., Department of Zoology, The University of New England, Armidale, New South Wales, 2351, Australia
Abstract: Abstract The effectiveness of nectarivorous birds and honeybees (Apis mellifera) as pollinators of Banksia spinulosa (Proteaceae) was investigated. Birds visited inflorescences in the early, mid and late flowering seasons. In contrast, honeybees visited only on days in the late flowering period when maximum temperatures exceeded 15°C. Self pollen remained on pollen presenters of flowers for up to 5 days in the early and mid periods. In the late period, when honeybees visited inflorescences, self pollen was removed within 2 days. Pollen removal was similar for caged (birds excluded) and open inflorescences in the late period, indicating that most pollen was removed by honeybees. In the early and mid periods, honeyeaters pollinated 22% and 27% of flowers on open inflorescences, respectively. In the late period, when both birds and bees visited inflorescences, 64–73% of flowers on open inflorescences were pollinated. Foraging by honeybees resulted in pollen deposition as 38% of flowers on caged inflorescences were pollinated. Throughout the flowering season a similar number of pollen grains was deposited per stigma. There were 3.0–3.7 pollen grains per stigma on open inflorescences in the late period, although only 2.0 grains per stigma on caged inflorescences. In the early and mid periods, fewer caged than open inflorescences produced fruits, indicating the importance of honeyeaters to reproductive success at these times. In contrast, in the late period when honeybees visited inflorescences, fruit‐set was similar on caged and open inflorescences. Overall, these results indicate that honeybees were effective pollinators of B. spinulosa. Copyright © 1992, Wiley Blackwell. All rights reserved

Title: Evaluating honey bees as pollinators of virgin flowers of Echium plantagineum L. (Boraginaceae) by pollen tube fluorescence
Affiliations: Plant Cell Biology Group, Research School of Biological Sciences, Australian National University, Canberra, ACT, 2601, Australia; Department of Biology, University of Saskatchewan, Saskatoon, Saskatchewan, S7N 0W0, Canada
Authors with affiliations: Davis, A.R., Plant Cell Biology Group, Research School of Biological Sciences, Australian National University, Canberra, ACT, 2601, Australia; Davis, A.R., Department of Biology, University of Saskatchewan, Saskatoon, Saskatchewan, S7N 0W0, Canada
Abstract: A novel technique was developed which simply, directly and quantitatively evaluated flower visitors as pollinators of Echium plantagineum in Canberra, Australia, based on microscopic detection of the fluorescence of the callose content of stylar pollen tubes stained with aniline blue. E. plantagineum is self-compatible, so that germination and pollen tube growth of both cross- and self-pollen to the ovules at the style base occur. The technique utilized ‘virgin’ flowers, bagged as buds and which subsequently opened within the bags. After careful unbagging, the majority (93.5%) of initial visitors to these previously-unvisited flowers were honey bees (Apis mellifera). The technique demonstrated that although autogamy was possible, it was not predominant in E. plantagineum because permanently-bagged flowers had very low numbers of pollen tubes at their style bases (usually none), and emasculated and intact flowers exposed to single honey bee visits usually had the same numbers of tubes. Within treatments (intact, emasculated), honey bee visits for pollen, nectar or both, did not result in differences in pollen tube number, nor was there any connection between degree of pollination and time spent by a single honey bee per virgin flower. Although most honey bees attending virgin flowers carried pellets of E. plantagineum pollen on their hind legs, as a result of grooming actions to gather grains from their bodies, they were still as effective as pollinating agents as bees lacking corbicular pollen. Because one-third of single honey bee visits to emasculated virgin flowers (bearing receptive stigmas) introduced sufficient pollen to achieve fertilization of all four ovules, and almost two-thirds of such visits resulted in pollination, it appears that honey bees were effective cross-pollinators of E. plantagineum. Various advantages of the technique, including applications to agriculture, are discussed. © 1992 International Bee Research Association.
Author Keywords: Aniline blue; Apis mellifera; Callose; Echium plantagineum; Fluorescence microscopy; Foraging; Honey bees; Pollen tubes; Pollination; Pollinators; Staining

Title: Diflubenzuron hazards to fish, wildlife, and invertebrates: a synoptic review
Source title: Biological Report - US Fish & Wildlife Services
Affiliations: US Fish & Widlife Service, Patuxent Wildlife Research Center, Laurel, Maryland 20708, USA.
Authors with affiliations: Eisler, R., US Fish & Widlife Service, Patuxent Wildlife Research Center, Laurel, Maryland 20708, USA.
Abstract: Diflubenzuron is a potent broad-spectrum insect growth regulator that interferes with chitin synthesis at time of molting and is effective in controlling immature stages of insects. Diflubenzuron seldom persists for more than a few days in soil and water. Applied to foliage of terrestrial plants, it tends to remain adsorbed for several weeks with little or no absorption or translocation from plant surfaces; loss occurs mainly from wind abrasion, rain washing, or shedding of senescent leaves. Among terrestrial insects, there is great variability in sensitivity to diflubenzuron. Sensitive pestiferous species of insects die at topical applications of 0.003-0.034 μg per larave or after consuming diets containing 0.1 mg/kg. Some beneficial insects, such as honey bee Apis mellifera, are adversely affected at 1 mg/kg fresh weight (FW) of diet. Diflubenzuron application rates between 28-56 g/ha or 2.5-16 μg/L are highly effective against pestiferous aquatic dipterans, including representative chaoborids, chironomids, and culicids. These same dosages temporarily suppress nontarget populations of cladocerans, copepods, mayfly nymphs, corixids, and springtails; population recovery is usually complete within 80 days. In general, crustaceans were the most sensitive nontarget aquatic organisms tested. Adverse effects on crustacean growth, survival, reproduction, and behavior occur between 0.062-2 μg/L. Birds seem comparatively resistant to diflubenzuron: acute oral LD50 doses exceed 2000 mg/kg body weight (BW); dietary concentrations <4640 mg/kg FW are tolerated for at least 8 days; and forest birds seem unharmed by recommended diflubenzuron application procedures to control pestiferous insects. No data were found on diflubenzuron effects on mammalian wildlife. -from Author

Title: Use of pollen traps to investigate the foraging behaviour of honey bee colonies in kiwifruit orchards
Source title: New Zealand Journal of Crop and Horticultural Science
Affiliations: Ruakura Apicultural Research and Advisory Unit, MAF Technology, Private Bag, Hamilton, New Zealand
Authors with affiliations: Goodwin, R.M., Ruakura Apicultural Research and Advisory Unit, MAF Technology, Private Bag, Hamilton, New Zealand; Perry, J.H., Ruakura Apicultural Research and Advisory Unit, MAF Technology, Private Bag, Hamilton, New Zealand
Abstract: The efficiency of a pollen trap in trapping kiwifruit (Actinidia deliciosa) pollen pellets was investigated. The trap had an average daily efficiency of 16.5 and 16.7% on 2 consecutive days. Hourly efficiencies varied between 0 and 25% with the highest efficiency in the middle of the day which coincided with periods of maximum honey bee (Apis melifera) foraging activity. The amount of staminate pollen in foragers’ corbiculae was closely related to the proportion of staminate pollen on their body indicating that pellets can be used as a measure of pollination efficiency. © 1992 The Royal Society of New Zealand.
Author Keywords: Actinidia deliciosa; Apis mellifera; Foraging behavior; Honey bees; Kiwifruit; Pollen traps

Authors: PENG C.Y., YIN C.‐M., YIN L.R.S.
Title: Effect of rapid freezing and thawing on cellular integrity of honey bee sperm
Affiliations: Department of Entomology, University of Massachusetts, Amherst, United States
Authors with affiliations: PENG, C.Y., Department of Entomology, University of Massachusetts, Amherst, United States; YIN, C.‐M., Department of Entomology, University of Massachusetts, Amherst, United States; YIN, L.R.S., Department of Entomology, University of Massachusetts, Amherst, United States
Abstract: Abstract. Direct observations on the effect of rapid freezing and thawing on honey bee (Apis melliferaL.) sperm were made by light, scanning and transmission electron microscopy. Rapid freezing of honey bee ejaculated sperm, suspended in freezing diluent, in liquid nitrogen followed by rapid thawing can cause cellular injuries which lead to the death of the sperm. The frozen‐thawed sperm, supravitally stained, showed a significant decrease in cell viability compared with that of the control fresh sperm (P<0.001). Significant uptake of the stain in the dead sperm resulted from damage in the cell membrane. The scanning electron micrographs of frozen‐thawed sperm further demonstrated that the injury of cell membrane can lead to the splitting of mitochondrial derivatives from the flagellar axoneme. More cellular injuries including the release of acrosomal content and membrane damage at the acrosome, nucleus and the tail regions were further revealed by transmission electron microscopy. The impact of cellular injuries on the quality of honey bee sperm cryopreserved for artificial insemination of honey bee queens is discussed. Copyright © 1992, Wiley Blackwell. All rights reserved
Author Keywords: Apis mellifera; cellular injury; freezing and thawing effect; Honey bee sperm; ultrastructure changes

Authors: FREE J.B., FERGUSON A.W., SIMPKINS J.R.
Title: The behaviour of queen honeybees and their attendants
Affiliations: Entomology and Nematology Department, Afrc Institute of Arable Crops Research, Rothamsted Experimental Station, Harpenden, United Kingdom
Authors with affiliations: FREE, J.B., Entomology and Nematology Department, Afrc Institute of Arable Crops Research, Rothamsted Experimental Station, Harpenden, United Kingdom; FERGUSON, A.W., Entomology and Nematology Department, Afrc Institute of Arable Crops Research, Rothamsted Experimental Station, Harpenden, United Kingdom; SIMPKINS, J.R., Entomology and Nematology Department, Afrc Institute of Arable Crops Research, Rothamsted Experimental Station, Harpenden, United Kingdom
Abstract: Abstract. The behaviour of queen and worker honeybees (Apis melliferaL.) was observed using small colonies in observation hives. Workers paid more attention to queens which had been mated for 2 months or more than to those which were newly mated; virgin queens received least attention. Queens received most attention when they were stationary and least when they were walking over the comb; virgin queens were most active. Queen cells had as many attendants as virgin queens and queen larvae were inspected almost continuously. The queen pheromone component 9–oxo‐trans‐2–decenoic acid stimulated ‘court’ behaviour when presented on small polyethylene blocks, but workers responded aggressively to complete extracts of queens' heads. Both the heads and abdomens of mated queens received much attention from court workers but the abdomens were palpated by more workers for longer and were licked much more. The queens' thoraces were least attended. Abdominal tergites posterior to tergite glands were licked for longer than those anterior to the glands. Only worker bees very near to the queen reacted to her and joined her ‘court’. No evidence was found of a diel periodicity in the behaviour of a queen or her ‘court’. During the winter the queen's court was smaller than in summer and she walked less and laid fewer eggs. When colonies were fed with sucrose syrup in winter, their queens laid more eggs and workers reared more brood but there was no change in the attention received by the queens. The implications of these findings for the secretion and distribution of queen pheromones are discussed. Copyright © 1992, Wiley Blackwell. All rights reserved
Author Keywords: Apis mellifera; attendants; behaviour; court; honeybee; Pheromone distribution; queen; queen cell; retinue; worker

Authors: Beinbrech G., Ashton F.T., Pepe F.A.
Title: The invertebrate myosin filament: subfilament arrangement of the solid filaments of insect flight muscles
Affiliations: Zoologisches Institut, Universität Münster, Germany
Authors with affiliations: Beinbrech, G., Zoologisches Institut, Universität Münster, Germany; Ashton, F.T., Zoologisches Institut, Universität Münster, Germany; Pepe, F.A., Zoologisches Institut, Universität Münster, Germany
Abstract: Transverse sections (approximately 140 nm thick) of solid myosin filaments of the flight muscles of the fleshfly, Phormia terrae-novae, the honey bee, Apis mellifica, and the waterbug, Lethocerus uhleri, were photographed in a JEM model 200A electron microscope at 200 kV. The images were digitized and computer processed by rotational filtering. In each of these filaments it was found that the symmetry of the core and the wall was not the same. The power spectra of the images showed sixfold symmetry for the wall and threefold symmetry for the core of the filaments. The images of the filaments in each muscle were superimposed according to the sixfold center of the wall. These averaged images for all three muscles showed six pairs of subunits in the wall similar to those found in the wall of tubular filaments. From serial sections of the fleshfly filaments, we conclude that the subunits in the wall of the filaments represent subfilaments essentially parallel to the long axis of the filament. In each muscle there are additional subunits in the core, closely related to the subunits in the wall. Evaluation of serial sections through fleshfly filaments suggests that the relationship of the three subunits observed in the core to those in the wall varies along the length of the filaments. In waterbug filaments there are three dense and three less dense subunits for a total of six all closely related to the wall. Bee filaments have three subunits related to the wall and three subunits located eccentrically in the core of the filaments. The presence of core subunits can be related to the paramyosin content of the filaments. © 1992, The Biophysical Society. All rights reserved.

Authors: STAUDACHER E., KUBELKA V., MÄRZ L.
Title: Distinct N‐glycan fucosylation potentials of three lepidopteran cell lines
Affiliations: Institut Für Chemie, Universität Für Bodenkultur, Vienna, Austria
Authors with affiliations: STAUDACHER, E., Institut Für Chemie, Universität Für Bodenkultur, Vienna, Austria; KUBELKA, V., Institut Für Chemie, Universität Für Bodenkultur, Vienna, Austria; MÄRZ, L., Institut Für Chemie, Universität Für Bodenkultur, Vienna, Austria
Abstract: The fucosyltransferase activities of three insect cell lines, MB‐0503 (from Mamestra brassicae), BM‐N (from Bombyx mori) and Sf‐9 (from Spodoptera frugiperda), were investigated and compared with that of honeybee venom glands. Cell extracts and venom gland extracts were incubated with GDP‐[14C]fucose and glycopeptides isolated from human IgG and from bovine fibrin. The labeled oligosaccharide products were released by peptide‐N4‐(N‐acetyl‐β‐glucosaminyl)asparagine amidase A, fluorescence marked with 2‐aminopyridine and analyzed both by reversed‐phase and size‐fractionation HPLC. They were identified by their elution positions before and after exoglycosidase treatment in comparison with standard oligosaccharides. These experiments revealed distinct fucosylation potentials in the three cell lines tested. While MB‐0503 cells, like honeybee venom glands, are able to transfer fucose into α1–3 and α1–6 linkage to the innermost N‐acetylglucosamine, only α1–6‐fucosyl linkages were detected with BM‐N and Sf‐9 cells. Authors: Danka R.G., Rinderer T.E., Hellmich R.L.
Title: Nest usurpation, supersedure and colony failure contribute to Africanization of commercially managed European honey bees in Venezuela
Affiliations: USDA-ARS Honey-Bee Breeding, Genetics and Physiology Laboratory, Baton Rouge, LA, 70820, United States; Department of Zoology and Genetics, Iowa, State University, Ames, IA, 50011, United States
Authors with affiliations: Danka, R.G., USDA-ARS Honey-Bee Breeding, Genetics and Physiology Laboratory, Baton Rouge, LA, 70820, United States, Department of Zoology and Genetics, Iowa, State University, Ames, IA, 50011, United States; Rinderer, T.E., USDA-ARS Honey-Bee Breeding, Genetics and Physiology Laboratory, Baton Rouge, LA, 70820, United States; Hellmich, R.L., USDA-ARS Honey-Bee Breeding, Genetics and Physiology Laboratory, Baton Rouge, LA, 70820, United States
Abstract: The fates of 58 colonies in 4 apiaries managed commercially for honey production in northwest Venezuela were determined during 15 months. All colonies had been previously requeened with marked European queens. Heritage of new queens (European daughter replacements versus Africanized usurpers) was traced by mitochondrial DNA and morphological characteristics of worker progeny. Three usurpations (5% of colony fates, at a rate of 4.7% of colonies per year) occurred. These colonies showed congruent African-derived mitochondrial DNA and Africanized morphology. Supersedures accounted for much of the introgression of African genes into the test apiaries. Twenty-eight colonies (48%) superseded their queens once, three (5%) had two supersedures and one (2%) had three supersedures. All original and supersedure queens had European mtDNA. The worker progeny of original queens had European morphology, but the progeny of supersedure queens showed mixed morphology, with mostly intermediate and European morphology in first generation workers and intermediate and Africanized morphology in later generations. Sixteen (28%) of the European queens died without being successfully replaced by their colonies, and only seven (12%) survived the 15-month test. Hives left unoccupied after colony failure would have been available for colonization by Africanized swarms. Usurpations, supersedures and colony failures thus accounted for an annual Africanization rate (i.e. a decrease in the percentage of colonies with both European mitochondrial DNA and European morphology) of 53%. © 1992 International Bee Research Association.
Author Keywords: Africanized honey bees; Apis mellifera; Colony failure; European honey bees; Genetic change; Honey bee colonies; Mitochondrial DNA; Morphology; Neotropical region; Supersedure; Usurpation; Venezuela

Title: Do simple rules apply in honey-bee nestmate discrimination?
Affiliations: Department of Environmental, Population and Organismic Biology, Institute for Behavioral Genetics, University of Colorado, Boulder, CO 90309-0334, United States
Authors with affiliations: Breed, M.D., Department of Environmental, Population and Organismic Biology, Institute for Behavioral Genetics, University of Colorado, Boulder, CO 90309-0334, United States; Julian, G.E., Department of Environmental, Population and Organismic Biology, Institute for Behavioral Genetics, University of Colorado, Boulder, CO 90309-0334, United States
Abstract: How do honey-bees integrate cues in nestmate recognition? Honey-bees are able to discriminate nestmates from non-nestmates using olfactory cues or contact chemoreception. Nestmates may differ from non-nestmates in either cues produced by the individuals, which have a genetic basis, or in cues that are acquired from the hive environment. Recognitive cues are learned by worker bees early in adult life; the learned cue profile serves as a template for comparison and determination of the colonial membership of bees that are encountered. We report here the response of bees to two cues: hexadecane and methyl docosonoate. © 1992 Nature Publishing Group.

Title: Cotoneaster for bumble bees and honey bees
Affiliations: Zoology Department, University of Cambridge, Downing Street, Cambridge, CB2 3EJ, United Kingdom
Authors with affiliations: Corbet, S.A., Zoology Department, University of Cambridge, Downing Street, Cambridge, CB2 3EJ, United Kingdom; Westgarth-Smith, A., Zoology Department, University of Cambridge, Downing Street, Cambridge, CB2 3EJ, United Kingdom
Abstract: Regular monitoring between May and August 1988 of a collection of 22 taxa of Cotoneaster in the UK showed that the bumble bees Bombus pratorum and B. pascuorum preferentially visited species in the section Cotoneaster. The short-tongued bumble bees B. terrestris/lucorum and honey bees visited species in both sections of the genus, concentrating on the section Cotoneaster in the dearth period of early summer and on Chaenopetalum after mid-June. The section Cotoneaster is recommended as particularly valuable for bee forage. This phenological survey should make it possible to select groups of species for amenity plantings to give a seasonal spread of flowering, enhancing the availability of nectar plants. © 1992 International Bee Research Association.

Authors: Zhang S.W., Srinivasan M.V., Horridge G.A.
Title: Pattern recognition in honeybees: local and global analysis
Source title: Proceedings of the Royal Society B: Biological Sciences
Affiliations: Centre for Visual Sciences, Research School Biological Sciences, Australian National University, PO Box 475, Canberra, ACT 2601, Australia
Authors with affiliations: Zhang, S.W., Centre for Visual Sciences, Research School Biological Sciences, Australian National University, PO Box 475, Canberra, ACT 2601, Australia; Srinivasan, M.V., Centre for Visual Sciences, Research School Biological Sciences, Australian National University, PO Box 475, Canberra, ACT 2601, Australia; Horridge, G.A., Centre for Visual Sciences, Research School Biological Sciences, Australian National University, PO Box 475, Canberra, ACT 2601, Australia
Abstract: This study explores the ability of honeybees to use local and global cues in learning patterns, by training them on patterns that contain both types of cue. The experiments are designed to investigate existing theories of what insects 'see' in visual patterns, and to unravel the mechanisms underlying feature extraction. The results show that bees are capable of discriminating visual patterns on the basis of local as well as global cues, and, having learned both without knowing in advance which is significant, they can perform the discrimination on the basis of one type of cue alone when the other type is absent. Under the conditions of our experiments, global cues dominate over local cues when the two types of cue are set in opposition. The results also suggest that local and global cues are analysed by separate processes.

Abstract: Traditionally the division of labour in social insects has been divided into two types: physical and temporal polyethism. New theoretical models indicate that temporal polyethism may be an emergent property rather than an organizational principle. Current research is revealing the relationship between temporal polyethism and the role of nonspecialized individuals within species of physically polymorphic social insects. © 1992.

Authors: Debevec M., Bounias M., Popeskovic D.
Title: Changes in the properties of honeybee haemolymph α-glucosidases following dithiothreitol dissociation of native complexes
Affiliations: Faculty of Veterinary Medicine, Department of Biology, P.O. Box 370, 11000 Beograd
Authors with affiliations: Debevec, M., Faculty of Veterinary Medicine, Department of Biology, P.O. Box 370, 11000 Beograd; Bounias, M., Faculty of Veterinary Medicine, Department of Biology, P.O. Box 370, 11000 Beograd; Popeskovic, D., Faculty of Veterinary Medicine, Department of Biology, P.O. Box 370, 11000 Beograd
Abstract: 1. 1. The higher relative molecular mass (Mr) forms of larval honeybee haemolymph α-glucosidases are dissociated by dithiothreitol (DTT) into lower Mr electrophoretic forms, without any important loss of activity. 2. 2. The maximum velocity remains unchanged and the apparent dissociation constant is slightly increased, with Ki ≅ 247 mM and I50 ≅ 730 mM. 3. 3. By contrast, the major changes affect the Hill coefficient which decreases from 1.0 in controls to 0.7 in presence of 600 mM DTT. 4. 4. In the absence of both DTT and substrate, the major native enzyme form, isolated by gel filtration, spontaneously rearranges to give three additional minor forms, one of lower Mr and two of higher Mr. 5. 5. These data are consistent with the hypothesis of substrate-directed aggregation of enzyme protomers into functional complexes. © 1992.
