Title: Pattern of nectar secretion in wild cherry, Prunus puddum Roxb, and the associated foraging behaviour of Apis cerana indica F and Apis mellifera L
Affiliations: Department of Entomology and Apiculture, University of Horticulture and Forestry, Nauni 173 230, Solan, India
Authors with affiliations: Gupta, J.K., Department of Entomology and Apiculture, University of Horticulture and Forestry, Nauni 173 230, Solan, India; Reddy, M.C.M., Department of Entomology and Apiculture, University of Horticulture and Forestry, Nauni 173 230, Solan, India; Kumar, J., Department of Entomology and Apiculture, University of Horticulture and Forestry, Nauni 173 230, Solan, India
Abstract: Nectar sugar production per flower (during 8 h of flower opening) was 4.15 mg, when the nectar was removed at short intervals, compared to 1.89 mg/flower in flowers of the same age where nectar was allowed to accumulate. Similarly, nectar removal every 24 h after flower opening resulted in more nectar sugar production. Flowers where nectar was allowed to accumulate resorbed nectar. Honeybees foraged both for nectar and pollen on the flowers. The activity of pollen gatherers peaked during early morning hours (8-9 h) and that of nectar gatherers at 11 h. A. mellifera spent more time per flower than A. indica. -from Authors

Authors: Owen M.D., Pfaff L.A., Reisman R.E., Wypych J.
Title: Phospholipase A2 in venom extracts from honey bees (Apis mellifera L.) of different ages
Affiliations: Department of Zoology, University of Western Ontario, London, Ontario, N6A 5B7, Canada; Allergy Research Laboratory, Buffalo General Hospital, 100 High Street, Buffalo, New York, 14203, United States
Authors with affiliations: Owen, M.D., Department of Zoology, University of Western Ontario, London, Ontario, N6A 5B7, Canada; Pfaff, L.A., Department of Zoology, University of Western Ontario, London, Ontario, N6A 5B7, Canada; Reisman, R.E., Allergy Research Laboratory, Buffalo General Hospital, 100 High Street, Buffalo, New York, 14203, United States; Wypych, J., Allergy Research Laboratory, Buffalo General Hospital, 100 High Street, Buffalo, New York, 14203, United States
Abstract: We measured phospholipase A2 activity in the venom of worker honey bees (Apis mellifera L.) of, known ages using chemical (titrimetric) and radioallergosorbent methods The two techniques give similar results. Low levels of phospholipase A2 are present in the venom system at the time of eclosion. Phospholipase A2 activity in the venom increases steadily through the 10 days after eclosion. Maximal phospholipase A2 levels (about 40 μg phospholipase A2/venom sac) are maintained through the rest of the life of a worker bee in summer. © 1990, Pergamon Press plc. All rights reserved.

Authors: CASTEELS P., AMPE C., RIVIERE L., van DAMME J., ELICONE C., FLEMING M., JACOBS F., TEMPST P.
Title: Isolation and characterization of abaecin, a major antibacterial response peptide in the honeybee (Apis mellifera)
Affiliations: Plant Genetic Systems NV, Gent, Belgium; Department of Zoophysiology, Gent State University, Belgium; Howard Hughes Medical Institute and Department of Genetics, Harvard Medical School, Boston, United States
Authors with affiliations: CASTEELS, P., Plant Genetic Systems NV, Gent, Belgium; AMPE, C., Plant Genetic Systems NV, Gent, Belgium; RIVIERE, L., Howard Hughes Medical Institute and Department of Genetics, Harvard Medical School, Boston, United States; van DAMME, J., Plant Genetic Systems NV, Gent, Belgium; ELICONE, C., Howard Hughes Medical Institute and Department of Genetics, Harvard Medical School, Boston, United States; FLEMING, M., Howard Hughes Medical Institute and Department of Genetics, Harvard Medical School, Boston, United States; JACOBS, F., Department of Zoophysiology, Gent State University, Belgium; TEMPST, P., Howard Hughes Medical Institute and Department of Genetics, Harvard Medical School, Boston, United States
Abstract: Honeybees (Apis mellifera) are frequently exposed to and likely to be infected by plant‐associated bacteria. We mimicked this process by injecting bees with live bacteria and isolated five induced antibacterial substances by comparative liquid chromatographic mapping of the hemolymph. Three of these antibiotics belong to a unique family of small (18 amino acids) peptides: the apidaecins [Casteels et al. (1989) EMBO J. 8, 2387–2391]. We have now characterized a fourth bee immune response peptide. The complete sequence was established by Edman degradation of the peptide and fragments thereof. It is 34 amino acids long and contains 10 proline residues. The amino‐terminal half is related to the apidaecins; similar proline motifs are also present in the aminoterminal quarter of the much longer fly diptericins. The newly identified peptide's broad spectrum, lower specific activities against Gram‐negative plant pathogens and its inability to inhibit bacterial growth at medium ionic strength are different from the apidaecins. Moreover, the highest observed specific activity was against an apidaecin‐resistant Xanthomonas strain. In contrast to the immediate action of apidaecins, bactericidal activity is delayed. We propose the name ‘abaecin’ for this new antibacterial response peptide. Copyright © 1990, Wiley Blackwell. All rights reserved

Title: Common mechanisms in proboscis extension conditioning and visual learning revealed by genetic selection in honeybees (Apis mellifera capensis)
Source title: Journal of Comparative Physiology A: Sensory, Neural and Behavioral Physiology
Affiliations: Institut für Bienenkunde, Fachbereich Biologie, Universität Frankfurt, Oberursel, D-6370, Germany; Institut für Neurobiologie, FU Berlin, Berlin, Germany; Department of Biology, Brandeis University, Bassine 235, Waltham, Massachusetts, 02254-9110, United States
Authors with affiliations: Brandes, Ch., Institut für Bienenkunde, Fachbereich Biologie, Universität Frankfurt, Oberursel, D-6370, Germany, Department of Biology, Brandeis University, Bassine 235, Waltham, Massachusetts, 02254-9110, United States; Menzel, R., Institut für Neurobiologie, FU Berlin, Berlin, Germany
Abstract: Four strains of the honeybee (Apis mellifera capensis), which were selected for high (N=2) or low (N=2) performance levels in classic conditioning of olfactory and mechanosensory stimuli, were examined in two instrumental visual learning tasks. Bees were trained to coloured cardboards either at the hive entrance or at the feeding station. Positive correlations were detected between olfactory/mechanosensory conditioning and visual learning. Good and poor learners from strains selected for olfactory conditioning differed significantly in their visual learning values. These strain differences reflect genetic differences in a common learning system rather than task specific differences in sensory, motor or motivational components. Parameters that were influenced by activity of the colony (duration of stay at the feeding place, time between visits) also differed among selected strains. These effects were not due to selection. Instead, they reflect a specific genetic background produced in each strain independently of selection. The results indicate that associative learning has a genetic basis which is independent of the sensory stimuli associated with reward, the learning procedure (classical conditioning or instrumental learning) or the motor patterns used to execute the learned behavior (proboscis extension, control for flight behavior, open field orientation). © 1990, Springer-Verlag. All rights reserved.
Author Keywords: Classical conditioning; Genetics; Honeybees; Learning; Selection

Title: Corpora allata activity, a prime regulating element for caste-specific juvenile hormone titre in honey bee larvae (Apis mellifera carnica)
Affiliations: LS Entwicklungsphysiologie, Zoologisches Institute, Auf der Morgenstelle 28, D-7400 Tübingen, Germany
Authors with affiliations: Rachinsky, A., LS Entwicklungsphysiologie, Zoologisches Institute, Auf der Morgenstelle 28, D-7400 Tübingen, Germany; Hartfelder, K., LS Entwicklungsphysiologie, Zoologisches Institute, Auf der Morgenstelle 28, D-7400 Tübingen, Germany
Abstract: Corpora allata activity of queen and worker larvae of the honey bee in late larval development was studied in vitro by a radiochemical assay. Prospective queens showed a high peak of corpora allata activity in the fourth and early fifth larval stadium. This peak coincides with a queen-specific maximum in juvenile hormone titre, demonstrating that modulation of juvenile hormone release is of prime importance in the regulation of the caste-specific juvenile hormone titre. In both castes, hormone release is strictly correlated with juvenile hormone synthesis. The conversion of the precursor methyl farnesoate to juvenile hormone may be regulated caste-specifically, since only in queens but not in workers a linear correlation between intraglandular contents of juvenile hormone and methyl farnesoate could be found. © 1990.
Author Keywords: Apis mellifera; Caste differentiation; corpora allata activity; in vitro juvenile hormone synthesis

Title: Trophallaxis and genetic variance of kin recognition in honey bees, Apis mellifera L.
Affiliations: Bayerische Landesanstalt für Bienenzucht, Burgbergstraße 70, 8520 Erlangen, Germany; Zoologisches Institut der Universität Basel, Rheinsprung 9, 4051 Basel, Switzerland
Authors with affiliations: Moritz, R.F.A., Bayerische Landesanstalt für Bienenzucht, Burgbergstraße 70, 8520 Erlangen, Germany; Hillesheim, E., Zoologisches Institut der Universität Basel, Rheinsprung 9, 4051 Basel, Switzerland
Abstract: Individual honey bee workers were tested in a trophallactic bioassay for their kin discrimination abilities. One bee (the donor) was fed with 20 μl dyed sugar syrup. The donor was placed into a group of six familiar and six unfamiliar workers of various degrees of relationship to the familar bees. Unrestricted trophallaxis was allowed for 2h. The amount of food transferred was photometrically determined. The majority of workers were able to discriminate between unfamiliar related and unrelated workers and preferentially fed related workers. Donor workers of different patrilines of the same colony showed a significant variability for kin discrimination. A sibling analysis on workers of sister queens revealed a substantial additive genetic variance for this character (39% of total variance) which is higher than heritability estimates of characters related to fitness known for other organisms. © 1990 The Association for the Study of Animal Behaviour.

Authors: Ramalho M., Kleinert-Giovannini A., Imperatriz-Fonseca V.
Title: Important bee plants for stingless bees (Melipona and Trigonini) and Africanized honeybees (Apis mellifera) in neotropical habitats: a review
Affiliations: Dept de Ecologia Geral do Instituto de Biociencias, Univ de Sao Paulo, 05508, Sao Paulo, Brazil
Authors with affiliations: Ramalho, M., Dept de Ecologia Geral do Instituto de Biociencias, Univ de Sao Paulo, 05508, Sao Paulo, Brazil; Kleinert-Giovannini, A., Dept de Ecologia Geral do Instituto de Biociencias, Univ de Sao Paulo, 05508, Sao Paulo, Brazil; Imperatriz-Fonseca, V., Dept de Ecologia Geral do Instituto de Biociencias, Univ de Sao Paulo, 05508, Sao Paulo, Brazil
Abstract: Some 288 species were considered important bee plants: 80 of these were important for the Africanized honeybee. -from Authors

Title: Preference for drone brood cells by Varroa jacobsoni Oud in colonies of Apis mellifera carnica
Affiliations: Inst fur Bienenkunde (Polytechnische Gesellschaft), Fachbereich Biologie der JW Goethe-Univ., Frankfurt am Main, D-6370 Oberursel, Germany
Authors with affiliations: Fuchs, S., Inst fur Bienenkunde (Polytechnische Gesellschaft), Fachbereich Biologie der JW Goethe-Univ., Frankfurt am Main, D-6370 Oberursel, Germany
Abstract: Infestation of mites per cell was on average 8.3 times higher in the drone brood than in the worker brood (see also 91L/09278 and 09279). -from Author

Title: The role of the mating sign in honey bees, Apis mellifera L.: does it hinder or promote multiple mating?
Affiliations: Institut für Bienenkunde (Polytechnische Gesellschaft), J.W. Goethe-Universität, Frankfurt, K.-v.-Frisch-Weg 2, 6370 Oberursel, Germany
Authors with affiliations: Koeniger, G., Institut für Bienenkunde (Polytechnische Gesellschaft), J.W. Goethe-Universität, Frankfurt, K.-v.-Frisch-Weg 2, 6370 Oberursel, Germany
Abstract: In a two-choice test, drones preferred queen models marked by a distinctly coloured 'mating sign' (secretions of the drone's copulatory organs) to unmarked models. This was true also for models marked by aluminium foil. Dark-coloured drones preferred to copulate with light-coloured models and vice versa. Models carrying copulating drones were more attractive than single models. Thus a copulating drone as well as the mating sign and other coloured markers increased the attractiveness of a queen. The mating sign may indicate a form of cooperation between drones by marking a queen after sperm transfer to facilitate the identification of a queen by the following drones. © 1990 The Association for the Study of Animal Behaviour.

Authors: Walker M.M., Younglim Lee, Bitterman M.E.
Title: Transfer along a continuum in the discriminative learning of honeybees (Apis mellifera)
Authors with affiliations: Walker, M.M.; Younglim Lee; Bitterman, M.E.
Abstract: In each of 2 experiments on discriminative learning in free-flying honeybees performance in a difficult problem was found to be facilitated by prior training in an easier problem. -from Authors

Title: Learning in honeybees (Apis mellifera) as a function of amount of reward: acquisition measures
Authors with affiliations: Lee, Y.; Bitterman, M.E.
Abstract: Foraging honeybees were trained individually to discriminate between targets that contained 5-μl or 20-μl drops of sucrose solution. Measures of resistance to extinction supported the assumption that the slope of the acquisition function increases with amount of reward while its asymptote remains the same. Honeybees tended to respond less rapidly after large than after small reward, which does not require an associative interpretation. -from Authors

Title: Effects of additional caged and free-running queens on honey bee (Apis mellifera) colony performance
Affiliations: USDA, Agricultural Research Service, Honey-Bee Breeding, Genetics & Physiology Laboratory, 1157 Ben Hur Road, Baton Rouge, LA 70820, USA.
Authors with affiliations: Oldroyd, B.P., USDA, Agricultural Research Service, Honey-Bee Breeding, Genetics & Physiology Laboratory, 1157 Ben Hur Road, Baton Rouge, LA 70820, USA.; Hunt, P.J., USDA, Agricultural Research Service, Honey-Bee Breeding, Genetics & Physiology Laboratory, 1157 Ben Hur Road, Baton Rouge, LA 70820, USA.
Abstract: Colonies with 1 queen had the highest colony weight gain. Results do not support the use of caged queens or 2-queen colonies for increasing honey production. -from Authors

Authors: Veleminsky M., Laznicka P., Stary P.
Title: Honeybees (Apis mellifera) as environmental monitors of heavy metals in Czechoslovakia
Affiliations: Inst of Entomology, Czechoslovak Acad of Sciences, Branisovska 31, 370 05 Ceske Budejogive, Czechoslovakia
Authors with affiliations: Veleminsky, M., Inst of Entomology, Czechoslovak Acad of Sciences, Branisovska 31, 370 05 Ceske Budejogive, Czechoslovakia; Laznicka, P., Inst of Entomology, Czechoslovak Acad of Sciences, Branisovska 31, 370 05 Ceske Budejogive, Czechoslovakia; Stary, P., Inst of Entomology, Czechoslovak Acad of Sciences, Branisovska 31, 370 05 Ceske Budejogive, Czechoslovakia
Abstract: Honeybees and their products have been used for biomonitoring of Pb, Cd, Cu and Zn in C and S Bohemia. -from Authors

Authors: Free J.B., Ferguson A.W., Simpkins J.R.
Title: Queen discrimination by honeybee (Apis mellifera L) workers
Affiliations: univ. of Wales, School of Pure & Applied Biology, Bee Research Unit, Cardiff, CF1 3TL, UK.
Authors with affiliations: Free, J.B., univ. of Wales, School of Pure & Applied Biology, Bee Research Unit, Cardiff, CF1 3TL, UK.; Ferguson, A.W., univ. of Wales, School of Pure & Applied Biology, Bee Research Unit, Cardiff, CF1 3TL, UK.; Simpkins, J.R., univ. of Wales, School of Pure & Applied Biology, Bee Research Unit, Cardiff, CF1 3TL, UK.
Abstract: Two queens were caged separately with groups of young sibling workers which were the daughters of another queen. The cages were exposed to the same environmental odours for 10 days. When placed in the test apparatus and given a choice of both queens, workers segregated towards the queen with which they had been caged. This provides further evidence that the distinctive odour of an individual queen is probably partly inherited and is learned by workers. -from Authors

Title: Uptake of l-leucine into isolated enterocytes of the honeybee (Apis mellifera L.) depending on season
Affiliations: Institut für Zoologie an der Karl-Franzens-Universität in Graz, Universitätsplatz 2, A-8010 Graz, Austria
Authors with affiliations: Haszonits, O., Institut für Zoologie an der Karl-Franzens-Universität in Graz, Universitätsplatz 2, A-8010 Graz, Austria; Crailsheim, K., Institut für Zoologie an der Karl-Franzens-Universität in Graz, Universitätsplatz 2, A-8010 Graz, Austria
Abstract: Enterocytes of hive bees, foragers and winter bees were isolated enzymatically. The transport of leucine into those cells depends nonlinearly on concentration and can be inhibited by isoleucine or by a reduction in temperature but neither dinitrophenol nor ouabain nor the absence of oxygen influence the uptake. Although diffusion accounts for a large part of the transport, a carrier-mediated transport system that does not need energy is assumed. © 1990.
Author Keywords: adaptation; amino acid; Apis; division of labour; season; transport

Authors: Rosenkranz P., Rachinsky A., Strambi A., Strambi C., Röpstorf P.
Title: Juvenile hormone titer in capped worker brood of Apis mellifera and reproduction in the bee mite Varroa jacobsoni
Affiliations: Department of Developmental Biology, Zoological Institute, University of Tübingen, Auf der Morgenstelle 28, D-7400 Tübingen, Germany; CNRS, Laboratoire de Neurobiologie, BP 71, F-13402 Marseille Cedex 9, France; Department of Bee Research, Zoological Institute, University of Berlin, Königin Luise Straße 3-7, D-1000 Berlin 33, Germany
Authors with affiliations: Rosenkranz, P., Department of Developmental Biology, Zoological Institute, University of Tübingen, Auf der Morgenstelle 28, D-7400 Tübingen, Germany; Rachinsky, A., Department of Developmental Biology, Zoological Institute, University of Tübingen, Auf der Morgenstelle 28, D-7400 Tübingen, Germany; Strambi, A., CNRS, Laboratoire de Neurobiologie, BP 71, F-13402 Marseille Cedex 9, France; Strambi, C., CNRS, Laboratoire de Neurobiologie, BP 71, F-13402 Marseille Cedex 9, France; Röpstorf, P., Department of Bee Research, Zoological Institute, University of Berlin, Königin Luise Straße 3-7, D-1000 Berlin 33, Germany
Abstract: Juvenile hormone (JH) titers were recorded from fifth instar worker larvae of Apis mellifera carnica, Apis mellifera lamarckii, and Africanized honeybees kept under temperature and tropical climatic conditions. No differences in hormone titer according to honeybee race or climatic conditions were determined. However, the rate of reproduction of the ectoparasitic mite, Varroa jacobsoni, on larvae of the different honeybee races was highly variable. The possible role of honeybee JH in control of the parasite's reproduction is discussed. © 1990.

Title: Investigation of the parasitic status of melittiphis alvearius (Berlese) on honeybees, apis mellifera l., by immunoassay
Affiliations: Microbiology Department, Otago University, Dunedin, New Zealand; Invermay Agricultural Centre, Private Bag, Mosgiel, New Zealand
Authors with affiliations: Gibbins, B.L., Microbiology Department, Otago University, Dunedin, New Zealand; Van Toor, R.F., Invermay Agricultural Centre, Private Bag, Mosgiel, New Zealand
Abstract: The potential parasitism of Apis mellifera L. (Honeybee) by the colony co-habitant Melittiphis alvearius (Berlese) was investigated by analysing homogenates of the mite for bee-derived antigens with a sensitive indirect immuno-dot procedure. This method revealed that the mite contained pollen and bee-derived antigens, but the latter were bee salivary antigens. These findings show that the mite is not parasitic on bees but rather is a scavenger of pollen within bee colonies. © 1990 International Bee Research Association.

Title: A simple in vivo estimation of hypopharyngeal gland activity in honeybees (Apis mellifera l., apidae, hymenoptera)
Affiliations: Department of Environmental Biology, University of Guelph, Guelph, ON, N1G 2W1, Canada
Authors with affiliations: Huang, Z.-Y., Department of Environmental Biology, University of Guelph, Guelph, ON, N1G 2W1, Canada
Abstract: The hypopharyngeal glands (HGs) are important protein-producing food glands in worker honeybees (Apis mellifera L.). A simple in vivo method is described for estimating HG activity. Radioactive 14CL-leucine (0 l εCi in 1 εl) is injected directly into the haemocoele of honeybees, and is subsequently incorporated into the HGs during protein synthesis. After 2 h incubation, the amount of radioactive leucine incorporated by the gland is measured and serves as an indicator of synthetic activity in the glands. The technique has been used successfully to reveal gland activity differences in bees from hives with and without brood. This technique is simple, fast, and reliable. Its advantages and disadvantages compared with the in vitro assay method of Brouwers (1982) are also discussed. © 1990 International Bee Research Association.

Title: Pests and pathogens of the honeybee (Apis mellifera l.) in Fiji
Affiliations: Department of Scientific and Industrial Research, Entomology Division, Mt. Albert Research Centre, Private Bag, Auckland, New Zealand
Authors with affiliations: Anderson, D.L., Department of Scientific and Industrial Research, Entomology Division, Mt. Albert Research Centre, Private Bag, Auckland, New Zealand
Abstract: The occurrence and distribution of pests and pathogens of the honeybee, Apis mellifera L., in Fiji, surveyed during October–November 1986, are reported. American foulbrood disease was detected in 33 (47%) hived colonies at one locality but in only 1 (0·8%) of all other colonies examined in other localities. Infestations of wax moth (Galleria mellonella or Achroia grisella) were observed in 139 (70%) hived colonies. The cane toad Bufo marinus was also observed as a pest of bee colonies. Chronic bee paralysis virus (CBPV) and sacbrood virus (SBV) were present in 30 (31%) and 76 (79%) hived colonies, respectively. Bee virus X, bee virus Y, black queen cell virus (BQCV), Kashmir bee virus (KBV), and slow bee paralysis virus were also detected in these colonies but they were less common than CBPV and SBV. Inapparent infections of SBV, BQCV and KBV were detected in seemingly healthy bees from hived colonies. SBV and CBPV were also detected in feral colonies. The Fijian KBV isolates were serologically distinguishable from New Zealand and Australian KBV isolates. Nosema apis, was found in 45 (47%) hived colonies. It was also detected in feral colonies. Malpighamoeba mellificae was detected in worker bees from 1 hived colony. European foulbrood and chalkbrood disease, the tracheal bee mite, Acarapis woodi, and other mites such as Varroa jacobsoni and Tropilaelaps clareae, were not detected in any colonies. © 1990 International Bee Research Association.

Title: In Vitro Observations on Ontogenesis of the Mite, Euvarroa Sinhai Delfinado & Baker (Acari: Varroidae), In Drone Brood Cells of the Honeybee, Apis Mellifera L.
Affiliations: Department of Entomology, College of Agriculture, Shahid Chamran University, Ahwaz, Iran
Authors with affiliations: Mossadegh, M.S., Department of Entomology, College of Agriculture, Shahid Chamran University, Ahwaz, Iran
Abstract: Ontogenesis of Euvarroa sinhai D. & B., a parasite of Apis florea F., on A. mellifera drone brood was observed at 24-h intervals. Ontogenesis lasted 5 days in the male and 6–7 in the female Euvarroa. Fertile females used once in the experiment produced 1–9 offspring with a mean of 5.14 ± 2.26/ cell. The actual and potential reproduction rates of the Euvarroa mite on A. mellifera drone brood were 4.89 and 5.14, respectively. © 1990 International Bee Research Association.

Authors: Beisser K., Munz E., Reimann M., Renner‐Müller I.C.E.
Title: Experimentelle Untersuchungen zur in vitro‐Kultivierung von Zellen der Kärntner Honigbiene (Apis mellifera carnica Pollmann, 1879)
Source title: Journal of Veterinary Medicine, Series B
Affiliations: Institut Für Vergleichende Tropenmedizin Und Parasitologie, Universität München, Germany
Authors with affiliations: Beisser, K., Institut Für Vergleichende Tropenmedizin Und Parasitologie, Universität München, Germany; Munz, E., Institut Für Vergleichende Tropenmedizin Und Parasitologie, Universität München, Germany; Reimann, M., Institut Für Vergleichende Tropenmedizin Und Parasitologie, Universität München, Germany; Renner‐Müller, I.C.E., Institut Für Vergleichende Tropenmedizin Und Parasitologie, Universität München, Germany
Abstract: Investigations on the in vitro cultivation of honey bee cells (Apis mellifera carnica Pollmann, 1879) A synopsis about published methods and results on experiments to cultivate bee cells in vitro is given. Experimental investigations were performed with haemocytes of larvae of the L‐5 stage using many different media and methods for the preparation of primary tissue culture. Monolayers could be prepared and a high rate of reproduction has been achieved, although subpassages could not be obtained. Haemocytes could be kept alive up to 27 days by using BML‐TC/7A medium according to Gardiner and Stockdale, modified by Skatulla (pers. communic., 1987). Further experiments are necessary in order to study the suitability of bee cells to detect specific pathogens and toxic substances. Der Literaturteil befaßt sich mit den bisherigen Methoden und Ergebnissen der in vitro‐ Züchtung von Bienenzellen. Die praktischen Versuche wurden mit Hämozyten der Larven des L‐5‐Stadiums unter Verwendung verschiedenster Medien und Methoden zur Herstellung von Primärkulturen durchgeführt. Die Zellen konnten vermehrt werden und bildeten einschichtige Zellrasen, die sich jedoch nicht subkultivieren ließen. Unter Verwendung des in Anlehnung an Gardiner und Stockdale hergestellten BML‐TC/7 A‐Mediums (modifiziert nach Skatulla, pers. Mitt., 1987), konnten Hämozyten bis zu 27 Tagen am Leben erhalten werden. Zur Feststellung der Eignung von Bienenzellkulturen für den Nachweis von Krankheitserregern und zur Prüfung von toxischen Substanzen müßten weitere Untersuchungen durchgeführt werden. © 1990 Blackwell Verlag GmbH

Title: FMRFamide-like immunoreactivity in the brain of the honeybee (Apis mellifera). A light- and electron microscopical study
Affiliations: I. Zoologisches Institut der Universität, Berliner Str. 28, D-3400 Göttingen, Germany; Institut für Biologie, TU Berlin, Franklinstr. 28, D-1000 Berlin 10, Germany
Authors with affiliations: Schürmann, F.W., I. Zoologisches Institut der Universität, Berliner Str. 28, D-3400 Göttingen, Germany; Erber, J., Institut für Biologie, TU Berlin, Franklinstr. 28, D-1000 Berlin 10, Germany
Abstract: Peptide-FMRFamide-like immunoreactivity in the brain and suboesophageal ganglion of the honeybee Apis mellifera L. is demonstrated with the peroxidase-antiperoxidase technique. Immuno-reactivity is found in about 120 perikarya of the brain and in about 30 of the suboesophageal ganglion. These cells are distributed in 13 paired clusters representing neurons of different types including neurosecretory neurons projecting to neurohemal organs. Immunoreactivity of different intensity is found in the non-glomerular neuropil around the mushroom bodies, in the lateral protocerebrum, the central body, the optic tubercles, the lobula and medulla of optic lobe, the ocellar neuropil, in multiglomerular elements of the antennal lobes and in the dorsal deuterocerebrum. In the mushroom bodies, immuno-reactivity is located in layers of the lobes and stalks, corresponding to intrinsic fibre bundles of some Kenyon cell types. The somata of these intrinsic cells did not show FMRFamide-like immunoreactivity. Electron microscopy of immunostained somata and nerve fibres was performed employing a pre-embedding peroxidase-antiperoxidase technique. Fibres of optic lobes and the non-glomerular neuropil contain immunoreactive dense core vesicles (diameter 50-165 nm) accumulated in boutons besides small synaptic vesicles and synaptic membrane specializations. Immunoreactive layers of the mushroom body neuropil were analysed at the ultrastructural level. Axon profiles with dense-core vesicles of a small type (diameter 35-75 nm) show only faint immunoreactive products. Immunoreactivity of intrinsic mushroom body neurons does not appear to be specifically correlated with synapses and synaptic organelles. Our results indicate that FMRFamide or related peptides peptides may be neuroactive compounds in different classes of nerve cells in the bee brain. © 1990.

Title: Distribution of a systemic functioning medicament in the body of the honey bee, Apis mellifera
Affiliations: Tierhygienisches Institut, Freiburg, Germany
Authors with affiliations: Eyrich, U., Tierhygienisches Institut, Freiburg, Germany; Ritter, W., Tierhygienisches Institut, Freiburg, Germany
Abstract: The distribution of a radio‐labelled substance, which functions systemically, was measured in bees individually fed with cymiazol hydrochloride. After various incubation times, the radioactivity of whole individual bees, as well as various organs and parts were measured by oxidative combustion. The passage of the active ingredient could be followed closely through the intestinal tract. Here, the active ingredient was only found in sufficient quantities in the honey stomach after 4 hours and was only available to other bees if food exchange occured at this time. Lastly, this substances lands in the rectum and is excreted when the bee takes flight. Within 12 hours after application, the active ingredient is found primarily in the muscle and haemolymphs of bees. On the basis of this evidence, it could be shown that the systemic substance cymiazol hydrochloride, or possibly one of its metabolites, is taken up by Varroa mites sucking on the haemolymphs of bees. Zur Verteilung eines systemisch wirkenden Medikaments im Körper der Honigbiene, Apis mellifera Die Verteilung einer systemisch wirkenden radioaktiv markierten Substanz wurde in Bienen gemessen, denen der Wirkstoff Cymiazol hydrochlorid einzeln appliziert wurde. Aus den anschließend einzeln gehaltenen Bienen wurden in zeitlicher Abfolge verschiedene Organe bzw. Teile entnommen und deren Radioaktivität nach oxidativer Verbrennung gemessen. Die Passage des Wirkstoffs durch den Magen‐Darm‐Trakt konnte gut verfolgt werden. Hierbei blieb der Wirkstoff nur für 4 Stunden in ausreichender Menge in der Honigblase und würde auch nur für diese Zeit dem sozialen Futteraustausch im Bienenvolk zur Verfügung stehen. Letzten Endes wird der Wirkstoff in der Kotblase gespeichert und würde beim Ausfliegen abgekotet werden. Innerhalb von 12 Stunden nach der Applikation ist der Wirkstoff vor allem im Muskelgewebe und der Hämolymphe der Bienen zu finden. Anhand des Nachweises von Radioaktivität in Varroa‐Milben konnte bewiesen werden, daß die systemisch wirkende Substanz Cymiazol hydrochlorid oder eines seiner Metaboliten von der an der Biene saugenden Milbe über die Hämolymphe aufgenommen wird. 1990 Blackwell Verlag GmbH

Authors: Yaginuma E.N., Silva de Moraes R.L.M., Cruz-Landim C.
Title: Cytophotometric Evaluation of Corpora Allata DNA During the Development of Larvae of Workers and Queens (Apis Mellifera L.; Hymenoptera, Apidae)
Affiliations: Departamento de Biologia e Centro de Estudos de Insetos Sociais, Universidade Estadual Paulista, Rio Claro, São Paulo, 13500, Brazil
Authors with affiliations: Yaginuma, E.N., Departamento de Biologia e Centro de Estudos de Insetos Sociais, Universidade Estadual Paulista, Rio Claro, São Paulo, 13500, Brazil; Silva de Moraes, R.L.M., Departamento de Biologia e Centro de Estudos de Insetos Sociais, Universidade Estadual Paulista, Rio Claro, São Paulo, 13500, Brazil; Cruz-Landim, C., Departamento de Biologia e Centro de Estudos de Insetos Sociais, Universidade Estadual Paulista, Rio Claro, São Paulo, 13500, Brazil
Abstract: Cytophotometric observation of corpora allata from workers and queens of A. mellifera showed significant variations in DNA content from the 2nd to the 4th instar of both castes, but the differences between castes are present only in the 2nd instar. The corpora allata are characterized by the presence of diploid, as well as polyploid cells, distributed in classes that are well established since the earliest developmental stages. However the frequency of cell nuclei in the higher classes of ploidy increases with development. This occurrence is responsible for the increase of the average DNA content in older larvae. © 1990 International Bee Research Association.

Authors: Espelie K.E., Butz V.M., Dietz A.
Title: Decyl decanoate: A major component of the tergite glands of honeybee queens (Apis mellifera l.)
Affiliations: Department of Entomology, University of Georgia, Athens, GA, 30602, United States
Authors with affiliations: Espelie, K.E., Department of Entomology, University of Georgia, Athens, GA, 30602, United States; Butz, V.M., Department of Entomology, University of Georgia, Athens, GA, 30602, United States; Dietz, A., Department of Entomology, University of Georgia, Athens, GA, 30602, United States
Abstract: Decyl decanoate and longer chain-length esters of decanoic acid were dominant components of the extracts of abdominal tergite glands of virgin honeybee queens, 3–10 days old. The esters were either absent or else present in very small amounts in queens which were 0–2 days old. The cuticular lipids of honeybee queens were predominantly n-alkanes and alkenes with n-heptacosane and hentriacontene being major components. © 1990 International Bee Research Association.

Title: Do honey bee, apis mellifera L., workers favour sibling eggs and larvae in Queen rearing?
Affiliations: Polish Academy of Science, Institute of Systematic and Experimental Zoology, ul. Slawkowaska 17, 31-016 Kraków, Poland
Authors with affiliations: Woyciechowski, M., Polish Academy of Science, Institute of Systematic and Experimental Zoology, ul. Slawkowaska 17, 31-016 Kraków, Poland
Abstract: [No abstract available]

Authors: Brandes Ch., Sugawa M., Menzel R.
Title: High-performance liquid chromatography (HLPC) measurement of catecholamines in single honeybee brains reveals caste-specific differences between worker bees and queens in apis mellifera
Source title: Comparative Biochemistry and Physiology. Part C, Comparative
Affiliations: Freie Universität Berlin, Institut für Neurobiologie, Königin Luise Str. 28-30, 1000 Berlin 33, Germany
Authors with affiliations: Brandes, Ch., Freie Universität Berlin, Institut für Neurobiologie, Königin Luise Str. 28-30, 1000 Berlin 33, Germany; Sugawa, M., Freie Universität Berlin, Institut für Neurobiologie, Königin Luise Str. 28-30, 1000 Berlin 33, Germany; Menzel, R., Freie Universität Berlin, Institut für Neurobiologie, Königin Luise Str. 28-30, 1000 Berlin 33, Germany
Abstract: 1. Catecholamines were determined by HPLC in honeybee brains using automatized extraction and on-line detection with an electrochemical detector. 2. This method has high sensitivity in the range of fmols. Thus, catechols can be measured in single brains as well as in parts of brains. 3. The comparison of brains of worker bees and queens shows a caste-specific content of eatecholamine concentrations in worker bees and queens. 4. The amount of norepinephrine and dopamine are higher in queens than in worker bees. 5. The differences are not caused by the different size of the respective brains, but reflect a difference in the two female castes. © 1990.

Authors: Büchler R., Drescher W., Büchler R.
Title: Variance and Heritability of the Capped Developmental Stage in European Apis Mellifera L. and Its Correlation with Increased Varroa Jacobsoni Oud. Infestation
Affiliations: Universität Bonn, Institut für Landwirtschaftliche Zoologie und Bienenkunde, Bonn, D-5300, Germany; Hessische Landesanstalt für Tierzucht, Abteilung für Bienenzucht, Kirchhain, 3575, Germany
Authors with affiliations: Büchler, R., Universität Bonn, Institut für Landwirtschaftliche Zoologie und Bienenkunde, Bonn, D-5300, Germany; Drescher, W., Universität Bonn, Institut für Landwirtschaftliche Zoologie und Bienenkunde, Bonn, D-5300, Germany; Büchler, R., Hessische Landesanstalt für Tierzucht, Abteilung für Bienenzucht, Kirchhain, 3575, Germany
Abstract: A time-saving method for determining the duration of the capped stage (sealed brood) of large numbers of colonies is described. The results of 112 colonies covering 22 different origins and hybrids of European honeybee races are presented. Differences up to 9 h between strains and up to 19 h within individual colonies could be detected. Influenced by seasonal effects, the average capped period is about 7 h shorter in early than in late summer. For one group of test colonies (n= 21) the Varroa infestation after 18 months of undisturbed colony and mite population development has been determined. The correlation between the capped period and the susceptibility of the colonies to mites is calculated as r = 0·48. By linear regression, an 8·7% reduction of the final mite infestation is calculated for a 1-h reduction of the capped period. The heritability of the duration of the capped period is estimated with h2 = 0·232. This may be a realistic value for test populations of European honeybee under field conditions. © 1990 International Bee Research Association.

Title: Foraging Rates and Hive Contents During the Establishment of Honeybee Colonies (Apis Mellifera L.)
Affiliations: Department of Biology, Hobart and William Smith Colleges, Geneva, NY, 14456, United States
Authors with affiliations: Kolmes, S.A., Department of Biology, Hobart and William Smith Colleges, Geneva, NY, 14456, United States; Sam, Y., Department of Biology, Hobart and William Smith Colleges, Geneva, NY, 14456, United States
Abstract: Four artificial honeybee swarms, as genetically similar to one another as possible, were established on the same day in the same apiary. Each contained a sister queen inseminated with 2 microlitres of mixed semen from seven drones. For each queen, the seven drones were taken respectively from each of seven drone-mother colonies. Each queen, accompanied by 0·91 kg of her own progeny, was placed in a 42-1 hive body provided with 1 frame containing approximately 40 × 30 cm of drawn comb, 9 undrawn frames of comb foundation, and 2·27 kg of sugar syrup. Foraging rates and hive contents were then periodically measured through the summer. The four colonies demonstrated synchronous fluctuations in foraging rates that were not generally associated with amounts of uncapped nectar, capped honey, pollen, or capped brood in the hives. Two colonies reduced their brood rearing early in the summer, and in these colonies there were no significant correlations between foraging rates and amounts of uncapped brood. The other two colonies reared brood at high levels throughout the summer, and the foraging rates were significantly positively correlated with their amounts of uncapped brood. The latter result is consistent with earlier reports of brood pheromone influences on foraging in larger established colonies. © 1990 International Bee Research Association.

Authors: Currie R.W., Jay S.C., Wright D., Currie R.W.
Title: The effects of honeybees (Apis mellifera l.) and leafcutter bees (Megachile rotundata F.) on out-crossing between different cultivars of beans (Vicia Faba L.) in caged plots
Affiliations: Department of Entomology, University of Manitoba, Winnipeg, MB, R3T 2N2, Canada; Dept. of Biological Sciences, Simon Fraser University, Burnaby, BC, V3J ISS, Canada
Authors with affiliations: Currie, R.W., Department of Entomology, University of Manitoba, Winnipeg, MB, R3T 2N2, Canada; Jay, S.C., Department of Entomology, University of Manitoba, Winnipeg, MB, R3T 2N2, Canada; Wright, D., Department of Entomology, University of Manitoba, Winnipeg, MB, R3T 2N2, Canada; Currie, R.W., Dept. of Biological Sciences, Simon Fraser University, Burnaby, BC, V3J ISS, Canada
Abstract: The effectiveness of honeybees and leafcutter bees in cross pollination between two cultivars of faba beans within cages was assessed. Both honeybee and leafcutter bee positive-foragers moved laterally between rows more often than along rows. The bees moved to rows with different cultivars more frequently that to rows with the same cultivar. However, the direction of movement and cultivar preference did not differ significantly between the two species of bees. Honeybees foraged in greater numbers, and on more flowers per bee than did leafcutter bees. The amount of movement also varied with the cultivars that were used. Few bees moved between the cultivars that differed greatly in appearance and growth habit (e.g. Aladin and 15025). The amount of movement between the cultivars Aladin and CM4 was much higher, ranging from 27 to 43 percent in honeybees and 22 percent in leafcutter bees. Honeybees were more effective than leafcutter bees as pollinators of faba beans in caged plots. © 1990 International Bee Research Association.

Authors: Sakamoto C.H., Soares A.E.E., Lopes J.N.C.
Title: A Comparison of 2-Heptanone Production in Africanized and European Strains of the Honeybee, Apis Mellifera L.
Affiliations: Department of Genetics, Ribeirao Preto, Brazil; Department of Chemistry and Physics, University of Sao Paulo, Ribeirao Preto, Brazil
Authors with affiliations: Sakamoto, C.H., Department of Genetics, Ribeirao Preto, Brazil; Soares, A.E.E., Department of Genetics, Ribeirao Preto, Brazil; Lopes, J.N.C., Department of Chemistry and Physics, University of Sao Paulo, Ribeirao Preto, Brazil
Abstract: The pheromone, 2-heptanone, (2-H) was quantified in bee workers of different age, and in three groups of unknown age, each performing a given task in the hive. Africanized (AHB) and European (EHB) honeybee colonies were studied. Younger bees produced no 2-H or produced it at levels undetectable by the apparatus used. 2-H production increased with age. The amount did not differ significantly between AHB and EHB colonies. Foragers with pollen showed a higher 2-H concentration than foragers without pollen and guard bees. 2-H in AHB foragers with pollen differed significantly from that in EHB foragers. © 1990 International Bee Research Association.

Authors: Sakamoto C.H., Soares A.E.E., Lopes J.N.C.
Title: Relationship Between 2-Heptanone and Some Biological and Environmental Variables in Apis Mellifera L.
Affiliations: Department of Genetics, Ribeirao Preto, Brazil; Department of Chemistry and Physics, University of Sao Paulo, Ribeirao Preto, Brazil
Authors with affiliations: Sakamoto, C.H., Department of Genetics, Ribeirao Preto, Brazil; Soares, A.E.E., Department of Genetics, Ribeirao Preto, Brazil; Lopes, J.N.C., Department of Chemistry and Physics, University of Sao Paulo, Ribeirao Preto, Brazil
Abstract: The present study was undertaken to determine the possible interrelationship between 2-heptanone production and brood development, nectar and pollen gathering, defensiveness (number of attacking bees and number of stings left in a ‘test’ ball), temperature and relative air humidity. It was found that 2-H production showed a strong correlation with brood area and it was negatively correlated with number of stings left in a ‘test’ ball. The other factors were not related to 2-H concentration. © 1990 International Bee Research Association.

Title: Nicotinic and muscarinic cholinergic receptors in honey bee (Apis mellifera) brain
Source title: Comparative Biochemistry and Physiology. Part C, Comparative
Affiliations: Department of Entomology, University of Missouri, Columbia, MO65211, U.S.A. [Telephone: (314) 882-7894]
Authors with affiliations: Zhi-Yong Huang, Department of Entomology, University of Missouri, Columbia, MO65211, U.S.A. [Telephone: (314) 882-7894]; Knowles, C.O., Department of Entomology, University of Missouri, Columbia, MO65211, U.S.A. [Telephone: (314) 882-7894]
Abstract: 1. Honey bee head homogenates contained particulate components capable of binding the nicotinic receptor antagonist α-bungarotoxin (BGT) and the muscarinic receptor antagonist quinuclidinyl benzilate (QNB). Specific binding of [125I]BGT (denned by nicotine) and [3H]QNB (defined by atropine) was heat sensitive, linear with tissue concentration, and saturable. Bmax values were 204 fmol mg protein-1 for [125I]BGT and 57 fmol mg protein-1 for [3H]QNB yielding a binding site ratio of 3.6:1. Hill coefficients were 1.0 for each radioligand. 2. Binding by both radioligands was rapid and reversible. Association (k+1) and dissociation (k-1) rates were 1.38 × 106 s-1 M-1 and 6.2 × 10-4 s-1 for [125I]BGT and 3.27 × 106 s-1 M-1 and 9.4 × 10-5 s-1 for [3H]QNB. The dissociation rate constants (KD) were 450 pM ( k-1 k+1) and 743 pM (saturation) for [125I]BGT and 30pM ( k-1 k+1) and 96 pM (saturation) for [3H]QNB. 3. Pharmacological profiles were nicotinic for [125I]BGT with nicotine (Ki 2.6 × 10-7 M), d-tubocurarine (Ki 1.0 × 10-6 M), and ACh + dichlorvos (Ki 4.5 × 10-6 M) being the most potent inhibitors and muscarinic for [3H]QNB with (±)-QNB (Ki 2.2 × 10-12M), S( + )-dexetimide (Ki 2.9 × 10-11 M), atropine (Ki 6.9 × 10-10M), and scopolamine (Ki 4.1 × 10-10M) being most potent. 4. It appeared that [125I]BGT and [3H]QNB were binding with high affinity to honey bee brain populations of nicotinic and muscarinic cholinergic receptors, respectively. © 1990.

Authors: Takenaka T., Ito H., Yatsunami K., Echigo T.
Title: Changes of Glucose Oxidase Activity and Amount of Gluconic Acid Formation in the Hypopharyngeal Glands during the Lifespan of Honey Bee Workers (Apis mellifera L.)
Affiliations: Department of Agricultural Chemistry, Faculty of Agriculture, Tamagawa University, Machida-shi Tokyo 194, Japan
Authors with affiliations: Takenaka, T., Department of Agricultural Chemistry, Faculty of Agriculture, Tamagawa University, Machida-shi Tokyo 194, Japan; Ito, H., Department of Agricultural Chemistry, Faculty of Agriculture, Tamagawa University, Machida-shi Tokyo 194, Japan; Yatsunami, K., Department of Agricultural Chemistry, Faculty of Agriculture, Tamagawa University, Machida-shi Tokyo 194, Japan; Echigo, T., Department of Agricultural Chemistry, Faculty of Agriculture, Tamagawa University, Machida-shi Tokyo 194, Japan

Title: A comparative study of morphological integration in Apis mellifera (Insecta, Hymenoptera)
Source title: Journal of Zoological Systematics and Evolutionary Research
Affiliations: Department of Ecology and Evolutionary Biology, Northwestern University, Evanston, United States
Authors with affiliations: Wagner, G.P., Department of Ecology and Evolutionary Biology, Northwestern University, Evanston, United States
Abstract: Morphometric correlation matrices from 11 Mediterranean and European honey bee races have been compared. The degree of integration, measured by the eigenvalue variance of the correlation matrix or by Cheverud's index of integration, varies considerably between races but covaries neither with overall body size nor with the variance of the respective sample. Hence, the degree of morphological integration does not depend on body size or the level of variability The patterns of morphometric correlation are significantly similar among all races, but some minor differences in the patterns could be detected: The similarity between the correlation matrices is independent of the degree of phylogenetic relatedness between the respective races. In all races characters belonin to the same functional and/or developmental unit (leg, wing, abdominal characters) have Eiter correlations than the average. Most of the variation in the pattern of correlation can be expfained as a side effect of variation in the degree of integration. Races with high levels of integration tend to have hiher correlations between the main groups of characters, and races with low levels of integration tave smaller correlations between the main grous of characters, while the basic pattern remains undisturbed. In summary, the comparative analysis of morphometric correlation matrices reveals a picture of stability with respect to the pattern of integration and of variation in the degree of integration, which is random with respect to body size, degree of variability, and phylogeny. Copyright © 1990, Wiley Blackwell. All rights reserved
Author Keywords: Morphological integration; Phenotypic correlations; Quantitative variation

Title: Ultrastructure of mitochondria in the corpora allata of honeybees infected by Nosema apis before and after treatment with anti-Nosema drugs
Affiliations: Bee Diseases Research Laboratory, Agriculture Canada Research Station, Box 29, Beaverlodge, Alta. T0H 0C0, Canada
Authors with affiliations: Liu, T.P., Bee Diseases Research Laboratory, Agriculture Canada Research Station, Box 29, Beaverlodge, Alta. T0H 0C0, Canada
Abstract: Ultrastructural differences were observed among mitochondria from the corpora allata of healthy, Nosema-infected, and anti-Nosema drug treated honeybees. Mitochondria in the corpora allata of the healthy honeybees were large in size, possessed well defined membrane, numerous mitochondrial granules and less electron-dense matrix. In the corpora allata of Nosema-infected honeybees, mitochondria were small in size and the mitochondrial matrix had a higher electron density. Mitochondria from the corpora allata of Nosema-infected honeybees after treatment with thimerosal, had a lower electron density in the mitochondrial matrix and a larger diameter than those from untreated honeybees. Mitochondria from fumagillin-treated honeybees had the smallest diameter and the highest electron density in the matrix among mitochondria observed in the present study. Image analysis also confirmed the differences in the electron density of the mitochondrial matrix among mitochondria in the corpora allata of four experimental groups of honey bees. © 1990.
Author Keywords: Corpora allata; fumagillin; Honeybees; image analysis; Mitochondria; Nosema apis; thimerosal

Authors: Grissa K., Cornuet J.M., Msadda K., Fresnaye J.
Title: Biometrical study of honey bee populations from Tunisia [Etude biometrique de populations d'abeilles tunisiennes]
Affiliations: INRA-CNRS, Lab de Neurobiologie comparee des Invertebres, BP 23, 91440 Bures-sur-Yvette, France
Authors with affiliations: Grissa, K., INRA-CNRS, Lab de Neurobiologie comparee des Invertebres, BP 23, 91440 Bures-sur-Yvette, France; Cornuet, J.M., INRA-CNRS, Lab de Neurobiologie comparee des Invertebres, BP 23, 91440 Bures-sur-Yvette, France; Msadda, K., INRA-CNRS, Lab de Neurobiologie comparee des Invertebres, BP 23, 91440 Bures-sur-Yvette, France; Fresnaye, J., INRA-CNRS, Lab de Neurobiologie comparee des Invertebres, BP 23, 91440 Bures-sur-Yvette, France
Abstract: The whole population is rather homogeneous for 6 studied characters without any regional differentiation. This population is included in the reference Apis mellifera intermissa sample. -from English summary

Authors: Walker A.K., Joshi N.K., Verma S.K.
Title: The biosystematics of Syntretomorpha szaboi Papp (Hymenoptera: Braconidae: Euphorinae) attacking the Oriental honey bee, Apis cerana Fabricius. (Hymenoptera: Apidae), with a review of braconid parasitoids attacking bees
Affiliations: CAB International Institute of Entomology, London, United Kingdom; Government Bee Keeping Station, Jeolikote, Nainital, India
Authors with affiliations: Walker, A.K., CAB International Institute of Entomology, London, United Kingdom; Joshi, N.K., Government Bee Keeping Station, Jeolikote, Nainital, India; Verma, S.K., Government Bee Keeping Station, Jeolikote, Nainital, India
Abstract: Records of braconid parasitoids attacking bees (Apidae) are reviewed and their biology is discussed. The adult of Syntretomorpha szaboi Papp (Braconidae) is redescribed, the female for the first time. The finAl-instar larva is also described for the first time and the implications of interpreting larval characters are discussed. The Oriental honey bee, Apis cerana Fabricius, is recorded here for the first time as the host of S. szaboi. © 1990, Cambridge University Press. All rights reserved.

Title: Ultrastructural changes in the secretion granules of the hypopharyngeal glands of the honeybee infected by Nosema apis and after treatment with fumagillin
Affiliations: Bee Diseases Research Laboratory, Agriculture Canada Research Station, Box 29, Beaverlodge, Alta. T0H 0C0, Canada
Authors with affiliations: Liu, T.P., Bee Diseases Research Laboratory, Agriculture Canada Research Station, Box 29, Beaverlodge, Alta. T0H 0C0, Canada
Abstract: Electron-dense secretion granules were numerous in the hypopharyngeal glands of healthy honeybees. In the hyopharyngeal glands of honeybees infected by Nosema apis, these granules appeared to have increased in size and lost their electron density, possessing a core area that consisted of numerous smaller granules, and a slightly electron dense fringe area, which in some cases possessed a crystalline structure. In the hypopharyngeal glands of infected honeybees after treatment with fumagillin, the secretion granules were also large and slightly electron dense, but the granular content was homogenous. Some of these granules were also partially crystallized. These ultrastructural changes in the secretion granules of diseased and fumagillin treated bees, is probably associated with a change in secretory activity of the glands. © 1990.
Author Keywords: Fumagillin; Honeybees; hypopharyngeal glands; image analysis; Nosema apis; secretion granules

Title: Ultrastructural differences of neurosecretion granules in the corpora cardiaca of the honeybee with and without infection by Nosema apis
Affiliations: Bee Diseases Research Laboratory, Agriculture Canada Research Station, Box 29, Beaverlodge, Alta. T0H 0C0, Canada
Authors with affiliations: Liu, T.P., Bee Diseases Research Laboratory, Agriculture Canada Research Station, Box 29, Beaverlodge, Alta. T0H 0C0, Canada
Abstract: Axons of corpora cardiaca in the Nosema infected honeybees contained numerous tightly packed neurosecretion granules. These granules invariably possessed high electron densities. Neurosecretion granules of similar size were also observed in the axons of corpora cardiaca in the healthy honeybees. But these granules were shown to possess various electron densities. Image analysis revealed that some of these granules possessed an electron dense core, and the electron densities decreased gradually from the core, to the fringe of the granule. Some granules appeared to be completely broken down into fine granular substances, while others appeared to be completely broken down into finer particles. It is suggested that in the healthy honeybees, the releasing of neurosecretion from the corpora cardiaca had taken place normally, whereas in the diseased bee, the releasing mechanism had been blocked. The blockage is probably due to the infection. © 1990.
Author Keywords: corpora cardiaca; honeybees; image analysis; neurosecretion granules; Nosema apis

Authors: Burgett D.M., Rossignol P.A., Kitprasert C.
Title: A model of dispersion and regulation of brood mite (Tropilaelaps clareae) parasitism on the giant honeybee (Apis dorsata)
Affiliations: Dept. of Entomology, Cordley Hall, Oregon State Univ., Corvallis, OR 97331-2907, USA.
Authors with affiliations: Burgett, D.M., Dept. of Entomology, Cordley Hall, Oregon State Univ., Corvallis, OR 97331-2907, USA.; Rossignol, P.A., Dept. of Entomology, Cordley Hall, Oregon State Univ., Corvallis, OR 97331-2907, USA.; Kitprasert, C., Dept. of Entomology, Cordley Hall, Oregon State Univ., Corvallis, OR 97331-2907, USA.
Abstract: The distribution of T. clareae on A. dorsata in N Thailand is aggregated and fits a negative binomial distribution if parasite-associated host mortality is presumed. No brood mortality was directly observed; the authors account for this presumed host mortality through the removal of infested late-instar larval brood or pupae, along with their parasites, by worker nurse bees. An ability of bees to detect infected brood, as a function of the number of parasites associated with the host, correlates significantly with observed data. Such a prophylactic strategy could regulate parasite density, because parasite mortality would increase more rapidly than brood host mortality. The potential tendency for the parasite population to be less aggregated, to evade bee defensive behaviour, may be counteracted by an advantage to sexual reproduction. -from Authors

Title: Ultrastructural analysis on the gland secretion in the extracellular ducts of the hypopharyngeal glands of the honeybee infected by Nosema apis
Affiliations: Bee Diseases Research Laboratory, Agriculture Canada Research Station, Box 29, Beaverlodge, Alta. T0H 0C0, Canada
Authors with affiliations: Liu, T.P., Bee Diseases Research Laboratory, Agriculture Canada Research Station, Box 29, Beaverlodge, Alta. T0H 0C0, Canada
Abstract: The hypopharyngeal glands of the honeybee secrete the larval food royal jelly, along with enzymes that are used in the production of honey from nectar. The composition of this secretion mixture varies with the physiological condition of the honeybee, and the final secretion mixture is conveyed through the extracellular ducts to the large excretory duct. The secretion products in the extracellular duct of both healthy and infected honeybees, was studied by transmission electron microscopy and image analysis. These products consisted of a densely packed, faintly visible granular substance. The granules were clearly defined by the computer enhanced image. The secretion products from the Nosema-infected honeybees exhibited the same granular structure, but were much less concentrated, thereby reducing the overall electron density of the secretion. These observations suggest that the composition of the secretion products from the hypopharyngeal glands in the Nosema-infected honeybees, was altered considerably. © 1990.
Author Keywords: extracellular ducts; gland secretion; Honeybee; hypopharyngeal glands; image analysis; Nosema apis

Authors: Schumacher M.J., Schmidt J.O., Egen N.B., Lowry J.E.
Title: Quantity, analysis, and lethality of European and Africanized honey bee venoms
Source title: American Journal of Tropical Medicine and Hygiene
Affiliations: Department of Pediatrics, University of Arizona Health Sciences Center, Tucson, AZ 85724, United States
Authors with affiliations: Schumacher, M.J., Department of Pediatrics, University of Arizona Health Sciences Center, Tucson, AZ 85724, United States; Schmidt, J.O., Department of Pediatrics, University of Arizona Health Sciences Center, Tucson, AZ 85724, United States; Egen, N.B., Department of Pediatrics, University of Arizona Health Sciences Center, Tucson, AZ 85724, United States; Lowry, J.E., Department of Pediatrics, University of Arizona Health Sciences Center, Tucson, AZ 85724, United States
Abstract: Venom from Africanized honey bees (derived mainly from Apis mellifera scutellata) was compared with venom from domestic, European bees by study of lethality, immunological cross-reactivity, venom yield, isoelectric focusing (IEF) patterns, and melittin titers. The LD50s of European and Africanized bee venom by iv injection in mice were similar. In venom neutralization experiments, Africanized bee venom was mixed with antibodies from a beekeeper exposed only to European bees and used to challenge mice. Survival times of mice given these mixtures were significantly prolonged, indicating that human serum antibodies to European bee venom neutralized the lethal effects of Africanized bee venom. Reservoirs from Africanized bees contained less venom than European bees (94 and 147 μg venom/bee, respectively) and Africanized bee venom had a lower melittin content. The IEF patterns of venom from individual European bees varied considerably, as did IEF patterns of individual Africanized bees. Pools of venom from 1,000 bees of each population of A. mellifera showed noticeable but less obvious electrophoretic differences. The findings suggest that multiple stinging, and not increased venom potency or delivery, is the cause of serious reactions from Africanized bee attacks.

Title: Recovery of learning responses by honeybees following a sublethal exposure to permethrin
Affiliations: USDA-ARS, Tucson, Arizona, United States
Authors with affiliations: MAMOOD, A.N., USDA-ARS, Tucson, Arizona, United States; WALLER, G.D., USDA-ARS, Tucson, Arizona, United States
Abstract: ABSTRACT A classical conditioned response was used to evaluate the learning behaviour of honeybees (Apis mellifera L.) which survived a sublethal dose of permethrin. Treated bees had lower learning response levels than untreated bees for 3 days, but regained normal learning ability on the fourth day after exposure. However, bees trained prior to exposure showed no significant effect of permethrin on their conditioned response. Copyright © 1990, Wiley Blackwell. All rights reserved
Author Keywords: Apis mellifera L.; odour; pyrethroid; thyme

Authors: Schmid K.P., Maier V., Haug C., Pfeiffer E.F.
Title: Ultrastructural localization of prolactin-like antigenic determinants in neurosecretory cells in the brain of the honeybee (Apis Mellifica)
Affiliations: Medizinische Universitatskl., Abteilung Innere Medizin I, Universitat Ulm, Robert-Koch-Strasse 8, D-7900 Ulm, Germany
Authors with affiliations: Schmid, K.P., Medizinische Universitatskl., Abteilung Innere Medizin I, Universitat Ulm, Robert-Koch-Strasse 8, D-7900 Ulm, Germany; Maier, V., Medizinische Universitatskl., Abteilung Innere Medizin I, Universitat Ulm, Robert-Koch-Strasse 8, D-7900 Ulm, Germany; Haug, C., Medizinische Universitatskl., Abteilung Innere Medizin I, Universitat Ulm, Robert-Koch-Strasse 8, D-7900 Ulm, Germany; Pfeiffer, E.F., Medizinische Universitatskl., Abteilung Innere Medizin I, Universitat Ulm, Robert-Koch-Strasse 8, D-7900 Ulm, Germany
Abstract: With two different antisera to human prolactin (hPRL), the ultrastructural localization of PRL-like material in the bee brain is examined by means of the protein-A-gold method at the electron microscopical level. Labelling is found in electron-dense granules of medium size (150-200 nm in diameter) for the first time in insects. Such granules are distributed in the cytoplasm of the neurosecretory cells, their axons and their axon-terminals. The electron-dense granule is one criterion for identifying a neurosecretory cell. In the honeybee, hPRL-like material may serve as an old neurohormone with respect to its evolution.
Author Keywords: comparative endocrinology; honeybee; neurosecretory granula; prolactin

Authors: Danka R.G., Williams J.L., Rinderer T.E.
Title: A bait station for survey and detection of honey bees
Affiliations: USDA, ARS Honey-Bee Breeding, Genetics & Physiology Lab, 1157 Ben Hur Rd, Baton Rouge, LA 70820, USA
Authors with affiliations: Danka, R.G., USDA, ARS Honey-Bee Breeding, Genetics & Physiology Lab, 1157 Ben Hur Rd, Baton Rouge, LA 70820, USA; Williams, J.L., USDA, ARS Honey-Bee Breeding, Genetics & Physiology Lab, 1157 Ben Hur Rd, Baton Rouge, LA 70820, USA; Rinderer, T.E., USDA, ARS Honey-Bee Breeding, Genetics & Physiology Lab, 1157 Ben Hur Rd, Baton Rouge, LA 70820, USA
Abstract: Apis mellifera were attracted with honey and Nasonov pheromone components (1:1 citral:geraniol). -from Authors

Authors with affiliations: Bromenshenk, J.J.; Lockwood-Ogan, N.
Abstract: Areas of comb can be used to assess qualities of Apis mellifera, colony dynamics such as brood rearing, hoarding behavior, and food stores. -from Authors

Authors: Pham-Delegue M.H., Le Metayer M., Douault P., Masson C.
Title: Age-related foraging behaviour in honey bees under artificial conditions
Affiliations: INRA-CNRS (URA 1190), Laboratoire de Neurobiologie Comparee des Invertebres, 91440 Burea-sur-Yvette, France
Authors with affiliations: Pham-Delegue, M.H., INRA-CNRS (URA 1190), Laboratoire de Neurobiologie Comparee des Invertebres, 91440 Burea-sur-Yvette, France; Le Metayer, M., INRA-CNRS (URA 1190), Laboratoire de Neurobiologie Comparee des Invertebres, 91440 Burea-sur-Yvette, France; Douault, P., INRA-CNRS (URA 1190), Laboratoire de Neurobiologie Comparee des Invertebres, 91440 Burea-sur-Yvette, France; Masson, C., INRA-CNRS (URA 1190), Laboratoire de Neurobiologie Comparee des Invertebres, 91440 Burea-sur-Yvette, France
Abstract: Foraging was mostly performed by the oldest Apis mellifera workers, who came to forage first and were the most numerous. Regardless of their age group, each individual coming to forage performed a constant average level of activity. -from Authors

Authors: Vandenberg J.D., Streett D.A., Herbert Jr E.W.
Title: Safety of grasshopper entomopoxviruses for caged adult honey bees (Hymenoptera: Apidae)
Affiliations: Bee Biology & Systematics, USDA-ARS, Lab, Utah State Univ, Logan, Utah 84322-5310, USA
Authors with affiliations: Vandenberg, J.D., Bee Biology & Systematics, USDA-ARS, Lab, Utah State Univ, Logan, Utah 84322-5310, USA; Streett, D.A., Bee Biology & Systematics, USDA-ARS, Lab, Utah State Univ, Logan, Utah 84322-5310, USA; Herbert Jr, E.W., Bee Biology & Systematics, USDA-ARS, Lab, Utah State Univ, Logan, Utah 84322-5310, USA
Abstract: Two entomopoxviruses (EPVs), one each from Melanoplus sanguinipes and Oedaleus senegalensis were tested for their safety for newly emerged adult workers of Apis mellifera. Neither reductions in longevity nor pathological effects of the grasshopper EPVs were observed. -Authors

Title: Budgets for the use of floral resources in mallee-heath
Source title: The mallee lands. Proc. national mallee conference, Adelaide, 1989
Authors with affiliations: Paton, D.C.
Abstract: Honeybees Apis mellifera removed up to 90% of the nectar and pollen produced by several native plants. Managers could produce budgets for the use of floral resources on reserves, and use these to set limits to honeybee densities. -from Author

Title: Observations on the floral biology of Prosopis (Leguminosae, Mimosoideae). II. Floral phase and visitors in the chaqueno serrano district [Observaciones sobre la biologia floral de Prosopis (Leguminosae, Mimosoideae). II. Fases florales y visitantes en el distrito chaqueno serrano]
Affiliations: Museo Argentino de Ciencias Naturales "Bernardino Rivadavia', Av. A. Gallardo 470 (1045) Capital Federal, Spain
Authors with affiliations: Genise, J., Museo Argentino de Ciencias Naturales "Bernardino Rivadavia', Av. A. Gallardo 470 (1045) Capital Federal, Spain
Abstract: Describes a community of Prosopis chilensis, P. flexuosa and P. pugionata growing in the Reserva Provincial "Los Pocitos', Dpto. de Pocho, Prov. de Cordoba. Pollinators included Caupolicana mendocina, Xylocopa splendidula and Apis mellifera. -from English summary

Title: Effects of honey-bee alarm pheromone compounds on the behaviour of Varroa jacobsoni
Affiliations: Institut fur Bienenkunde, Polytechnische Gesellschaft, Fachbereich Biologie der JW Goethe-Universitat, Karl-von-Frisch-Weg 2, D-6370 Oberursel/Ts, Germany
Authors with affiliations: Kraus, B., Institut fur Bienenkunde, Polytechnische Gesellschaft, Fachbereich Biologie der JW Goethe-Universitat, Karl-von-Frisch-Weg 2, D-6370 Oberursel/Ts, Germany
Abstract: Apis mellifera killed by freezing were more attractive to Varroa than bees stung to death by other bees. The smell of the sting apparatus proved to be repellent for Varroa. -from Author

Authors: Naumann K., Winston M.L., Wyborn M.H., Slessor K.N.
Title: Effects of synthetic, honey bee (Hymenoptera: Apidae) queen mandibular-gland pheromone on workers in packages
Affiliations: Simon Fraser University, Burnaby, British Columbia V5A 1S6, Canada
Authors with affiliations: Naumann, K., Simon Fraser University, Burnaby, British Columbia V5A 1S6, Canada; Winston, M.L., Simon Fraser University, Burnaby, British Columbia V5A 1S6, Canada; Wyborn, M.H., Simon Fraser University, Burnaby, British Columbia V5A 1S6, Canada; Slessor, K.N., Simon Fraser University, Burnaby, British Columbia V5A 1S6, Canada
Abstract: Synthetic queen mandibular-gland pheromone can be used as a queen substitute for the shipment and temporary storage of packaged Apis mellifera provided that proper care is taken when introducing queens following package shipment. -from Authors

Authors: Sakofski F., Koeniger N., Fuchs S.
Title: Seasonality of honey bee colony invasion by Varroa jacobsoni Oud
Affiliations: Institut fur Bienenkunde (Polytechnische Gesellschaft), FB Biologie der JW Geothe-Universitat, Frankfurt/Main, D-6370 Oberursel, Karl- von-Frisch-Weg 2, Germany.
Authors with affiliations: Sakofski, F., Institut fur Bienenkunde (Polytechnische Gesellschaft), FB Biologie der JW Geothe-Universitat, Frankfurt/Main, D-6370 Oberursel, Karl- von-Frisch-Weg 2, Germany.; Koeniger, N., Institut fur Bienenkunde (Polytechnische Gesellschaft), FB Biologie der JW Geothe-Universitat, Frankfurt/Main, D-6370 Oberursel, Karl- von-Frisch-Weg 2, Germany.; Fuchs, S., Institut fur Bienenkunde (Polytechnische Gesellschaft), FB Biologie der JW Geothe-Universitat, Frankfurt/Main, D-6370 Oberursel, Karl- von-Frisch-Weg 2, Germany.
Abstract: Invasion of the mite Varroa jacobsoni into Apis mellifera colonies was low in spring and increased considerably during summer when it remained at high levels until autumn. -from Authors

Authors: Nasr M.E., Thorp R.W., Tyler T.L., Briggs D.L.
Title: Estimating honey bee (Hymenoptera: Apidae) colony strength by a simple method: measuring cluster size
Affiliations: Dept. of Entomology, Univ. of California, Davis, California 95616, USA.
Authors with affiliations: Nasr, M.E., Dept. of Entomology, Univ. of California, Davis, California 95616, USA.; Thorp, R.W., Dept. of Entomology, Univ. of California, Davis, California 95616, USA.; Tyler, T.L., Dept. of Entomology, Univ. of California, Davis, California 95616, USA.; Briggs, D.L., Dept. of Entomology, Univ. of California, Davis, California 95616, USA.
Abstract: A cluster count method for estimating Apis mellifera colony strength is presented in contrast to intensive frame-by-frame evaluations. Cluster counts are recommended to growers and beekeepers involved in pollination contracts as a simple, rapid economic evaluation method which is not excessively disruptive to the colony. -from Authors

Title: On the relative importance of queens and workers to honey production
Affiliations: US Dept. of Agriculture, Honey-Bee Breeding, Genetics & Physiology Research Lab., 1157 Ben Hur Rd., Baton Rouge, LA 70820, USA
Authors with affiliations: Oldroyd, B.P., US Dept. of Agriculture, Honey-Bee Breeding, Genetics & Physiology Research Lab., 1157 Ben Hur Rd., Baton Rouge, LA 70820, USA; Goodman, R.D., US Dept. of Agriculture, Honey-Bee Breeding, Genetics & Physiology Research Lab., 1157 Ben Hur Rd., Baton Rouge, LA 70820, USA
Abstract: Colonies of honey bees Apis mellifera with different queen genotypes, but identical worker genotype, were established. The 2 groups differed significantly in both weight gain and brood area, indicating the queen genotype influences honey production. Queen genotype plays a significant part in colony genotypic merit for honey production. -from Authors

Title: Comparison of honey bee (Hymenoptera: Apidae) mortality as a result of diurnal and nocturnal applications of dimethoate
Authors with affiliations: Byrne, D.N.; Waller, G.D.
Abstract: Applications of dimethoate in Arizona are currently being made to citrus orchards at night to reduce the hazard to pollinating honey bees, Apis mellifera. Bee mortality from applications sprayed at night, although significantly lower than the applications sprayed during the day, is probably still at a level unacceptable to beekeepers. -from Authors

Title: The influence of detoxifying enzymes on insecticide tolerance in honey bee colonies (Hymenoptera: Apidae)
Affiliations: Agric Canada Res Stn, Summerland, CC V0H 1Z0, Canada
Authors with affiliations: Smirle, M.J., Agric Canada Res Stn, Summerland, CC V0H 1Z0, Canada
Abstract: Colonies of Apis mellifera showed variation in tolerance to diazinon, propoxur, aldrin and carbaryl. Tolerance to diazinon and propoxur was positively related to midgut mixed-function oxidase and glutathione transferase enzyme activities, but tolerance to aldrin was inversely related to these enzymes. Differences in tolerance to carbaryl were evident among colonies but were not related to enzyme activity levels. -from Author

Title: The population density of feral colonies of honey bees (Hymenoptera: Apidae) in a city in upstate New York
Affiliations: Department of Entomology, Cornell University, Ithaca, New York 14853, USA
Authors with affiliations: Morse, R.A., Department of Entomology, Cornell University, Ithaca, New York 14853, USA
Abstract: In Oswego, a search for Apis mellifera colonies in an area of 4.2 km2 revealed 12 colonies. All but one of the colonies were feral, living in tree cavities and the walls of buildings. Density was 2.7 colonies km-2. -from Authors

Title: The protein balance of the honey bee worker
Affiliations: Inst fur Zool an der Karl-Franzens-Univ, Universitatsplatz 2, A-8010 Graz, Austria
Authors with affiliations: Crailsheim, K., Inst fur Zool an der Karl-Franzens-Univ, Universitatsplatz 2, A-8010 Graz, Austria
Abstract: For Apis mellifera workers, protein requirements and consumption, digestion, intestinal absorption and utilisation all depend on the worker's age and functional status in the system of division of labor within the colony. Workers at the stage of nurses play a pivotal role not only in protein digestion but also in its distribution. They are well equipped for digestion of pollen, are rich in protein and produce large amounts of jelly, which they distribute to almost all members of the colony. -Author

Title: Pollen grains adhering to bodies of honeybees after cole (Brassica oleracea) crop pollination [Pollenkorner am Bienenkorper nach der Bestaubung verschiedener Kohlsorten (Brassica oleracea)]
Affiliations: College of Agriculture, Brno, Czechoslovakia
Authors with affiliations: Kubisova, S., College of Agriculture, Brno, Czechoslovakia; Haslbachova, H., College of Agriculture, Brno, Czechoslovakia
Abstract: Determined the shortest time lapse after which the same group of Apis mellifera could be utilized for pollination of genetically related material without the risk of causing undesirable cross-fertilization. In the studied plant material, transportation of viable pollen carried on bodies of honeybees from the hive to the stigmas of flowers is highly improbable, because of the low germinability of the pollen grains and their deposition on inaccessible parts of the honeybee body. -from English summary

Authors: Gambino P., Hoelmer K., Daly H.V.
Title: Nest sites of feral honey bees in California, USA
Affiliations: Hawaii Volcanoes National Park, Field Res Center, Box 52, Hawaii National Park, HI 96718, USA
Authors with affiliations: Gambino, P., Hawaii Volcanoes National Park, Field Res Center, Box 52, Hawaii National Park, HI 96718, USA; Hoelmer, K., Hawaii Volcanoes National Park, Field Res Center, Box 52, Hawaii National Park, HI 96718, USA; Daly, H.V., Hawaii Volcanoes National Park, Field Res Center, Box 52, Hawaii National Park, HI 96718, USA
Abstract: Apis mellifera nests wee in trees of mean diameter 85cm primarily in live hardwoods, especially oaks. Entrances were mostly single knots or cracks in the main trunk at ground level and up to a mean height of 2.5m. Most nests in the ground were in treeless areas; half had partially exposed combs, possibly aiding ventilation. Nests in buildings differed from those in trees by having smaller entrances. Compass orientation of comb in natural nest sites was commonly from 145-195°. -from Authors

Title: Safety of four entomopathogens for caged adult honey bees (Hymenoptera: Apidae)
Affiliations: Beneficial Insects Lab, USDA-ARS, Beltsville, MD 20705, USA
Authors with affiliations: Vandenberg, J.D., Beneficial Insects Lab, USDA-ARS, Beltsville, MD 20705, USA
Abstract: The bacterium Bacillus sphaericus and the fungus Entomophaga maimaiga did not affect Apis mellifera longevity and did not cause disease among treated bees. Both of these microorganisms are considered safe for honey bees. A technical powder and a formulated product of the bacterium Bacillus thuringiensis var. tenebrionis reduced bee longevity at the higher concentration tested (108 spores/ml sucrose syrup), but did not cause disease. The fungus Beauveria bassiana reduced bee longevity at the 2 highest concentrations tested and caused mycosis among treated bees at all 3 concentrations tested (106-108 spores per bee). -from Author

Authors: Haouar M., De Cormis L., Rey J.
Title: Fluvalinate applied to flowering apple trees: contamination of honey-gathering bees and hive products [Le fluvalinate applique sur pommiers en pleine floraison: contamination des abeilles butineuses et des produits de la ruche]
Affiliations: INRA, Station de phytopharmacie, centre de recherches d'Avignon, 84140 Montfavet, France
Authors with affiliations: Haouar, M., INRA, Station de phytopharmacie, centre de recherches d'Avignon, 84140 Montfavet, France; De Cormis, L., INRA, Station de phytopharmacie, centre de recherches d'Avignon, 84140 Montfavet, France; Rey, J., INRA, Station de phytopharmacie, centre de recherches d'Avignon, 84140 Montfavet, France
Abstract: Just after treatment at recommended insecticidal doses (144 g/ha) apple tree flowers contained 41.3 μg/g of fluvalinate and 11 d later residues were still present at the level of 34.4 μg/g. Fluvalinate concentrations gathered in the pollen were 0.26 μg/g 1 d after treatment and 0.13 μg/g 2 d after treatment while no more residues could be detected at D+6. Apis mellifera contained 0.075 μg/g at D+1, 0.006 μg/g/bee (3000 times less than the LD50), 0.032 μg/g at D+4 and no more residues at D+7. Honey collected from hives one month after treatment did not contain residues of fluvalinate. -from English summary

Authors: Baumann O., Kitazawa T., Somlyo A.P.
Title: Laser Confocal scanning microscopy of the surface membrane/T-tubular system and the sarcoplasmic reticulum in insect striated muscle stained with DiIC18(3)
Affiliations: Institut fur Zoologie, Universitat Regensburg, Universitatsstrasse 31, D-8400 Regensburg, Germany; Department of Physiology, Medical Center, University of Virginia, Box 449, Charlottesville, VA 22908, United States
