Title: Nosema Apis and Mites in Honeybee Colonies in Papua New Guinea
Affiliations: Wallaceville Animal Research Centre, Research Division, Ministry of Agriculture and Fisheries, Private Bag, Upper Hutt, New Zealand
Authors with affiliations: Clinch, P.G., Wallaceville Animal Research Centre, Research Division, Ministry of Agriculture and Fisheries, Private Bag, Upper Hutt, New Zealand
Abstract: Colonies of Apis mellifera in a beekeeping project in Papua New Guinea were surveyed in November 1977, to determine the prevalence of Nosema apis and mite infestation. Bees in samples from 47% of 403 colonies of Apis mellifera contained Nosema apis spores, but only 4 colonies showed more than 5 × 106 spores per bee. Approximately 30 000 bees from 424 colonies were screened for mites, and Acarapis externus, A. dorsalis and Neocypholaelaps africana were identified; none have previously been recorded in Papua New Guinea. No mite species believed to be of danger to honeybees was found. © 1979 International Bee Research Association.

Authors: Koeniger N., Weiss J., Maschwitz U.
Title: Alarm pheromones of the sting in the genus Apis
Affiliations: Fachbereich Biologie d. J. W. Goethe-Universität, Institut fur Bienenkunde (Polytechn. Ges.), Im Rothkopf 5, D-6370 Oberursel/Js., Germany
Authors with affiliations: Koeniger, N., Fachbereich Biologie d. J. W. Goethe-Universität, Institut fur Bienenkunde (Polytechn. Ges.), Im Rothkopf 5, D-6370 Oberursel/Js., Germany; Weiss, J., Fachbereich Biologie d. J. W. Goethe-Universität, Institut fur Bienenkunde (Polytechn. Ges.), Im Rothkopf 5, D-6370 Oberursel/Js., Germany; Maschwitz, U., Fachbereich Biologie d. J. W. Goethe-Universität, Institut fur Bienenkunde (Polytechn. Ges.), Im Rothkopf 5, D-6370 Oberursel/Js., Germany
Abstract: An experimental comparison of sting extracts of all four species was carried out in Oberursel in flight rooms as well as in the natural habitat of Asiatic bees in Sri Lanka. The following results were obtained.o1.The behavioural response to sting extracts showed only slight differences among the four species, but the duration of the reaction to the extract was different. In Apis mellifera and Apis cerana it lasted ca. 3 min and in Apis florea and Apis dorsata 6-15 min.2.Interspecific tests led to the conclusion that Apis florea and Apis dorsata must have an additional pheromone besides isopentyl acetate (ipa).3.Using gas chromatographic analysis, 2-decen-1-yl-acetate (2da) was found in sting extracts of Apis florea and Apis dorsata.4.2da had a specific effect in Apis florea and Apis dorsata only. It extended the duration of the alarm reaction compared to the reaction on pure ipa. A mixture of ipa and 2da had a similar effect on the behaviour and reaction time, as did sting extracts. © 1979 Pergamon Press Ltd.

Title: Sex determination in apis cerana indica
Affiliations: Central Bee Research Institute, Pune 4, India; Institut für Bienenkunde, Oberursel/Ts., Germany; Bee Division, Agricultural University, Warszawa, Ursynów, 02-766, Poland
Authors with affiliations: Woyke, J., Central Bee Research Institute, Pune 4, India, Institut für Bienenkunde, Oberursel/Ts., Germany, Bee Division, Agricultural University, Warszawa, Ursynów, 02-766, Poland
Abstract: Each of 11 Apis cerana indica queens was mated instrumentally to 5–29 of her brothers. Any queen mated to more than 15 brothers laid only fertilized eggs in worker cells. Unlike A. mellifera, almost all A. cerana larvae produced by sibling-mated queens survived their first day of larval life. The youngest larvae were collected from worker cells for microscopical investigation. Examinations of slides prepared from 572 larvae (originating from all the sibling-mated queens) showed that 27–4% were drones, most of which must have developed from fertilized eggs. This percentage is close to the expected 25%, and it is concluded that the sex determination mechanism in A. cerana is similar to that in A. mellifera, where there is one sex locus X with several alleles. Heterozygosity results in females, homozygosity in diploid males, and hemizygosity in haploid males. The fate of diploid drone larvae in the colony is different in A. cerana and A. mellifera. © 1979 International Bee Research Association.

Authors: Lensky Y., Ben-David E., Schindler H.
Title: Ultrastructure of the Spermatozoon of the Mature Drone Honeybee
Affiliations: The Triwaks Bee Research Center, Hebrew University, Faculty of Agriculture, Rehovot, 76100, Israel; Department of Pathology, Beilinson Hospital, Petah-Tikvah, Israel; Department of Animal Reproduction, Agricultural Research Organisation, Bet Dagan, Israel
Authors with affiliations: Lensky, Y., The Triwaks Bee Research Center, Hebrew University, Faculty of Agriculture, Rehovot, 76100, Israel, Department of Pathology, Beilinson Hospital, Petah-Tikvah, Israel, Department of Animal Reproduction, Agricultural Research Organisation, Bet Dagan, Israel; Ben-David, E., The Triwaks Bee Research Center, Hebrew University, Faculty of Agriculture, Rehovot, 76100, Israel, Department of Pathology, Beilinson Hospital, Petah-Tikvah, Israel, Department of Animal Reproduction, Agricultural Research Organisation, Bet Dagan, Israel; Schindler, H., The Triwaks Bee Research Center, Hebrew University, Faculty of Agriculture, Rehovot, 76100, Israel, Department of Pathology, Beilinson Hospital, Petah-Tikvah, Israel, Department of Animal Reproduction, Agricultural Research Organisation, Bet Dagan, Israel
Abstract: Mature spermatozoa of drone honeybees (Apis mellifera), obtained from seminal vesicles, were examined with an electron microscope by negative staining and by serial sectioning. The structure is described, and illustrated in photomicrographs. © 1979 International Bee Research Association.

Authors: FERGUSON A.W., FREE J.B., PICKETT J.A., WINDER M.
Title: Techniques for studying honeybee pheromones involved in clustering, and experiments on the effect of Nasonov and queen pheromones
Affiliations: Rothamsted Experimental Station, Harpenden, Hertfordshire, United Kingdom
Authors with affiliations: FERGUSON, A.W., Rothamsted Experimental Station, Harpenden, Hertfordshire, United Kingdom; FREE, J.B., Rothamsted Experimental Station, Harpenden, Hertfordshire, United Kingdom; PICKETT, J.A., Rothamsted Experimental Station, Harpenden, Hertfordshire, United Kingdom; WINDER, M., Rothamsted Experimental Station, Harpenden, Hertfordshire, United Kingdom
Abstract: ABSTRACT. Techniques for investigating pheromones responsible for clustering in Apis mellifera are described. Stable queenless clusters were formed in response to synthetic Nasonov pheromone mixed with (E)‐9‐oxo‐2‐decenoic acid. This mixture plus the addition of (E)‐9‐hydroxy‐2‐decenoic acid was less potent in initiating cluster formation than it was without this addition, but the clusters once formed sometimes grew larger. Other unknown components from the queen's mandibular glands encouraged cluster formation. Copyright © 1979, Wiley Blackwell. All rights reserved

Title: Honey bee hoarding behaviour: Effects of previous stimulation by empty comb
Affiliations: Bee Breeding and Stock Center Laboratory, Federal Research, Science and Education Administration, Baton Rouge, LA 70808, United States
Authors with affiliations: Rinderer, T.E., Bee Breeding and Stock Center Laboratory, Federal Research, Science and Education Administration, Baton Rouge, LA 70808, United States; Baxter, J.R., Bee Breeding and Stock Center Laboratory, Federal Research, Science and Education Administration, Baton Rouge, LA 70808, United States
Abstract: Hoarding experiments were performed utilizing the transfer of honey bees (Apis mellifera) from cages with large or small amounts of empty honeycomb to cages with equal, greater, or lesser amounts. Results confirmed that empty comb stimulates hoarding. Furthermore, bees that were transferred from a small to a greater amount of comb hoarded significantly more than control bees, indicating that stimulus deprivation followed by stimulus enrichment increases the strength of the hoarding response. © 1979.

Title: Insect pollination in asiatic cotton (gossypium arboreum)
Affiliations: Department of Entomology, College of Agriculture, Punjab Agricultural University, Ludhiana, India
Authors with affiliations: Tanda, A.S., Department of Entomology, College of Agriculture, Punjab Agricultural University, Ludhiana, India; Goyal, N.P., Department of Entomology, College of Agriculture, Punjab Agricultural University, Ludhiana, India
Abstract: During research on pollination of Asiatic cotton (Gossypium arboreum) at Ludhiana, Punjab (India), the most important insect pollinators were found to be the honeybees (Apis mellifera and Apis cerana indica). Foraging behaviour of pollen and nectar gatherers of these honeybees in fields of G. arboreum is described. Intensive bee pollination increased the yield of this species of cotton by 14·2 to 15·8%. There was also a great improvement in the quality of the cotton. Keeping higher populations of these bees in fields of Asiatic cotton is recommended for better returns. © 1979 International Bee Research Association.

Title: Genetics of the Response of the Honeybee to an Alarm Chemical, Isopentyl Acetate
Affiliations: Department of Genetics, The Ohio State University, Columbus, OH, 43210, United States; USDA, AR/SEA, Bee Breeding and Stock Center Laboratory, Route 3, Box 82-B Ben Hur Road, Baton Rouge, LA, 70808, United States
Authors with affiliations: Collins, A.M., Department of Genetics, The Ohio State University, Columbus, OH, 43210, United States, USDA, AR/SEA, Bee Breeding and Stock Center Laboratory, Route 3, Box 82-B Ben Hur Road, Baton Rouge, LA, 70808, United States
Abstract: In laboratory tests, two inbred lines of honeybees (Apis mellifera) different in colony defensive behaviour were shown to differ in their initial general activity level, the time to react to isopentyl acetate, and the initial intensity of the reaction. Evaluation of an F1 and backcrosses to both lines indicated that a more responsive phenotype was dominant to a less responsive phenotype in all three characteristics. The degree of dominance for time to react was estimated as 0.502 and the heritability as 0.681. It was estimated that 2 or 3 loci controlled each of the three components of behaviour. © 1979 International Bee Research Association.

Authors: Sosa B.P., Alagón A.C., Possani L.D., Juliá J.Z.
Title: Comparison of phospholipase activity with direct and indirect lytic effects of animal venoms upon human red cells
Source title: Comparative Biochemistry and Physiology -- Part B: Biochemistry and
Affiliations: Departmento de Neurociencias, Centro de Investigaciones en Fisiología Celular and Departamento de Bioquimica, Facultad de Medicina, Apartado Postal 70-600, Universidad Nacional Autónoma de México, México 20 D.F., México; Instituto Nacional de Higiene, Secretaría de Salubridad y Asistencia, México 17, D.F., Mexico
Authors with affiliations: Sosa, B.P., Departmento de Neurociencias, Centro de Investigaciones en Fisiología Celular and Departamento de Bioquimica, Facultad de Medicina, Apartado Postal 70-600, Universidad Nacional Autónoma de México, México 20 D.F., México; Alagón, A.C., Departmento de Neurociencias, Centro de Investigaciones en Fisiología Celular and Departamento de Bioquimica, Facultad de Medicina, Apartado Postal 70-600, Universidad Nacional Autónoma de México, México 20 D.F., México; Possani, L.D., Departmento de Neurociencias, Centro de Investigaciones en Fisiología Celular and Departamento de Bioquimica, Facultad de Medicina, Apartado Postal 70-600, Universidad Nacional Autónoma de México, México 20 D.F., México; Juliá, J.Z., Instituto Nacional de Higiene, Secretaría de Salubridad y Asistencia, México 17, D.F., Mexico
Abstract: 1. 1. The venoms of 22 species of arthropods, saurians, elapids and crotalids were studied concerning the phospholipase activity and the presence of a direct and an indirect lytic effect upon human red cells. 2. 2. The venoms from the spiders Latrodectus and "tarantula", and the venoms from the scorpions of the genus Centruroides are not haemolytic and do not have phospholipase activity. 3. 3. Only the venoms of Apis mellifera and Naja naja siamensis have shown a direct lytic effect. 4. 4. All other venoms studied have an indirect haemolytic effect associated to a phospholipase activity, but there is indication that other agents might be implicated in the haemolytic processes. © 1979.

Title: POLLINTATION ECOLOGY OF, AND HYBRIDIZATION BETWEEN, ORCHIS CORIOPHORA L. AND O. COLLINA SOL. EX RUSS. (ORCHID ACEAE) IN ISRAEL
Affiliations: Institute of Evolution, Haifa University, Haifa, Israel
Authors with affiliations: DAFNI, A., Institute of Evolution, Haifa University, Haifa, Israel; IVRI, Y., Institute of Evolution, Haifa University, Haifa, Israel
Abstract: The flower of Orchis coriophora L. contains free nectar in the spur and is very fragant; it attracts a large gallery of pollinators mainly Apis mellifera. The capsule production rate is about 90% O. collina Sol. ex Russ. has empty spurs and is scentless; pollinators are scarce and capsule production rate is about 25%. The species are sympatric in some habitats in Israel and create rare hybrids which seem to be the result of common pollinators. It is suggested that each of the two species represents different pollination strategy in the genus. This view and the implications on self and cross pollination are discussed. Copyright © 1979, Wiley Blackwell. All rights reserved

Authors: Radford B.J., Nielsen R.G.H., Rhodes J.W.
Title: Agents of pollination in sunflower crops on the central darling downs, queensland
Authors with affiliations: Radford, B.J.; Nielsen, R.G.H.; Rhodes, J.W.
Abstract: Honeybees (Apis mellifera L.) were the most frequent insect visitors to flowering sunflower heads on the central Darling Downs. Populations in 42 crops during mid-morning in fine weather averaged 65.3 bees per 100 flowering heads. A range of moth species was observed at night but total moth populations in 33 crops between 7 p.m. and 8 p.m. averaged only 3.9 moths per 100 flowering heads. Although Heliothis armigera moths and wind can pollinate sunflowers, insects other than honeybees, and wind, played an insignificant role in crop pollination. © 1979 ASEG.

Title: The pollination of lonicera japonica
Affiliations: Department of Biology, North East London Polytechnic, Romford Road, London, E15 ALZ, United Kingdom
Authors with affiliations: Roberts, A.V., Department of Biology, North East London Polytechnic, Romford Road, London, E15 ALZ, United Kingdom
Abstract: Observations were made on a cultivated specimen of Lonicera japonica growing in South Wales. In this habitat, flowers opened a few hours before dusk. The great majority of flowers were pollinated during the following day, by either Bombus lucorum or B. pascuorum. Tubercled hairs which lined the inside of the corolla tube spread and supported nectar by capillarity. Thus presented nectar was accessible to short-tongued bees, including Apis mellifera. Relatively few bees visited the flowers at midday, and alternative explanations of this are discussed. © 1979 International Bee Research Association.

Authors: Gilliam M., Taber S., III, Argauer R.J.
Title: Degradation of oxytetracycline in sugar syrup and honey stored by honeybee colonies
Affiliations: Agricultural Research, Science and Education Administration, USDA, Carl Hayden Bee Research Center, 2000 E. Allen Road, Tucson, AZ, 85719, United States; Agricultural Research, Science and Education Administration, USDA, Agricultural Environmental Quality Institute, Beltsville, MD, 20705, United States
Authors with affiliations: Gilliam, M., Agricultural Research, Science and Education Administration, USDA, Carl Hayden Bee Research Center, 2000 E. Allen Road, Tucson, AZ, 85719, United States, Agricultural Research, Science and Education Administration, USDA, Agricultural Environmental Quality Institute, Beltsville, MD, 20705, United States; Taber, S., III, Agricultural Research, Science and Education Administration, USDA, Carl Hayden Bee Research Center, 2000 E. Allen Road, Tucson, AZ, 85719, United States, Agricultural Research, Science and Education Administration, USDA, Agricultural Environmental Quality Institute, Beltsville, MD, 20705, United States; Argauer, R.J., Agricultural Research, Science and Education Administration, USDA, Carl Hayden Bee Research Center, 2000 E. Allen Road, Tucson, AZ, 85719, United States, Agricultural Research, Science and Education Administration, USDA, Agricultural Environmental Quality Institute, Beltsville, MD, 20705, United States
Abstract: Degradation of two concentrations of Oxytetracycline hydrochloride (OTC) in medicated syrup and honey in store in colonies of honeybees (Apis mellifera) was followed using a spectrofluorometric technique. The rate of degradation was similar in syrup and honey, and most of the OTC had gone 6–9 weeks after the end of feeding medicated solutions. However, a small residual fluorescence appeared to persist indefinitely; it was presumed to be due to a product of the degradation and might be useful as an indicator of previous medication with OTC. © 1979 International Bee Research Association.

Title: Times spent on various components of foraging activity: Comparison between european and africanized honeybees in brazil
Affiliations: Fisiologia del Comportamiento, Centro de Biofisica, Bioquimica Instituto Venezolano de Investigaciones Cientificas (IVIC), Apartado, Caracas 101, 1827, Venezuela
Authors with affiliations: Núñez, J.A., Fisiologia del Comportamiento, Centro de Biofisica, Bioquimica Instituto Venezolano de Investigaciones Cientificas (IVIC), Apartado, Caracas 101, 1827, Venezuela
Abstract: Foraging behaviour patterns of two races of Apis mellifera were compared: E, of European origin, and A, hybrids descended from African strains. Results showed the following differences: (a) the time interval between inspecting two successive feeders was shorter for A than for E, if searching activity is excluded; (b) the relative endurance (faithfulness) at a patch (group) of feeders of A was about 60% of that of E; (c) when the rate of sugar flow was high, incomplete inspections of feeders were relatively more frequent by A than by E. These differences seem to be related to a higher sensitivity of A than of E to flow changes. Such a difference might help to explain the greater efficiency of A than E as a sugar (nectar) collector. © 1979 International Bee Research Association.

Title: Effects of caffeine and various xanthines on hornets and bees
Affiliations: Department of Physiology and Pharmacology, Sackler School of Medicine, Tel Aviv University, Ramat Aviv, Israel
Authors with affiliations: Ishay, J.S., Department of Physiology and Pharmacology, Sackler School of Medicine, Tel Aviv University, Ramat Aviv, Israel; Paniry, V.A., Department of Physiology and Pharmacology, Sackler School of Medicine, Tel Aviv University, Ramat Aviv, Israel
Abstract: The effect of caffeine was assessed on Vespa orientalis hornets maintained either in sealed breeding boxes or as entire colonies free to forage, and also on Apis mellifera bees within their hives. In a number of instances the hornets were also used to study the effect of various bodily extracts of queen hornets and of the following xanthines: Purine; hypoxanthine; uric acid; theophylline; and theobromine. The studied materials were found to exert an effect on three categories of activities: (1) Motor motility, flight, and construction; (2) sensory response to light (retinal and extraretinal), noise, irritability, orientation; and (3) physiological changes in appetite, copulation, oviposition, hibernation, resistance to cold, and longevity. Up to a point the produced effects were reversible. Throughout the period of experimentation the test insects did not show signs of tolerance or addiction towards caffeine. © 1979 Springer-Verlag.
Author Keywords: Caffeine; Hypoxanthine; Purinergic pheromones; Social insects

Title: Colour patterns of syrphidae
Affiliations: Genetics Department, University of Liverpool, United Kingdom; Department of Biological Sciences, Keele University, Keele, Staffordshire, United Kingdom
Authors with affiliations: Heal, J., Genetics Department, University of Liverpool, United Kingdom, Department of Biological Sciences, Keele University, Keele, Staffordshire, United Kingdom
Abstract: Eristalis tenax is a Batesian mimic of the honeybee Apis mellifera and resembles its model in general form, coloration and flower-visiting behaviour. The abdominal patterns of E. tenax vary from completely dark brown to those in which the abdomen is mainly orange. A major gene locus (termed Ap for abdominal pattern) has been identified with alleles for light and dark colour pattern. Light pattern is dominant, but there is a sex difference in expression such that males tend to have more extensive orange markings. Thus a different division into Light and Dark Phenotype classes is necessary in males and females. Besides the major gene, other sources of variability are important. Both environmental and polygenic factors produce a range of patterns within the two principal categories. © 1979 The Genetical Society of Great Britain.

Title: Nest site selection by the honey bee, Apis mellifera
Affiliations: Museum of Comparative Zoology Laboratories, Harvard University, Cambridge, 02138, Massachusetts, United States; Department of Entomology, Cornell University, Ithaca, 14853, New York, United States
Authors with affiliations: Seeley, T.D., Museum of Comparative Zoology Laboratories, Harvard University, Cambridge, 02138, Massachusetts, United States, Department of Entomology, Cornell University, Ithaca, 14853, New York, United States; Morse, R.A., Museum of Comparative Zoology Laboratories, Harvard University, Cambridge, 02138, Massachusetts, United States, Department of Entomology, Cornell University, Ithaca, 14853, New York, United States
Abstract: 1. Honey bees exhibit preferences in several nest site properties. The following preferences were identified («>» means «preferred to»): nest height, 5>1 m; entrance area, 12.5>75 cm2; entrance position, bottom >top of nest cavity, entrance direction, southward>northward; nest cavity volume, 10<40>100 liters. 2. The data also suggest preferences exist for previously inhabited nest cavities and for nest sites beyond 300 m from the parent colony. 3. Nest sites with high exposure and visibility were occupied more rapidly than sites with low exposure and visibility. However, this difference probably reflects differential ease of nest site discovery rather than a preference for exposed nest sites. 4. No preferences were found in the following variables: entrance shape (slit vs. circle), nest cavity shape (cube vs. tall parallelepiped), cavity draftiness (sound vs. drafty), and cavity dryness (wet vs. dry). Cavity draftiness and dryness are probably important to bees, but because bees can seal and waterproof their nests, they may be less demanding about these two nest site variables than about those they cannot modify. 5. The complex process of nest site selection apparently benefits a honey bee colony in several ways, including facilitation of colony defense and hygiene, simplification of nest construction and microclimate control, and reduction of foraging competition with the parent colony. © 1978 Masson.

Title: Identification of juvenile horm one 3 as the only JH hom olog in all developmental stages of the honey bee
Source title: Zeitschrift fur Naturforschung - Section C Journal of Biosciences
Affiliations: Max-Planck-Institut für Biochemie, Martinsried bei München, Germany
Authors with affiliations: Hagenguth, H., Max-Planck-Institut für Biochemie, Martinsried bei München, Germany; Rembold, H., Max-Planck-Institut für Biochemie, Martinsried bei München, Germany
Abstract: Total extracts from worker larvae, pupae, and adults of the honey bee were analyzed for their juvenile hormone contents. Using the 10-(heptafluorobutyrate)-ll-methoxy derivative, the hormone was isolated in yields of 20 — 50% in nanogram quantities as calculated from isotope dilution and from gas chromatography with electron capture detection. The procedure is sensitive enough to isolate the juvenile hormone out of 1 — 4 grams insect material for qualitative and quantitative analysis. Only juvenile hormone 3 (methyl 10.11-epoxy-2-trans, 6-trans-farnesoate) could be detected as the predominant hormone homolog of all the three developmental stages. Juvenile hormone 1 (methyl 3.11-dimethyl-10.11-cis-epoxy-7-ethyl-2-trans, 6-trans-tridecadienoate) could, if at all, only be identified in trace amounts, and juvenile hormone 2 was completely absent in all stages. This first systematic analysis of a hymenopteran insect shows a modulation of JH3 titre between zero and 2 ng per gram body weight during imaginal development and a rather constant JH3 titre near 10 ng per gram in the adult. © 1978, Walter de Gruyter. All rights reserved.
Author Keywords: Apis mellifera; Honey Bee; Juvenile Hormone 3

Title: Changes in chemical and mechanical properties of honeybee (Apis mellifera adansonii L.) cuticle during development
Affiliations: Department of Physiology, University of the Witwatersrand, Johannesburg, South Africa
Authors with affiliations: Thompson, P.R., Department of Physiology, University of the Witwatersrand, Johannesburg, South Africa; Hepburn, H.R., Department of Physiology, University of the Witwatersrand, Johannesburg, South Africa
Abstract: 1. The non-extractability of cuticular proteins in formamide and sodium hydroxide, and the elastic modulus, breaking stress, relative stiffness and breaking strain of abdominal cuticle from different developmental stages of adult worker honeybees (Apis mellifera adansonii L.) were examined as a function of developmental age. 2. All of these properties were found to be age dependent. 3. The mechanical properties varied in direct proportion to the amount of sodium hydroxide non-extractable protein, and hence the degree of matrix stabilization. © 1978 Springer-Verlag.

Title: The reproductive biology of Nelumbo pentapetala (Nelumbonaceae) on the Upper Mississippi River. II. The insects associated with the transfer of pollen
Affiliations: Department of Biology, University of Wisconsin-La Crosse, La Crosse, 54601, WI, United States
Authors with affiliations: Sohmer, S.H., Department of Biology, University of Wisconsin-La Crosse, La Crosse, 54601, WI, United States; Sefton, D.F., Department of Biology, University of Wisconsin-La Crosse, La Crosse, 54601, WI, United States
Abstract: An in-depth study of the insects associated with the transfer of pollen in the American lotus was undertaken in a selected population on the Upper Mississippi River near La Crosse, Wisconsin. The study showed that members of the Coleoptera (Coleomegilla fascilabris Malsant, Diabrotica unidecimpunctata howardi Barber, D. virgifera Lec.), Diptera (Eristalis tenax (L.), Parhelophilus laetus (Locw)) and Hymenoptera (Agapostemon radiatus (Say), Apis mellifera L., Dialictus sp., Lasioglossum zonulum (Smith)) were the principal visitors and most obvious vectors in pollination. Although there are features of the flowers of the lotus that indicate cantharophily, such as the diurnal movements of the tepals and the food bodies of the anthers, in the area of study no special beetle-pollination system, as reported for such genera as Magnolia and Nuphar, appears to occur. © 1978 The New York Botanical Garden.

Authors: Veith H.J., Weiss J., Koeniger N.
Title: A new alarm pheromone (2-decen-1-yl-acetate) isolated from the stings of Apis dorsata and Apis florea (Hymenoptera: Apidae)
Affiliations: Institut für Organische Chemie und Biochemie der Technischen Hochschule, Darmstadt, D-6100, Germany; Institut für Bienenkunde an der Universität Frankfurt, Oberursel/Ts., D-6370, Germany
Authors with affiliations: Veith, H.J., Institut für Organische Chemie und Biochemie der Technischen Hochschule, Darmstadt, D-6100, Germany; Weiss, J., Institut für Organische Chemie und Biochemie der Technischen Hochschule, Darmstadt, D-6100, Germany, Institut für Bienenkunde an der Universität Frankfurt, Oberursel/Ts., D-6370, Germany; Koeniger, N., Institut für Organische Chemie und Biochemie der Technischen Hochschule, Darmstadt, D-6100, Germany, Institut für Bienenkunde an der Universität Frankfurt, Oberursel/Ts., D-6370, Germany
Abstract: From sting extracts of Apis dorsata and A. florea, a substance was isolated which is active in alarm behaviour of both of these species but not of A. mellifera and A. cerana. The active substance was identified as 2-decen-1-yl-acetate. © 1978 Birkhäuser Verlag.

Title: Laboratory studies on the contact toxicity and activity in soil of four pyrethroid insecticides1
Affiliations: Research Institute, Agriculture Canada, London, Ontario N6A 5B7, Kiribati
Authors with affiliations: Harris, C.R., Research Institute, Agriculture Canada, London, Ontario N6A 5B7, Kiribati; Turnbull, S.A., Research Institute, Agriculture Canada, London, Ontario N6A 5B7, Kiribati
Abstract: The spectrum of contact toxicity and activity in soil of four pyrethroid insecticides was assessed in the laboratory. Pyrethroids tested were: FMC 33297 (3-phenoxybenzyl (±)-3-(2, 2-dichlorovinyl)-2,2-dimethylcyclopropanecarboxylate); Shell WL 41706 (alpha-cyano-3 phenoxybenzyl 2,2,3,3-tetramethylcyclopropanecarboxylate); Shell WL 43467 (alpha-cyano-3-phenoxybenzyl 2-(2,2-dichlorovinyl)-3,3-dimethylcyclopropane-l-carboxylate); and Shell WL 43775 (alpha-cyano-3-phenoxybenzyl-2-(4-chlorophenyl)-3-methyl-1-butyrate). Chlorpyrifos and carbofuran, two broad spectrum contact and soil insecticides were included for comparative purposes. Spectrum of contact toxicity was determined using 24-48 h nymphs of the common field cricket, Acheta pennsylvanicus (Burmeister), 24-48 h onion maggot adults, Hylemya antigua (Meigen), 3rd instar darksided cutworms, Euxoa messoria (Harris), northern com rootworm adults, Diabrotica longicornis (Say), and honeybees, Apis mellifera L. Crickets were used to assess insecticidal activity in soil relative to soil moisture, type, and temperature. The pyrethroids were effective contact insecticides comparable in toxicity and spectrum of activity to chlorpyrifos and carbofuran. They were particularly toxic to the darksided cutworm. They were less effective in mineral soil than chlorpyrifos. WL 43467 showed activity in mineral soil close to that of carbofuran, while the other pyrethroids were less active. Activity in soil was influenced by soil moisture and type. In contrast to the standard insecticides the pyrethroids generally showed a negative temperature coefficient of toxicity in soil. © 1978, Entomological Society of Canada. All rights reserved.

Authors: Gilliam M., Taber III S., Argauer R.J.
Title: Degradation of oxytetracycline in medicated sucrose and honey stored by caged honey bees, Apis mellifera

Title: Bacteria belonging to the genus Bacillus isolated from selected organs of queen honey bees, Apis mellifera
Affiliations: U. S. Department, Agriculture Agricultural Research Service Bee Research Laboratory, 2000 E. Allen Road, Tucson, AZ 85719, United States

Title: Histological development of cuticle in the worker Honeybee, apis mellifera adansonii
Affiliations: Department of Physiology, University of the Witwatersrand, Johannesburg, South Africa
Authors with affiliations: Thompson, P.R., Department of Physiology, University of the Witwatersrand, Johannesburg, South Africa
Abstract: The histological development of cuticle from adult worker honeybees from South Africa (Apis mellifera adansonii) was investigated. In order to obtain large numbers of individuals of known age from sealed cells, a grouping system was devised and the temporal limits of the groups determined. The terminology applied to the different stages in the life cycle was also examined, and the pupal stage was found to be much shorter, and the adult stage much longer, than previously reported in the literature on Apis mellifera. Cuticle of the frons and scutum were similar in their patterns of differentiation and thickness, but showed certain differences from cuticle of the abdominal tergites. In general however, the patterns of differentiation of cuticle from all three regions are similar to those found in many insectts. © 1978 International Bee Research Association.

Title: Effect of ZR 515 on honey bee, Apis mellifera L.
Affiliations: Plant Protection Department, College of Agriculture, Assiut University, Assiut, Egypt
Authors with affiliations: Hussein, M.H., Plant Protection Department, College of Agriculture, Assiut University, Assiut, Egypt; Abdel‐Aal, Y.A.I., Plant Protection Department, College of Agriculture, Assiut University, Assiut, Egypt
Abstract: Synthetic juvenile hormone analogue, ZR 515 (isopropyl‐11‐methoxy‐3,7,11‐trimethyl‐2,4‐dodecadienoate) was topically applied to 3‐ and 5‐day old worker honey bee larvae in the hive. About 55 to 70% of the hormone‐treated larvae were removed from their brood cells one day after treatment. Formation of unusual shapes of abdomen, wings and wax glands were a consequence of hormone treatment. Malformed adults were 13 to 38.5% of the emerged adults. These deformities were concentration dependent and were much pronounced with the younger larvae. Zur Wirkung des Hormonoids ZR 515 auf die Honigbiene Apis mellifera L. Nach topicaler Applikation des synthetischen Juvenilhormon‐Analogons ZR 515 (isopropyl‐11‐methoxy‐3,7,11‐trimethyl‐2,4‐dodecadienoate) bei 3 und 5 Tage alten Arbeitsbienen‐Larven im Stock traten bei 13 bis 38,5% der daraus hervorgehenden Bienen Deformierungen des Abdomens, der Flügel und Wachsdrüsen auf. Sie waren von der Konzentration des Wirkstoffs abhängig und am ausgeprägtesten nach Behandlung jüngerer Larven. 1978 Blackwell Verlag GmbH

Authors: Conner W.E., Wilkinson C.F., Morse R.A.
Title: Penetration of insecticides through the foregut of the honeybee (Apis mellifera L.)
Affiliations: Section of Neurobiology and Behavior, Cornell University, Ithaca, NY 14853, United States; Department of Entomology, Cornell University, Ithaca, NY 14853, United States
Authors with affiliations: Conner, W.E., Section of Neurobiology and Behavior, Cornell University, Ithaca, NY 14853, United States; Wilkinson, C.F., Department of Entomology, Cornell University, Ithaca, NY 14853, United States; Morse, R.A., Department of Entomology, Cornell University, Ithaca, NY 14853, United States
Abstract: The rates of penetration of 14C-labeled insecticides (parathion, carbaryl, and dieldrin) through the foregut of the honeybee (Apis mellifera L.) were measured in vitro and in vivo. Uptake of the insecticides from the lumen of the foregut into foregut tissue was directly proportional to insecticide lipophilicity, but penetration through the foregut was not. Of the three insecticides studied, parathion appeared to possess the optimal physicochemical characteristics required for penetration. The uptake of carbaryl and release of dieldrin by the foregut tissues may limit their respective penetration rates. Insecticide penetration was found to be inversely proportional to the sucrose concentration in the lumen of the foregut in both in vitro and in vivo studies. The oral toxicity of carbaryl showed a similar dependence on the sucrose concentration of the solution in which the insecticide was fed. The data presented indicate that the honeybee foregut is permeable to lipophilic compounds and strongly suggest that this permeability may contribute substantially to the toxicity of orally ingested insecticides in this insect. © 1978.

Title: Venom replenishment, as indicated by histamine, in honey bee (Apis mellifera) venom
Affiliations: Department of Zoology, University of Western Ontario, London, Ont., Canada
Authors with affiliations: Owen, M.D., Department of Zoology, University of Western Ontario, London, Ont., Canada
Abstract: Venom resynthesis, as indicated by histamine, has been investigated in the venom system of worker honey bees. After depletion of the venom contained in the venom reservoir, by electrical "milking", histamine resynthesis was most active between 18 and 24 hr after "milking". The ability of a bee to resynthesise histamine is age dependent. Young bees show some resynthetic ability, two week old bees show maximal ability to replace histamine. This capability is gradually lost as bees age and is virtually absent in 40 day old bees. © 1978.

Title: Fluorescent pigment and pentane production by lipid peroxidation in honey bees, Apis Mellifera
Affiliations: Department of Entomology, Cornell University, Ithaca, NY 14853, United States; Department of Food Science and Technology, University of California, Davis, CA 95616, United States
Authors with affiliations: Young, R.G., Department of Entomology, Cornell University, Ithaca, NY 14853, United States; Tappel, A.L., Department of Food Science and Technology, University of California, Davis, CA 95616, United States
Abstract: The concentration of fluorescent pigment associated with the oxidation of polyunsaturated lipids is significantly higher in old worker bees than in newly emerged worker adults. Pentane and hexane are produced by bees, presumably by decomposition of lipid hydroperoxides formed by peroxidation of membrane lipids. Protection against lipid peroxidation by vitamin E and glutathione peroxidase appears to be minimal in bees. © 1978.

Title: Occurrence of a new type of mosaicism in Apis mellifera
Affiliations: Area de Genética, Instituto de Biociências de Rio Claro, UNESP, Rio Claro, 13 500, S.P., Brazil; Departamento de Genética, Faculdade de Medicina de Ribeirão Preto, USP, Ribeirão Preto, 14 100, S.P., Brazil
Authors with affiliations: Stort, A.C., Area de Genética, Instituto de Biociências de Rio Claro, UNESP, Rio Claro, 13 500, S.P., Brazil, Departamento de Genética, Faculdade de Medicina de Ribeirão Preto, USP, Ribeirão Preto, 14 100, S.P., Brazil; Soares, A.E., Area de Genética, Instituto de Biociências de Rio Claro, UNESP, Rio Claro, 13 500, S.P., Brazil, Departamento de Genética, Faculdade de Medicina de Ribeirão Preto, USP, Ribeirão Preto, 14 100, S.P., Brazil
Abstract: A mixture of tissue with male and female olfactory plates (sensilla placodea) was observed in the antennal segments number 8, 9 and 10 of a gynandromorphic honeybee obtained by radiation from a Co60 source. © 1978 Birkhäuser Verlag.

Title: The Acute Toxicity of Unformolated Pesticides to Worker Honey Bees (Apis mellifera L.)
Affiliations: Rothamsted Experimental Station, Harpenden, Hertfordshire, United Kingdom
Authors with affiliations: STEVENSON, J.H., Rothamsted Experimental Station, Harpenden, Hertfordshire, United Kingdom
Abstract: Results obtained in the laboratory at Rothamsted from 1964 to 1977 on the contact and oral toxicities of 60 pesticides to worker honey bees are summarised. Copyright © 1978, Wiley Blackwell. All rights reserved

Authors: Gunst K.W., Hilldrup J.L., Llewellyn G.C.
Title: Aflatoxin production on apis mellifera artificially inoculated with aspergillus flavus and aspergillus parasiticus
Affiliations: Department of Biology, Virginia Commonwealth University, Richmond, VA, 23284, United States
Authors with affiliations: Gunst, K.W., Department of Biology, Virginia Commonwealth University, Richmond, VA, 23284, United States; Hilldrup, J.L., Department of Biology, Virginia Commonwealth University, Richmond, VA, 23284, United States; Llewellyn, G.C., Department of Biology, Virginia Commonwealth University, Richmond, VA, 23284, United States
Abstract: Larval and adult worker honeybees, and brood comb, were inoculated artificially with known toxigenic strains of the two Aspergillus species. Toxins were produced by both species on all media, but the amounts varied widely. The total amounts of anatoxin were substantially less than those on agricultural substrates, but still sufficient to warrant further studies. © 1978 International Bee Research Association.

Title: Life history strategy of the honey bee, Apis mellifera
Affiliations: Museum of Comparative Zoology Laboratories, Harvard University, Cambridge, 02138, MA, United States
Authors with affiliations: Seeley, T.D., Museum of Comparative Zoology Laboratories, Harvard University, Cambridge, 02138, MA, United States
Abstract: The feral honey bee queens (colonies) of central New York State (USA) show a K-type life history strategy. Their demographic characteristics include low early life mortality, low reproductive rate, long lifespan, high population stability and repeated reproductions. Identifying the life history strategy of these bees reveals the general pattern of selection for competitive ability, rather than productivity, which has shaped their societies. Selection for competitive power explains the adaptiveness (compared with alternatives found in many other insect societies) of the large perennial colonies, infrequent but expensive offspring, and efficient foraging which characterize the social organization of these bees. © 1978 Springer-Verlag.

Title: Recent isolations of Bacillus pulvifaciens from powdery scales of honey bee, Apis mellifera, larvae
Affiliations: U. S. Department, Agriculture Agricultural Research Service Bee Research Laboratory, 2000 E. Allen Road, Tucson, AZ 85719, United States
Authors with affiliations: Gilliam, M., U. S. Department, Agriculture Agricultural Research Service Bee Research Laboratory, 2000 E. Allen Road, Tucson, AZ 85719, United States; Dunham, D.R., U. S. Department, Agriculture Agricultural Research Service Bee Research Laboratory, 2000 E. Allen Road, Tucson, AZ 85719, United States
Abstract: [No abstract available]
Author Keywords: Bacillus pulvifaciens; honey bee; powdery scale disease

Title: A filamentous virus of the honey bee
Affiliations: Bioenvironmental Bee Laboratory, Federal Research Science and Education Administration, U. S. Department of Agriculture, Beltsville, MD 20705, United States
Authors with affiliations: Clark, T.B., Bioenvironmental Bee Laboratory, Federal Research Science and Education Administration, U. S. Department of Agriculture, Beltsville, MD 20705, United States
Abstract: A common and widespread disease of honey bees, Apis mellifera, is caused by an unoccluded, Feulgen-positive, filamentous nuclear virus. Ovoid viral particles seen in diseased bee hemolymph consisted of a folded nucleocapsid within a viral envelope and were 0.40 by 0.10 μm. Virions with unfolded nucleocapsids were about 3060 by 60 nm. The disease was transmissible to bees both per os and by injection, but efforts to infect oriental cockroaches, Blatta orientalis, and the greater wax moth, Galleria mellonella, failed. The disease is apparently the same as that described as a rickettsial disease of European bees. © 1978.
Author Keywords: Apis mellifera; bee rickettsiosis, transmission of; Blatta orientalis; Galleria mellonella; insect fat tissue, insect ovarian tissue; virus

Title: Comparative biometrical investigation on diploid drones of the honeybee III. The abdomen, and weight
Affiliations: Departmento de Genetica, Faculdade de Mediana, Univetsidade de São Paulo, Ribeirão Preto, SP, Brazil; Bee Division, Agricultural University, Warszawa, Ursynów, Poland
Authors with affiliations: Woyke, J., Departmento de Genetica, Faculdade de Mediana, Univetsidade de São Paulo, Ribeirão Preto, SP, Brazil, Bee Division, Agricultural University, Warszawa, Ursynów, Poland
Abstract: A total of 9268 measurements were made on abdominal segments 4 and 5 of 271 diploid and 264 haploid drones. 109 queens and 236 workers, originating from 12 queens of Apis mellifera adansonii, Apis mellifera ligustica and some crosses. Also 518 diploid and haploid drones were weighed individually. Abdominal segments of diploid drones were larger than those of haploids. Out of 12 characters studied, 4 were smaller in the females, and as many as 8 were larger in at least one female caste, than those in the haploid drones. Therefore the size of certain abdominal parts of diploid drones showed different relations from those of haploids andfemales. Foursegment sizes showed super-male character and out of 8 others, 4 showed caste character, 2 intersex, 1 female and 1 super-female character. The pure race diploid drones were about 25% heavier than the haploids, showing a super-male character. © 1978 International Bee Research Association.

Title: Notes on the driedfruit mite carpoglyphus lactis (Acarina: Carpoglyphidae) infesting honeybee combs
Affiliations: Systematic Entomology Laboratory, IIBIII, Agricultural Research Service, USDA, Beltsville, MD, 20705, United States; New York State Museum and Science Service, Albany, NY, 12234, United States
Authors with affiliations: Baker, E.W., Systematic Entomology Laboratory, IIBIII, Agricultural Research Service, USDA, Beltsville, MD, 20705, United States, New York State Museum and Science Service, Albany, NY, 12234, United States; Delfinado, M.D., Systematic Entomology Laboratory, IIBIII, Agricultural Research Service, USDA, Beltsville, MD, 20705, United States, New York State Museum and Science Service, Albany, NY, 12234, United States
Abstract: This paper is part of a continuing report of the mites associated with honeybees Apis mellifera and A. cerana. In earlier papers (Delfinado & Baker, 161, 1974a, 1974b; Baker & Delfinado, 1976), we have reported and discussed the following bee mites: Tropilaelaps clareae Delfinado & Baker, Varroa jacobsoni Oudemans, Euvarroa sinhai Delfinado & Baker, Mellitiphis alvearius (Berlese), and Neocypholaelaps indica Evans. An acaroid mite infesting honeybee combs is now reported, with notes on its identification, habitat and distribution. © 1978 International Bee Research Association.

Title: Karyological study of honeybee
Affiliations: Biology Laboratory, Daitobunka University High School, Tokyo, Japan; Department of Biology, Yokohama City University, Yokohama, Japan
Authors with affiliations: Hoshiba, H., Biology Laboratory, Daitobunka University High School, Tokyo, Japan; Kusanagi, A., Department of Biology, Yokohama City University, Yokohama, Japan
Abstract: The karyotype of Apis mellifera is illustrated and described, using mitotic chromosomes. The chromosome complement in the haploid male (n 16) could be divided into the two groups: 8 metacentrics and 8 submetacentrics. The longest metaphase chromosome was about 4·3μm long, and the shortest 1·3 μ.m, after in vitro pretreatment with colchicine. The secondary constriction was clearly seen in the longest chromosome. © 1978 International Bee Research Association.

Authors: GAULDIE J., HANSON J.M., SHIPOLINI R.A., VERNON C.A.
Title: The Structures of Some Peptides from Bee Venom
Affiliations: Christopher lngold Laboratories, Department of Chemistry, University College London, 20 Gordon Street, London, WCIH OAJ, United Kingdom
Authors with affiliations: GAULDIE, J., Christopher lngold Laboratories, Department of Chemistry, University College London, 20 Gordon Street, London, WCIH OAJ, United Kingdom; HANSON, J.M., Christopher lngold Laboratories, Department of Chemistry, University College London, 20 Gordon Street, London, WCIH OAJ, United Kingdom; SHIPOLINI, R.A., Christopher lngold Laboratories, Department of Chemistry, University College London, 20 Gordon Street, London, WCIH OAJ, United Kingdom; VERNON, C.A., Christopher lngold Laboratories, Department of Chemistry, University College London, 20 Gordon Street, London, WCIH OAJ, United Kingdom
Abstract: The sequences are given of two peptides (secapin and melittin F) whose isolation from the venom of the common European honey bee (Apis mellifera) has previously been described [Gauldie et al. (1976) Eur. J. Biochem. 61, 369–376]. Some structural studies on the known peptide 401 (MCD peptide) are described. The positions of the two disulphide bridges in peptide 401 have been determined by (an essentially) novel method. Copyright © 1978, Wiley Blackwell. All rights reserved

Title: Proline in honey: An osmoregulatory hypothesis
Affiliations: Agricultural Research Council, Food Research Institute, Colney Lane, Norwich, NR4 7UA, United Kingdom
Authors with affiliations: Davies, A.M.C., Agricultural Research Council, Food Research Institute, Colney Lane, Norwich, NR4 7UA, United Kingdom
Abstract: Previously published data are used to support a proposal that the hypopharyngeal glands of the worker honeybee (Apis mellifera) contain a large concentration of proline, which counterbalances the osmotic pressure of nectar and facilitates the transfer of invertase from the glands to the nectar. The hypothesis offers an alternative explanation to that put forward by other authors, for the addition of proline by the bees during the processing of nectar into honey. © 1978 International Bee Research Association.

Title: Influence of photoperiod on the behaviour and brood-rearing activities of honeybees in a flight room
Affiliations: Institut für Bienenkunde, Oberursel, Germany
Authors with affiliations: Kefuss, J.A., Institut für Bienenkunde, Oberursel, Germany
Abstract: The effects of increasing and decreasing photoperiods on the honeybee Apis mellifera were studied under flight-room conditions. Brood was reared under both long-day and short-day photoperiods, indicating that there is no critical day length that has to be attained before brood rearing can begin. Honeybees reacted to increasing photoperiods by rearing more brood, and to decreasing photoperiods by rearing less brood, under both long-day and short-day photoperiods. Neither the oscillator nor the hour-glass model proposed by other authors explains the brood-rearing responses that were observed to the photoperiods used. © 1978 International Bee Research Association.

Title: Mineral requirements for brood-rearing by honeybees fed a synthetic diet
Affiliations: Bioenvironmental Bee Laboratory, Federal Research Science and Administration, USDA, Beltsville, MD, 20705, United States
Authors with affiliations: Herbert, E.W., Jr., Bioenvironmental Bee Laboratory, Federal Research Science and Administration, USDA, Beltsville, MD, 20705, United States; Shimanuki, H., Bioenvironmental Bee Laboratory, Federal Research Science and Administration, USDA, Beltsville, MD, 20705, United States
Abstract: Honeybees, Apis mellifera, fed a chemically defined diet containing 10 essential and 8 non-essential amino acids, and 10 water-soluble vitamins, were able to rear brood for 10 weeks. When this diet was improved by the addition of pollen ash, bees fed diets containing 1% ash reared more brood than bees fed only the synthetic diet or bees fed 0-5% or 2-8% pollen ash. Quantitative analysis by atomic absorption spectrophotometry revealed that pollen ash contained more potassium and less calcium and sodium than a commercial salt mixture. © 1978 International Bee Research Association.

Title: The role of the glial cells in the maintenance of the ionic environment of the photoreceptors of the retina of the drone [LE ROLE DES CELLULES GLIALES DANS LE MAINTIEN DE L'ENVIRONNEMENT IONIQUE DES PHOTORECEPTEURS DE LA RETINE DU FAUX-BOURDON]
Affiliations: Lab. Ophtalmol. Exp., Geneve, Switzerland
Authors with affiliations: Tsacopoulos, M., Lab. Ophtalmol. Exp., Geneve, Switzerland; Coles, J.A., Lab. Ophtalmol. Exp., Geneve, Switzerland
Abstract: A double-barrelled potassium sensitive micro-electrode was used to record electrical potentials and K+ activities in the retina of the drone Apis Mellifera during stimulation with trains of flashes, 1 per sec, intense enough to produce receptor potentials of near maximal amplitude. During the stimulation photoreceptors lose about 25% of their intracellular potassium concentration. During stimulation the potassium activity in the extracellular space increased transitorily up to 20 mM and then fell to a plateau. By this time the potassium concentration increased by about 20% in the glial cells. These results suggest that the glial cells may participate in the regulation of K+ activity in the extracellular space. The increase of potassium activity in the glial cells may be a stimulus for activation of cellular metabolism.

Title: Comparative Biometrical Investigation on Diploid Drones of the Honeybee II. The Thorax
Affiliations: Departmento de Genetica, Faculdade de Mediana, Universidade de São Paulo, Ribeirão Pre to, SP, Brazil; Bee Division, Agricultural University, Warszawa, Ursynów, Poland
Authors with affiliations: Woyke, J., Departmento de Genetica, Faculdade de Mediana, Universidade de São Paulo, Ribeirão Pre to, SP, Brazil, Bee Division, Agricultural University, Warszawa, Ursynów, Poland
Abstract: A total of 10 758 measurements were made on the thorax and its appendages of 269 haploid and 295 diploid drones, 109 queens, and 248 workers. All individuals originated from 12 queens of Apis mellifera ligustica, A.m. adansonii, their backcrosses and some hybrids. The structures measured were mostly larger in diploid than in haploid drones. The number of bristles on the forewing and the number of hooks on the hindwing were lower in diploids, and the cubital index was similar in the two types of drone. The relationships for the same characters in queens and workers were different; diploid drone characters were variously super-male, male or female, or caste characters. © 1978 International Bee Research Association.

Authors: PAMILO P., VARVIO‐AHO S.‐L., PEKKARINEN A.
Title: Low enzyme gene variability in Hymenoptera as a consequence of haplodiploidy
Affiliations: Departments of Genetics and Zoology, Tvärminne Zoological Station, University of Helsinki, Finland
Authors with affiliations: PAMILO, P., Departments of Genetics and Zoology, Tvärminne Zoological Station, University of Helsinki, Finland; VARVIO‐AHO, S.‐L., Departments of Genetics and Zoology, Tvärminne Zoological Station, University of Helsinki, Finland; PEKKARINEN, A., Departments of Genetics and Zoology, Tvärminne Zoological Station, University of Helsinki, Finland
Abstract: Enzyme gene variability in fifteen hymenopteran species, mainly bees, has been studied. The species were Apis mellifera L., six Bombus species, Macropis labiata F., Colletes succincta L., three Andrena species, Vespula vulgaris L., Mimesa equestris F. and Pontania vesicator Bremi. The hymenopteran species reproduce by arrhenotokous parthenogenesis so that the males are haploid and the females are diploid. The present results, as also the earlier studies, show that the number of polymorphic loci and the amount of heterozygosity are smaller in haplodiploid than in diploid insect populations. This is in accordance with theoretical expectations, as both deterministic selection models and the neutral hypothesis predict that genic variability is reduced in haplodiploid populations. The average heterozygosity per locus is lower in eusocial than in solitary species. The difference is not statistically significant, but it may indicate that either small effective population sizes or stable conditions in the nests of eusocial species affect genic variation. © 1978 Mendelian Society of Lund

Title: Vibration of queen cells by worker honeybees and its relation to the issue of swarms with Virgin Queens
Affiliations: Department of Entomology, University of Natal, Pietermaritzburg, South Africa; Bee Research Laboratory, Plant Protection Research Institute, Private Bag Xl34, Pretoria 0001, South Africa
Authors with affiliations: Fletcher, D.J.C., Department of Entomology, University of Natal, Pietermaritzburg, South Africa, Bee Research Laboratory, Plant Protection Research Institute, Private Bag Xl34, Pretoria 0001, South Africa
Abstract: In 4 honeybee colonies (Apis mellifera adansonii) where the workers did not perform vibratory dances on emergency queen cells, the first queen to emerge attacked the other queen cells. The queens were not themselves vibrated until they had destroyed these cells, and they did not pipe. On average they matured in 7 days 2 h after their cells were sealed. In 3 other colonies the workers vibrated emergency queen cells, and this behaviour was associated with imprisonment of most of the queens, piping by one of the first queens to emerge, and swarming. Typically, the number of vibratory dances performed rose to a peak on all cells at about the time the first queens matured. The number then dropped sharply when a free queen began to pipe, but rose to a new peak in the absence of piping when that queen left the hive with a swarm. Some of the workers vibrated individual cells at an increased rate while other workers were resealing cuts made in the cell caps by the queens in them. It was concluded that both vibratory dances and queen piping play a role in the imprisonment of queens through inhibition, although other mechanisms were also involved. Vibration of queen cells and of workers on them, as well as of free virgin queens, also appeared to protect the cells from attack. If virgin queens were vibrated in the presence of imprisoned queens, they piped and were sometimes chased by the workers. On the other hand virgin queens that were not vibrated did not pipe and remained quietly in the lower part of the hive. Piping may therefore be interpreted as a “displacement activity” caused by conflicting activating and inhibiting stimuli. The three colonies in which queen cells were vibrated produced 4 swarms, 2 of which were accompanied by more than one virgin queen. Some of the supernumerary queens emerged before swarming, and others emerged while the bees were leaving the hive. The data presented are all consistent with the “inhibition hypothesis” concerning the function of vibratory dances. © 1978 International Bee Research Association.

Title: Biocenosis del tamarugo (Prosopis tamarugo Philippi) con especial referenda de los artrópodos fitófagos y sus enemigos naturales
Authors with affiliations: Koch, C.K.; Campos, L.S.
Abstract: The biocoenosis of the Tamarugo tree (Prosopis tamarugo Philippi) with special regard to the phytophagous Arthropods and their antagonists The natural community of the “Pampa del Tamarugal” in the desert of northern Chile is described with emphasis on the trophic natural chain of the tamarugo (Prosopis tamarugo Philippi) and the main changes which took place (i.e. afforestation and intensive sheep tenure) in order to convey the energy of the ecosystem to human utilization. The outstanding morphological characteristics, biology and habits of 12 phytophagous arthropods associated with twigs, foliage, flowers and pods of the tamarugo are described and its natural enemies reported. Some of these species are endemic to the Tamarugal. Among the principal insect species are 3 Lepidoptera: Leptotes trigemmatus Butler, Cryptophlebia carpophagoides Clarke and Ithome sp. which are able to destroy 75% of the flowers, pods and seeds in certain years, and constitute the principal entomological problem. Solitary bees (Centris mixta Friese) and the introduced Apis mellifera are important factors in regard to the economical exploitation of the tamarugo as a “permanent tree crop” in one of the extreme desert areas of the world. Se describe la comunidad existente en la Pampa del Tamarugal en el desierto del norte de Chile, esquematizando el funcionamiento de la cadena trófica natural del tamarugo (Prosopis tamarugo Philippi) y los principales cambios realizados para canalizar la energía del ecosistema hacia el consumo humano. En la cadena trófica antropogénica el incremento de la productividad neta del ecosistema está basado en la (re)forestación de los salares con tamarugos y el aprovechamiento del recurso forrajero (frutos y hojarasca) con ovinos como consumidores primarios. Se describen los aspectos más relevantes sobre la distribución, morfología, biología y hábitos de 12 artrópodos fitófagos ‐ algunos endémicos de la zona ‐ asociados al follaje, ramillas, flores y frutos, señalando además los principales enemigos naturales encontrados. Entre las especies de mayor potencial reproductivo se destacan 3 lepidópteros: la mariposa violeta (Leptotes trigemmatus Butler), la polilla del fruto (Cryptophlebia carpophagoides Clarke) y la polillita de la flor (Ithome sp.) quienes son capaces de destruir, de acuerdo con los años, hasta un 75% de las inflorescencias y legumbres y constituyen el principal problema en el aprovechamiento económico del tamarugo como productor primario. Los polinizadores nativos de las diferentes especies de Prosopis de la zona, particularmente la abeja solitaria Centris mixta Friese y la abeja melífera Apis mellifica introducida del centro del país, representan un factor importante en la utilización del tamarugo como “cultivo permanente” en una de las regiones desérticas más extremas del mundo. Die Biozönose des Tamarugo Prosopis tamarugo (Philippi) unter besonderer Berücksichtigung der phytophagen Arthropoden und deren natürliche Feinde Die als „Pampa del Tamarugal” bekannte Biozönose in der nordchilenischen Wüste wird beschrieben. In schematischer Form werden die natürliche Nahrungskette des Prosopis tamarugo und die wichtigsten Änderungen, um die Energie des Ökosystems für den Menschen nutzbar zu machen, aufgezeigt. Die Produktivitätssteigerung in der anthropogenen Nahrungskette basiert auf der Wiederaufforstung bzw. Aufforstung der Salzpfannen („Salares”) mit Tamarugos und der Verwertung der Früchte und des Laubwerks durch Schafherden als erste Konsumenten. Die wichtigsten Eigenschaften, Verbreitung, Morphologie, Biologie und Ökologie von 12 phytophagen Arthropoden ‐ einige davon endemisch ‐ die auf den Zweigen, dem Laubwerk, den Blüten und Hülsen des Tamarugo leben und deren natürliche Feinde werden dargestellt. Unter den bedeutendsten Insektenarten befinden sich 3 Lepidoptera: Leptotes trigemmatus Butler, Cryptophlebia carpophagoides Clarke und ein kleiner Schmetterling der Gattung Ithome. In manchen Jahren zerstören diese Spezien 75% der Blüten und Früchte und sind das wichtigste entomologische Problem in der Biozönose. Ein bedeutender Faktor für die Wirtschaftlichkeit des Systems spielen die solitäre Bienenart Centris mixta Friese und die eingeführte Honigbiene Apis mellifica in der Nutzung des Tamarugo als „Waldweide” in einer der extremen Wüsten der Welt. 1978 Blackwell Verlag GmbH

Title: Induction of caste differentiation in the honey bee (Apis mellifera L.) after topical application of JH-III
Affiliations: Laboratory of Entomology, Agricultural University, Binnenhaven 7, Wageningen, Netherlands
Authors with affiliations: Goewie, E.A., Laboratory of Entomology, Agricultural University, Binnenhaven 7, Wageningen, Netherlands

Authors: Fluri P., Wille H., Gerig L., Lüscher M.
Title: Juvenile hormone, vitellogenin and haemocyte composition in winter worker honeybees (Apis mellifera)
Affiliations: Division of Animal Physiology, Zoological Institute of the University of Bern, Engehaldenstrasse 6, Bern, CH-3012, Switzerland; Apicultural Section, Federal Dairy Research Station, Liebefeld-Bern, CH-3097, Switzerland
Authors with affiliations: Fluri, P., Division of Animal Physiology, Zoological Institute of the University of Bern, Engehaldenstrasse 6, Bern, CH-3012, Switzerland, Apicultural Section, Federal Dairy Research Station, Liebefeld-Bern, CH-3097, Switzerland; Wille, H., Division of Animal Physiology, Zoological Institute of the University of Bern, Engehaldenstrasse 6, Bern, CH-3012, Switzerland, Apicultural Section, Federal Dairy Research Station, Liebefeld-Bern, CH-3097, Switzerland; Gerig, L., Division of Animal Physiology, Zoological Institute of the University of Bern, Engehaldenstrasse 6, Bern, CH-3012, Switzerland, Apicultural Section, Federal Dairy Research Station, Liebefeld-Bern, CH-3097, Switzerland; Lüscher, M., Division of Animal Physiology, Zoological Institute of the University of Bern, Engehaldenstrasse 6, Bern, CH-3012, Switzerland, Apicultural Section, Federal Dairy Research Station, Liebefeld-Bern, CH-3097, Switzerland
Abstract: The haemolymph of winter bees (long life span) in contrast to that of summer bees (short life span) has a low juvenile hormone titre and a high protein titre. It is suggested that the winter bee physiology may be brought about by low JH-production. © 1977 Birkhäuser Verlag.

Authors: Copijn G.M., Beetsma J., Wirtz P.
Title: Queen differentiation and mortality after topical application of different juvenile hormone analogues on worker larvae of the honey bee (Apis mellifera L.)
Affiliations: Laboratory of Entomology, Agricultural University, Binnenhaven 7, Wageningen, Netherlands
