Authors: Rutz W., Gerig L., Wille H., Lüscher M.
Title: The function of juvenile hormone in adult worker honeybees, Apis mellifera
Affiliations: Division of Animal Physiology, Zoological Institute, the University of Bern, Engehaldenstrasse 6, CH-3012 Bern, Switzerland; Federal Dairy Research Station, Apicultural Section, CH-3097 Liebefeld-Bern, Switzerland
Authors with affiliations: Rutz, W., Division of Animal Physiology, Zoological Institute, the University of Bern, Engehaldenstrasse 6, CH-3012 Bern, Switzerland, Federal Dairy Research Station, Apicultural Section, CH-3097 Liebefeld-Bern, Switzerland; Gerig, L., Division of Animal Physiology, Zoological Institute, the University of Bern, Engehaldenstrasse 6, CH-3012 Bern, Switzerland, Federal Dairy Research Station, Apicultural Section, CH-3097 Liebefeld-Bern, Switzerland; Wille, H., Division of Animal Physiology, Zoological Institute, the University of Bern, Engehaldenstrasse 6, CH-3012 Bern, Switzerland, Federal Dairy Research Station, Apicultural Section, CH-3097 Liebefeld-Bern, Switzerland; Lüscher, M., Division of Animal Physiology, Zoological Institute, the University of Bern, Engehaldenstrasse 6, CH-3012 Bern, Switzerland, Federal Dairy Research Station, Apicultural Section, CH-3097 Liebefeld-Bern, Switzerland
Abstract: The injection of high doses of JH-III into adult worker honeybees causes the hypopharyngeal glands to degenerate and lowers the vitellogenin synthesis rate as well as the total haemolymph protein concentration. The injection of low doses increases the protein titre and stimulates vitellogenin synthesis while the hypopharyngeal glands develop. The effects of high doses of JH corresponds to the normal physiological changes in the ageing bee, especially at the time of the transformation into field bees. Hormone titre measurements show a drastic increase during adult life, which together with the injection experiments seems to indicate stimulating effects of low JH titre on protein synthesis and hypopharyngeal gland development during the first phase of adult life, and inhibiting and degeneration inducing effects of the high JH titre during the second phase of life. Thus it is possible that the physiological changes correlated with changes in behaviour of the adult worker bee are controlled by the JH titre. © 1976.

Authors: Wright D.A., Neff R.D., O'Connor R.
Title: The radioprotective quality of glycylhistamine and the venom of Apis mellifera (honeybee)
Affiliations: Texas A&M Univ., College Station, Tex. 77840, United States
Authors with affiliations: Wright, D.A., Texas A&M Univ., College Station, Tex. 77840, United States; Neff, R.D., Texas A&M Univ., College Station, Tex. 77840, United States; O'Connor, R., Texas A&M Univ., College Station, Tex. 77840, United States
Abstract: [No abstract available]

Title: Retrograde amnesia in honeybees (Apis mellifera carnica)
Source title: Journal of Comparative and Physiological Psychology
Affiliations: Technische Hochschule Darmstadt, Zoologisches Inst, Germany
Authors with affiliations: Erber, J., Technische Hochschule Darmstadt, Zoologisches Inst, Germany
Abstract: After a single reward on a spectral color, 48 freely flying honeybees showed retrograde amnesia when an ECS, CO2 narcosis, N2 narcosis, or cooling (to 1Deg. C) was applied after learning. Retrograde amnesia was measurable with these 4 treatments up to 7 min after the reward. For none of the treatments was a consistent relationship found between the reaction tested and the time of testing after the treatment. Prolonged application of the 4 treatments led to a significant increase in the rate of retrograde amnesia only after CO2 narcosis. Memory was susceptible to impairment until 15 min after the reward. (23 ref) (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2006 APA, all rights reserved). © 1976 American Psychological Association.
Author Keywords: ECS vs CO sub 2 narcosis vs N sub 2 narcosis vs cooling after learning, retrograde amnesia, honeybees

Title: Degenerative changes in heart muscle from senescent honeybee workers (Apis mellifera adansonii)
Affiliations: Departamento de Morfologia Animal, Faculdade de Filosofia, Ciencias e Letras. 13.500 Rio Claro, SP, Brazil
Authors with affiliations: Cruz-Landim, C.D., Departamento de Morfologia Animal, Faculdade de Filosofia, Ciencias e Letras. 13.500 Rio Claro, SP, Brazil
Abstract: The electron microscope of cardiac muscles from the honeybee showed degenerative alterations due to aging. The ultrastructural alterations appear mainly in the mitochondria and myofibrils. Lysosomes play some role in the degenerative process. © 1976.

Title: Temperature maintenance and CO2 concentration in a swarm cluster of honey bees, Apis mellifera
Source title: Comparative Biochemistry and Physiology -- Part A: Physiology
Affiliations: Laboratory of Nuclear Medicine and Radiation Biology, Department of Biology, University of California, Los Angeles, CA 90024, United States
Authors with affiliations: Nagy, K.A., Laboratory of Nuclear Medicine and Radiation Biology, Department of Biology, University of California, Los Angeles, CA 90024, United States; Stallone, J.N., Laboratory of Nuclear Medicine and Radiation Biology, Department of Biology, University of California, Los Angeles, CA 90024, United States
Abstract: 1. 1. A swarm cluster of bees had a nearly constant core temperature (mean = 34.0°C) despite air temperatures that ranged from 4.0 to 16.4°C. 2. 2. Core CO2 concentrations were inversely correlated with air temperatures, suggesting that the bees regulated cluster temperature by appropriate variation of their rate of heat production. 3. 3. Contraction of the cluster to conserve heat at the lower air temperatures was not detectable. © 1976.

Title: Ultrastructure of the contact chemoreceptors of Apis mellifera L. (Hymenoptera : Apidae)
Source title: International Journal of Insect Morphology and Embryology
Affiliations: Department of Entomology, University of Illinois, Urbana, IL 61801, United States
Authors with affiliations: Whitehead, A.T., Department of Entomology, University of Illinois, Urbana, IL 61801, United States; Larsen, J.R., Department of Entomology, University of Illinois, Urbana, IL 61801, United States
Abstract: Sensilla chaetica of different sizes were found by scanning electron microscopy on the glossa, labial palps, galeae, antennae and tarsi of the worker honey bee. Sensilla basiconica also were found on these structures, except the antennae and glossa. With the exception of the mandibles, whose sensilla are all innervated by one sensory neuron, transmission electron microscope studies showed these receptors are similar in ultrastructure to taste receptors previously described in other insects. It was determined that sensilla on the mouthparts and tarsi possess 5 sensory neurons, one of which ends at the sensilla base as a mechanoreceptor, the other 4 extending up the lumen of a two-chambered hair. Many of the sensilla are tipped with either a pore or a papilla. About half of the sensilla observed on the antennae are innervated by 6 sensory neurons. A peculiarly shaped sensillum trichodeum occurs on the mandible which breaks off at pupal eclosion. A spatulate peg on the tarsal claw is also present. © 1976.
Author Keywords: honey bee; Scanning electron microscopy; sensilla basiconica; sensilla chaetica; taste receptors; transmission electron microscopy

Title: An electrophoretic and pH comparison of the soluble trehalases of several insect species
Source title: Comparative Biochemistry and Physiology -- Part B: Biochemistry and
Affiliations: Biochemistry Group, Department of Chemistry, University of Calgary, Calgary, Alta., Canada
Authors with affiliations: Talbot, B.G., Biochemistry Group, Department of Chemistry, University of Calgary, Calgary, Alta., Canada; Huber, R.E., Biochemistry Group, Department of Chemistry, University of Calgary, Calgary, Alta., Canada
Abstract: 1. 1. Trehalases of a number of insects were shown to vary in terms of their electrophoretic mobilities and pH optima. 2. 2. The thorax trehalases of Apis mellifera and Drosophila melanogaster had different electrophoretic and pH characteristics compared to their respective abdominal trehalases. This was not found to be the case for the trehalases of the other insects studied. 3. 3. The thorax trehalase of Apis mellifera was distinct from any of the other trehalases studied. It showed an unusual biphasic pH optimum curve in contrast with the single bell shaped pH optima of the intestinal trehalase of Apis mellifera and of the trehalases of all of the other insects studied. 4. 4. When the variation of the Vmax of a purified thorax trehalase from honey bees was compared to the variation of the Vmax of a purified abdominal enzyme at various pHs it was seen that these two enzymes were distinctly different. © 1976.

Authors: GAULDIE J., HANSON J.M., RUMJANEK F.D., SHIPOLINI R.A., VERNON C.A.
Title: The Peptide Components of Bee Venom
Affiliations: Department of Biochemistry, Mcmaster University, 1200 Main Street West, Hamilton, Ontario, L8S 4J9, Canada; Department of Immunology, The Mathilda and Terence Kennedy Institute of Rheumatology, Bute Gardens, London, United Kingdom; Christopher Ingold Laboratories, Department of Chemistry, University College London, 20 Gordon Street, London, WC1H OAJ, United Kingdom
Authors with affiliations: GAULDIE, J., Department of Biochemistry, Mcmaster University, 1200 Main Street West, Hamilton, Ontario, L8S 4J9, Canada; HANSON, J.M., Department of Immunology, The Mathilda and Terence Kennedy Institute of Rheumatology, Bute Gardens, London, United Kingdom; RUMJANEK, F.D., Christopher Ingold Laboratories, Department of Chemistry, University College London, 20 Gordon Street, London, WC1H OAJ, United Kingdom; SHIPOLINI, R.A., Christopher Ingold Laboratories, Department of Chemistry, University College London, 20 Gordon Street, London, WC1H OAJ, United Kingdom; VERNON, C.A., Christopher Ingold Laboratories, Department of Chemistry, University College London, 20 Gordon Street, London, WC1H OAJ, United Kingdom
Abstract: A procedure is described for the simultaneous separation of all the peptides (other than those present in trace amounts) contained in the venom of the common European honey bee (Apis mellifera). Three new peptides have been isolated: one is a fragment of the known peptide melittin. Some properties of the peptides are described. Copyright © 1976, Wiley Blackwell. All rights reserved

Authors: Bailey L., Ball B.V., Woods R.D.
Title: An iridovirus from bees
Affiliations: Rothamsted Exp. Stat., Harpenden, United Kingdom
Authors with affiliations: Bailey, L., Rothamsted Exp. Stat., Harpenden, United Kingdom; Ball, B.V., Rothamsted Exp. Stat., Harpenden, United Kingdom; Woods, R.D., Rothamsted Exp. Stat., Harpenden, United Kingdom
Abstract: An iridovirus, Apis iridescent virus (AIV), isolated from sick adult specimens of Apis cerana (Hymenoptera) from Kashmir, closely resembles iridescent viruses from Tipula and Sericesthis spp. (TIV and SIV). However, AIV is only distantly related serologically to TIV and SIV and is even more remotely related to several other similar viruses that were tested in tube precipitation tests with intact particles. AIV multiplied in Apis mellifera, forming cytoplasmic iridescent crystalline aggregates in several tissues, but unlike all the other iridoviruses tested, it failed to multiply in Galleria mellonella.

Authors: Ishay J., Gitter S., Galun R., Doron M., Laron Z.
Title: The presence of insulin in and some effects of exogenous insulin on hymenoptera tissues and body fluids
Source title: Comparative Biochemistry and Physiology -- Part A: Physiology
Affiliations: Department of Physiology and Pharmacology, Israel; Israel Institute for Biological Research, Ness Ziona, Israel; Institute of Pediatric and Adolescent Endocrinology, Beilinson Hospital, Sackler School of Medicine, Israel
Authors with affiliations: Ishay, J., Department of Physiology and Pharmacology, Israel; Gitter, S., Department of Physiology and Pharmacology, Israel; Galun, R., Israel Institute for Biological Research, Ness Ziona, Israel; Doron, M., Institute of Pediatric and Adolescent Endocrinology, Beilinson Hospital, Sackler School of Medicine, Israel; Laron, Z., Institute of Pediatric and Adolescent Endocrinology, Beilinson Hospital, Sackler School of Medicine, Israel
Abstract: Abstracto1.Radioimmunoassay technique has revealed the presence of insulin in the tissues of various Hymenopteran insects, including the honeybee Apis mellifera, the Oriental hornet Vespa orientalis and several other Paleoarctic social wasps, the Mason bee Chalicodoma sicula, the cuckoo wasp Chrysis sp. and the weaver ant Polyrachis simplex.2.Laboratory determinations carried out in vivo and in vitro on several insects have shown that bovine insulin injected into insect hemolymph or incubated together with the hemolymph causes a significant drop in the glucose level of the fluid. © 1976 Pergamon Press Ltd.

Authors: Engels W., Goncalves L.S., Engels E., Engels W.
Title: Effects of carbon dioxide on vitellogenin metabolism in unmated queen honeybees
Affiliations: Departamento de Genética, Universidade de São Paulo, Ribeirão Preto, SP, Brazil; Zoologisches Institut der Universität Münster/Westfalen, D-44 Münster, Badestrasse, Germany
Authors with affiliations: Engels, W., Departamento de Genética, Universidade de São Paulo, Ribeirão Preto, SP, Brazil; Goncalves, L.S., Departamento de Genética, Universidade de São Paulo, Ribeirão Preto, SP, Brazil; Engels, E., Departamento de Genética, Universidade de São Paulo, Ribeirão Preto, SP, Brazil; Engels, W., Zoologisches Institut der Universität Münster/Westfalen, D-44 Münster, Badestrasse, Germany
Abstract: Sixty-one young virgin queen honeybees (Apis mellifera adansonii hybrids) received a double CO2 narcosis, as usually applied in instrumental insemination. These (non-inseminated) queens were then introduced into nucleus colonies. Within 2 days of the second CO2 treatment vitellogenin synthesis was stimulated rapidly, resulting in a doubling of the vitellogenin content of the haemo-lymph. A further slow increase of vitellogenin synthesis during the next 6 days indicated the initiation of vitellogenesis, which resulted a slight decline in the vitellogenin content of the haemolymph, and also an increase of about 50% in the body weight. All values levelled off in egg-laying queens.The effects described did not occur in 8 control queens which remained caged after the second CO2 application. It is therefore concluded that there was social conditioning of the queen’s vitellogenin metabolism. © 1976 International Bee Research Association.

Title: Characteristic field symptoms comprising honeybee hairless-black syndrome induced in the laboratory by a virus
Affiliations: Department of Entomology, The Ohio State University, Columbus, OH 43210, United States
Authors with affiliations: Rinderer, T.E., Department of Entomology, The Ohio State University, Columbus, OH 43210, United States; Rothenbuhler, W.C., Department of Entomology, The Ohio State University, Columbus, OH 43210, United States
Abstract: All the characteristic symptoms comprising hairless-black syndrome found in the field were reproduced in the laboratory by transferring virus-fed adult honeybees, Apis mellifera, to cages containing healthy bees. The experimental, virus-fed bees showed high mortality and various combinations of other symptoms, such as paralysis, withdrawal from the cluster, trembling, subjection to attack by healthy bees, and the hairless-black condition. Control bees, treated identically except not fed virus, displayed none of these symptoms. Virus-fed bees transmitted the disease to other bees; control bees did not. Suspensions made from experimental bees contained virus; suspensions made from control bees did not. It is concluded that the virus is the causal agent of hairless-black syndrome. © 1976.

Title: The availability of environmental radioactivity to honey bee colonies at Los Alamos
Affiliations: Los Alamos Sci. Lab., Los Alamos, N.M. 87545, United States
Authors with affiliations: Hakonson, T.E., Los Alamos Sci. Lab., Los Alamos, N.M. 87545, United States; Bostick, K.V., Los Alamos Sci. Lab., Los Alamos, N.M. 87545, United States
Abstract: Data are presented on the availability of tritium, cesium 137, and plutonium to honey bee colonies foraging in the environment surrounding the Los Alamos Scientific Laboratory. Sources of these radionuclides in the laboratory environs include liquid and atmospheric effluents and buried solid waste. Honey bee colonies were placed in three canyon liquid waste disposal areas and were sampled frequently, along with honey, surface water, and surrounding vegetation, to qualitatively determine the availability of these radionuclides to bees (Apis mellifera) and to identify potential food chain sources of the elements. Tritium concentrations in bee and honey samples from the canyons increased rapidly from initial values of <1 pCi/ml moisture to as much as 9.2 nCi/ml in 75 days after placement of the hives in the canyons. Seasonal patterns in foraging activities as influenced by weather and food availability were apparent in the data. It appears that several sources of tritium were utilized by the colonies, including surface water in the canyons and vegetation receiving tritium from atmospheric effluents and buried solid waste. Concentrations of cesium 137 and plutonium were generally low or undetectable in bees throughout the study. However, levels of both nuclides increased by factors of 10-20 in bees from two of the canyon study areas during a 3 month period in 1973. It was speculated that the liquid effluents in the two canyons were the source of the increased concentrations in bee samples, since this water was the only significant source of 137Cs in the environs. The existence of at least three radionuclide sources in the Los Alamos Scientific Laboratory (LASL) environs complicates the interpretation of the data. However, it is apparent that honey bees can acquire 3H, 137Cs, and Pu from multiple sources in the environs.Data are presented on the availability of tritium, cesium-137, and plutonium to honey bee colonies foraging in the environment surrounding the Los Alamos Scientific Laboratory. Sources of these radionuclides in the laboratory environs include liquid and atmospheric effluents and buried solid waste. Honey bee colonies were placed in three canyon liquid waste disposal areas and were sampled frequently, along with honey, surface water, and surrounding vegetation, to qualitatively determine the availability of these radionuclides to bees (Apis mellifera) and to identify potential food chain sources of the elements.

Authors: Sobotka A.K., Franklin R.M., Adkinson Jr. N.F., Valentine M., Baer H., Lichtenstein L.M.
Title: Allergy to insect stings. II. Phospholipase A: The major allergen in honeybee venom
Source title: The Journal of Allergy and Clinical Immunology
Affiliations: Johns Hopkins University School of Medicine Baltimore, MD, United States
Authors with affiliations: Sobotka, A.K., Johns Hopkins University School of Medicine Baltimore, MD, United States; Franklin, R.M., Johns Hopkins University School of Medicine Baltimore, MD, United States; Adkinson Jr., N.F., Johns Hopkins University School of Medicine Baltimore, MD, United States; Valentine, M., Johns Hopkins University School of Medicine Baltimore, MD, United States; Baer, H., Johns Hopkins University School of Medicine Baltimore, MD, United States; Lichtenstein, L.M., Johns Hopkins University School of Medicine Baltimore, MD, United States
Abstract: In order to determine the proteins of major allergenic importance in honeybee venom (Apis mellifera) it was chromatographed on G-50 Sephadex. The four major protein peaks eluted were identified as hyaluronidase, phospholipase, melittin, and apamin. Testing these preparations on the leukocytes of 6 honeybee-sensitive patients, with the in vitro method of histamine release, revealed that all individuals were most sensitive to phospholipase A. IgE antibodies against phospholipase A (RAST) were found in the sera of honeybee-sensitive patients and IgG antibodies to this venom component were found in the sera from beekeepers and venom-treated patients. Melittin appeared to be allergenic in several patients, but the results were variable and were possibly due to contamination with phospholipase. All patients were insensitive to the hyaluronidase and apamin preparations. We conclude that phospholipase A is the major allergen of honeybee venom and, since this protein is readily available, it should be useful for diagnostic and therapeutic studies as well as for the standardization of materials used in the management of honeybee-sensitive patients. © 1976.

Authors: Sobotka A.K., Franklin R.M., Franklin Adkinson Jr. N., Valentine M., Baer H., Lichtenstein L.M.
Title: Allergy to insect stings. II. Phospholipase A: the major allergen in honeybee venom
Source title: Journal of Allergy and Clinical Immunology
Affiliations: The Johns Hopkins University, School of Medicine, Baltimore, MD, United States; The Bureau of Biologics, Food and Drug Administration, Rockville, MD, United States
Authors with affiliations: Sobotka, A.K., The Johns Hopkins University, School of Medicine, Baltimore, MD, United States; Franklin, R.M., The Johns Hopkins University, School of Medicine, Baltimore, MD, United States; Franklin Adkinson Jr., N., The Johns Hopkins University, School of Medicine, Baltimore, MD, United States; Valentine, M., The Johns Hopkins University, School of Medicine, Baltimore, MD, United States; Baer, H., The Johns Hopkins University, School of Medicine, Baltimore, MD, United States, The Bureau of Biologics, Food and Drug Administration, Rockville, MD, United States; Lichtenstein, L.M., The Johns Hopkins University, School of Medicine, Baltimore, MD, United States
Abstract: In order to determine the proteins of major allergenic importance in honeybee venom (Apis mellifera) it was chromatographed on G 50 Sephadex.
